Classically conceived dry stout from one of the well-respected Californian craft beer pioneers; ingredients list literally says "water, barley, malt, hops, yeast and thats all", as if they want to make a statement against all those more recent, trendy stouts with special flavorings added... I like the design, almost looks like a classic English bottle and label, like most of North Coasts bottles. Thick, frothy, beaten egg-like, yellowish hued head leaving a thick coating of membranous lacing all around, blackish appearance but actually a very deep purple-hued bronze, completely translucent (but hardly so and under bright light). Aroma of cold black coffee, coffee beans even, fairly subtle bitter chocolate, soaked bayleaf, beef stock cubes, burnt branches, leather, liquorish candy, mocha, faintly sweetish aromas of horse steak, unripe elderberries, tomato concentrate and stewed white beans, in warming up even something vaguely sweet sherry-like. Soft, initially somewhat neutral onset, shyly revealing dried fruit sweetishness paired with equally subtle umami (beef stock but only vaguely so), underlying roasted barley sourishness pulling things forward to a pleasantly rounded, nutty and toasted bittersweet malt core, gaining confidence in the end with a coffeeish roasted bitterness filling the mouth cavity; under soft carbonation, the mouthfeel is slick and smooth, but full and pleasant, just right for a stout at session strength. Spicy, even slightly tonic water-like hop bitter notes reinforce the roasted bitterness in the end, but that rounded, sweetish, nutty flavor lingers just as well. Dry stout alright, still carrying sweetness to give it balance and rotundity - this is a very appetizing example of its style. Fairly classic in comparison with so many younger West Coast craft breweries, North Coast is still a resounding name for its historical influence alone, and still delivers consistent quality in its (relatively speaking) classically designed beers - not unlike Sierra Nevada, I reckon.

 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance  The beer almost pitch black deep-deep brown color with a one finger head of a cream color. The head has a good level of retention, sitting around for some time before fading to leave a nice level of streaky lace on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma of the beer is heaviest of a nice roasted malt smell with dark chocolate and a notes of coffee. Some light smells of vanilla and caramel are mixed in with the darker and roasted aromas producing a somewhat semi-sweet chocolate bar like smell.

 Taste  The taste begins a bit sweeter than the nose would have let on with some vanilla and brown sugar sweetness mixed with a nice roasted flavor. A little bit of chocolate is upfront as well, but this remains relatively light throughout the taste. In opposition to the chocolate, the coffee begins very light but increases quite a bit as the flavors advance, becoming the dominant darker flavor toward the end of the flavor profile. With the coffees increase in intensity, the bitterness of the beer increases as well, and with a slight increase in the sweetness, due to a bit of a cola flavor coming to the tongue at the end of the taste, one is left with a bitter-sweet, dark roasted coffee flavor to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the slightly thicker side for a brew of 5.6 % abv. with a slightly lower carbonation level. The slightly thicker body and lower carbonation are great for the darker flavors of the brew all while not being too low or too thick to keep it from being drinkable.

 Overall  A nice Irish stout. Not the driest out there in terms of its sweetness but a very nice and easy drinker none the less. Very enjoyable.

(bottle).  Nice roasted malt aroma with some vanilla. Deep brown complexion with thin tan head.  Flavors of roasted malt and some coffee.  Thin palate.

Draught @ Oliver Twist. Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a small creamy pale mocha head that doesnt leave much trace while dissipating. Pours a brownish black with tan head. Nose is roasted malts and taste has a nice chocolate and coffee flavor suttle but there.

Poured into a beer mug.

A: Pours a very dark brown color. The head is a three finger tan color with good retention and lacing. It doesnt have the beauty of Guinness, but as the old saying goes, looks aint everything...

S: I really like the subtle chocolate notes this give off, but I also smell a light fruitiness from the esters alongside the typical roast. Not much coffee on the nose, but still a good smell.

T: This has a bit of a milk stout vibe to it, with its lactic twang and light milk chocolate notes intertwining with its roasty base. Just like in the smell, this could use a little more coffee. The back end of the flavor profile sees hints of fruitiness pop up. Not insanely complex, but well balanced and very likable.

M: Light-medium body, with subtle dryness on the finish and medium carbonation. Mild astringency give a pleasant tingling on the tongue, without going overboard.

O: Looking back on it, I regret not buying a six pack of this. Impressive stuff.

A-- Poured a dark brownish cola color and settled black with a few small tints of ruby here and there. Mocha colored head, one finger in height. Has good staying power until finally fading to film. Two finger height in swirling. No lacing. 

S-- Roasted malts, chocolate and Carmel. Very soft smelling at first and flavors pick up more with air. 

T-- Thin and watery taste. Bits of water, roasted malts, chocolate, and Carmel. Very watery up front. 

M-- Medium carbonation and lighter feel. Small bit of watery gap in the mid palate but much better than the taste. Decent amount of sweet carmel, dairy milk and roasted malts in the back palate. Finishes dry and sweet with lingering sweetness. 

O-- What beer lacks for in taste, it makes up for in feel. Easy to drink but in a way bordering more on a dark brown ale. Nothing too exciting but it is quite sessionable.
Smooth, light, mild nutty, with a hint of sweet stout taste. Had a quick bite that doesn't last.

Draught.
Pours a really dark brown, with a beige head.
Roasted aroma, malt, chocolate, licorice, hops, caramel, ash.

Faint aromas of dough and light coffee. Pours a solid black with some brown tint. Subtle bittering hop bite at first, followed by a slightly watery thin coffee flavors. 330 ml bottle pours dark amber with tan head. Head that just shot up the glass served at room temperature. Not as bad when was cooler. Aroma of caramel, vanilla, toffee. Taste of smooth sweet burnt toffee with very slight tart beginning. Medium bodied with toffee aftertaste. Less tart when flat.
Pours black..big thick brown head.. Aroma is fruity metallic alchol.. Taste is good. Smooth...nothing special but good
12oz bottle. FLBC. Pours thin, black. Some tan head. Aroma... yeah. Flavor? Yep. and a dry finish. Your run of the mill stout, here. Nothing more, nothing less.

The odd experience with the Anchor Porter did make me somehow uneasy about what to expect from the Californian Old No. 38 Stout. But those two were just like water and wine. And Sicilian wine, for that matter: fortified Marsala. Exactly what comes out to start with, so delicious with the aroma of this Old No. 38: Port, Dry Sherry, but most specifically, Marsala. Its a fabulous beer! Beautiful mocha head. Not sure if theres still any Exxon Valdez on the North Coast, but the persisting foam does have a suggestion of brine and tar, which blend just perfectly with the roasted malt flavours, chocolate notes and raisin overtones of Medoncino grapes. Not a hint of cannabis though. So far this North Coast stout is the best American stout I have had.

Tap at Oliver Twist. Black with red tints and a short brown "film" of foam.
Roasted malt in the aroma and a bit sour. Burnt bread and dishrag with hints of cold weak coffee and chocolate.
Taste is pretty thin and acidic but sweet with weak coffee, chocolate and lemon. Decent but pretty boring.

Had a taster at the Hopping Pig in Gaslamp. From the tap (nitro beer). Poured rich, deep and dark. Head was beige to white and creamy. Taste was not heavy or overwhelming. Definitely a beer I would stick with throughout the evening. Would highly recommend!

(Draught at Oliver Twist, 20120627) The beer poured black. Its head was small and white. Aroma had roasted malts and liquorice. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were roasted malts, liquorice, hops, mildly ash and medium bitterness. Aftertaste had liquorice, roasted malts and bitterness. A very tasty mild (for US standards) stout.
Fruity, metallic. Tastes like what every other brew pub puts out. No distinctiveness.

12oz bottle - pours black with nice beige head.  Nose is roasty and chocolate.  Flavor adds coffee.  Taste is a little sweet but mainly bitter from the roast.  Dry finish with some stickiness.  Medium to full body and easy to drink.  Other than pound cake, I really dont know how to pair this.  no burp to report.

355ml bottle. Dark brown to black in colour with a cola coloured soft head. Looks strong in the glass. Great aroma of dark chocolate, vanilla and malt. Smooth velvet texture and mouthfeel with a lingering aftertaste. A good honest stout.

Bottle.  Pours black with two fingers of rocky tan head that dissipates pretty quickly.  Aroma has tons of dark malt with some mocha notes. North Coast seems to excel in stout making. This is another fine example. While its not an Imperial stout, it had decent blend of
coffee, roast, earth tones, dark raisin and toffee flavors.
 
A good DRY stout.

At just on cool and into a snifter. Deepest, darkest brown in body, just shy of black, and opaque. Solid, compact and tight dollop of tannish cream rests there for the length to leave a very fine lace. Aroma is dominated by molasses with nuances of smoke, cocoa butter, kecap manis, peat and almond nougat, sultry. Deliciously rich on the palate, full and rounded. Firm, meaty body, very smooth in back and oily finish with a light spritz to tickle the tip of the tongue. Bitter/sweet dark chocolate dominates, good lot of smoke, wood and peat comes through as does a cheeky showing of earthy, herbal, almost Noble hops.Very well balanced. Burnt bitter malt, smoke, tar and the hops linger long between each sip. This is a smashing good stout. Mouthfilling, complex yet deadly sessionable. Impressive. (12fl.Oz, no date stamp, Cellarbrations Carlisle)

12 oz bottle pours an opaque dark brown/black with a tan head and good lacing.  Smells like currants and raisins.  Aroma has those plus lots of roasted malts.  Hops kick in for a bitter finish. Pouring as black as the coal that likely fueled engine No. 38, this stout from North Coast offers quite the inviting aroma, as well. Overflowing with caramel, currants, and raisins. Overall, another very impressive brew from North Coast. It takes a bit to get used to all the fruit notes, but the charred and toasted character along with peppery hops lead to a very nice balance. Pick this up when you find it!

Tap.  Pours a dark brown with a large, tan head.  Roasted malt aroma.  A little thin but a nice flavor of roasted malts and coffee with a underlying sweetness. Very smooth with a nicely bitter finish.

Bottle from Andersons general store. Pours black with a half inch of khaki foam.It doesnt leave any lacing.  Barley on the nose. Roasted chocolate on the tongue. Finishes smooth.

Firm bitterness in the finish rounds things out. This isnt really a headturning brew but its completely solid and drinkable and would make for a very fine everyday stout if you can get it reliably fresh.
poured nice with a decent head that faded quickly.  Tasted coffee burnt malts, bitter chocolate, with a dry bitter aftertaste.

Really nicely muted beer. Up front it presents some chocolate, maybe coffee and roasted malts. Reasonably light in the mouth with low to medium carbonation. All in all, a good beer that you wouldnt get sick of in a session.

Pours a dark motor oil color. Smells or roasted malts, dark chocolate and toffee. Taste is full bodies with nice hints of the chocolate and roasted malts. All in all a good stout if you are looking to try something new.

Enjoyed while trying to mentally chill out after a long work week, given to me by my friend Kate for my birthday.  Thanks Kate!  Appearance is a very dark black with a thin lightly tan head that rims to the glass, not super thick, can see a dark brown hue at the bottom of the glass when holding it up to light. Deep brown black pour thin off white head ... aroma of roasted malts, sweet dark fruity yeast, light coffee and chocolate .... taste of roasted malts, light coffee and chocolate with a sweet fruit light a dark fruity yeast ... dry finish not bad simple stout

Bottle.  Pours black with a medium tan head and some nice lacing.  Aroma is lots of molasses with caramel, toffee, some coffee and chocolate, and cherry and, oddly but tastily, blueberry.  Actually, theres a lot of blueberry in the nose.  Wonderfully complex aroma.  The flavor is a bit of a letdown:  its rich and well-balanced, but a little chalky and fairly bitter.  It smooths out as it warms up.  Lots of roasted and nearly burnt malt, some coffee and chocolate, but almost none of the toffee and fruit from the nose.  A bit overcarbonated.  Otherwise a medium palate.
just a very bland non-inventive, boring dry stout. Not much for flavors, although pleasant and non-offensive

Bottle. Black when poured with a decent beige head.  Good lacing.  The aroma has hints of chocolate and roasted coffee.  Tastes sweet, has some dark chocolate and a roasted flavor to it.  Finishes dry, still with a roasted flavor.  A very solid beer for sure, makes up for some of North Coasts lesser beers. 5.6% alcohol.
on tap@ the union.. nice and dry. roasty. good bite on it for a low abv beer. i enjoyed it.
Much like an amplified Guiness or Guiness Extra Stout, a basic stout, no bells and whistles, just a decent stout.

Roasty with hints of coffee. Brown head, but not much. Fairly opaque dark brown. Moderate bitterness in the middle, with just subtle hints of sweetness. Very clean, medium body feel, not much in the way of carbonation. Overall, a very clean, simple, refined beer.

12oz bottle from 16th St.Liquor in West Vancouver. Pours dark brown with ruby tint, small tan head that quickly diminishes. Aroma is dry, roasted barley with some chocolate notes. The flavour is very dry, roasted, coffee, some dark chocolate. Finish is medium length and dry.

Sampled at the Black Hills Beer Fest.  I was pretty amped to try this one.  It definitely was a let down.  Pretty mediocre flavor for a stout.  I wouldnt recommend wasting money on this one.  It was better than a swift kick to the nuts.
Draft @ blind tiger. Same look and consistency as a guinness. Smell is slightly more floral. Taste is malty with a fruity aftertaste. Not very complex. Not vey bad. Not great...but good

interesting caramel apple like aroma with dark fruitiness and plenty of maltiness as well..black brown liquid qith dark red around the edges,tan head foamy leaving good lacing..tastes of caramel,roasty malts,raisins,other dark fruit,chocolate,wine,sort of a root beer like flavor too..again interesting in a nice way..aftertaste of sweet wine and chocolate..overall fairly sweet but unusual for the style and full flavored for the low abv

Bottle pout in Lake Tahoe. Solid black with a medium head that held up. Nose of dark roasted coffee which shows up prominently in the taste as well. Medium bitterness lingers. Approachable for a stout.

Pours like a dark stout with a light brown, spongy head.  However, this beer has strong notes of burnt toast and charcoal and has a soda-poppy carbonation to it. Glad I tried it but will pass next time. $1.99/12oz

A great looking beer that just doesnt seem to measure up to my expectations. Based on the scores others have for this beer, I may have a bad bottle, but other than a hint of autolysis in the nose (and the bottle is well within BB - thought to be fair, has travelled to New Zealand) there are no off flavours. Standard roasty coffee notes on the nose, thinish in the mouth. It looks beautiful, a rich shiny black with a mocha head. Other than appearance though, its a firmly average beer.
Draught. Pours really. shiny black. Really pretty beer.  Some chocolate and maltiness and creamy smoKe if that makes sense.

Smell is roasty with notes of coffee and a bit of dried fruit. Pours an opaque black even when held up to light; one finger of tan head which dissipates quickly. Taste is robust, roasted malts with just a bit of sweetness upon finish. Slightly bitter aftertaste and light mouthcoat. Fairly drinkable; quite strong for such a low ABV stout.

Very dark brownish/black color with a few deep ruby highlights when held towards the light.  Thick tan head.  Creamy and full.  The retention wasnt exceptionally long, but it hung around for a few minutes then settles to a nice film.  Pretty good lacing too.  Roastiness comes forth first in the nose.  Getting a type of dark fruitiness.  Like a deep cherry or a deep, dark plum.  Picking up some hints of coffee and dark chocolate.  The taste mimics the smell very well.  The roasted malt and dark fruit are present, but I also found a mint-chocolate chip ice cream sort of flavor.  It was subtle, but there.  Couldve just been me.  It wasnt unpleasant.  Kind of interesting.  Medium mouthfeel.  Nice and smooth.  Creamy.  Bountiful amounts of flavor left on the palate.  Dry and delicate.  Goes down way to easy.  I like it.  This is a very sound and agreeable Stout.  Perfect for those cold Winter nights.  Its a session beer for me.  I would love to pick this up again.  I want another one.  Goes down easy and is not overly filling.  A very, very, very nice beer.  Cheers!!!!

Black as a moonless night with a thin tan head.  Sweet, inviting aroma with chocolate, coffee, and malt standing out.  The palate is medium and smooth with a decent carbonation bite.  Wonderful flavor backs up the great aroma.  Semisweet chocolate and coffee and cream up front.  A dry finish with a touch of ash.  Wonderful stout.
Black, frothy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, fruit and roasted malts. Taste is the same, mostly malty, some milk sweetness. Medium body, soft carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 On tap at The Blind Lady Alehouse in SD 
Appearance: Back with a nice tan head and some good lacing 
Aroma: Not much, roasted malts 
Taste: Thin mouthfeel. Roasted malts and chocolate 
Ok, but nothing special. Left half a pint on the table when l left. Ill look for this in bottles so I can re-rate it, my experience doesnt come close to other ratings.  
ReRate 3/15/12 12oz bottle 
Aroma of roasted malts and rich chocolate. Flavors of roasted malts, molasses, grainy, chocolate and bitter. Im not changing my rating. I still didnt like this beer.

Pours dark brown medium black with good head. Foam is touch oily. Aromas are of coffee, bubblegum, toffee, cream, pop sickle. Tastes like more coffee, chocolate, mocha ya know. Also popcorn. Very creamy. Has something a little weird going on that I cant pin point. Also some dark fruit. Not bad at all.

Dark, opaque body with dark cola colored edges and a small, tan head. The aroma is pretty roasty, with a touch of coffee. Roasty flavor upfront, with an abrupt, dry finish. Tasty and drinkable. Full bodied with moderate carbonation.

12oz bottle. Good as pitch with deep ruby flecks and a filthy manilla collar. Dark chocolate ice cream over blackcurrant and blueberry aroma; burnt, juicy and smouldering with charred chocolatey malt. That same balance carries over into the flavour; carob, drinking chocolate and burnt toast dusted on a streak of pruney, blueberry fruit. Finishes burnt with a lingering high cocoa and cigar smoke aftertaste with hints of peppermint. Complex, highly swiggable stout. My. These boys know their way round a dark roasted beer alright- bring on the Rasputins...

12 oz. from Bottleworks. Totally solid stout. Nothing really stands out other than the fact that everything is very well-balanced. Just roasty enough, just sweet enough, hints of chocolate and coffee... Everything works in great balance without bashing you over the head with its stout-ness.

pours black with a slight orange hue and little head & low carbonation. Roasty toasty notes dominate this brew, kinda like burn toast a little bit. Some mocha and chocolate notes are there as well. on the palate it is full bodied, coffee bitterness and roasted burnt notes as well. Solid stout but the finish is somewhat light.

Pours almost black, with the slightest line of brown visible at the edges where the beer is thinnest.  Nose smells lightly of dark chocolate with malty notes.  Flavor is similar, with the chocolate coming to the fore and a fading bitterness at the end.  Flavors are nice, but perhaps a tad thin.  Overall, a good dry stout.

Black with a tan head. Medium body, a little light for a stout imo. Dark roasted malts is the first thing I identify when I take a whiff of this. As for taste, well the first thing that hit me was the aggressive carbonated nature of this beer, after that subsided roasted malts, chocolate and a dry toffee finish rounded the beer out. A good beer.

Appearance:  black as sin with a short, creamy khaki head.  Aroma:  toasted grains, chocolate, some old leather in there too.  Taste:  freeze-dried coffee, chocolate, earth, and a hint of mellow hops.  Finish:  smooth, dry and lightly bitter; creamy and yet good carbonation to scrape the palate clean. Notes:  A fine example of the style.  A worthwhile stout.
On tap at Bar on Buena. Pours dark and smooth with a thick tan head. Malty coffee aroma. Smooth, almost nitrous, taste of malty coffee. Not terrible but didnt love.
Tasted on nitro at Tonys Darts Away in Burbank.  Really smooth and creamy, but also very delicious.  Dark as night with a Guinness-like head on top.  Smooth, and very drinkable.

Bottle. Opaque dark brown, creamy golden brown head. Chocolate and roast aroma, light blueberries. Medium body, velvetty mouthfeel, with fine prickly carbonation. Good mellow roastyness, a few honyed almonds, smooth exit

bottle pours black with a medium light brown head.  Aroma is roasty with coal and worn leather notes.  Mouth is full bodied but there is a good bit of carbonation cleaning the palate in the finish.  This is big and black through and through.  Roasted malt, bitter cocoa, burnt sugar or caramel, minimal sweetness, but I like it.  Noticeable grassy hops in the finish.  Overall, a very well done stout.
Sampled at the brewpub on 8/5/10. Brown pour with a thick tan head. Aroma of metal, roast and some chocolate. Creamy chocolate flavor with a roasty finish thats a bit thin.
Bottle (in NZ). Stout as it should be. Black as the nights sky. Full of roasted malt, giving off coffee and just a little bit of toffee. And all on a big full dry palate. Yum.

Bottle from Kenny Road Market, poured into english pint glass. Black pour with a thin dark head. The aroma is heavy on burnt coffee with a little hoppiness. The flavor is similar, but more earthy and smokey. Simple, but good.

From a bottle.  Pours like coffee, with a very dark brown color and nice cola khaki head.  Aroma is roasted coffee that is slightly bitter.  Flavor is sweet with large coffee flavor, some oat-like dryness, and slightly bitter hoppy finish.  Pretty simple and enjoyable.

330 ml bottle from Premier Wine & Spirits (Halifax).  Pours an opaque ultra, ultra dark cola brown with quickly disappearing beige head.  Roasty aroma with coffee, some floral hops and some alcohol.  Huge coffee flavour with some dark chocolate, light hoppy bitterness.  Not particularly dry.  Moderately creamy mouthfeel.  Nice.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2010 Tap at Paradiso Dupont. Pours a clear cola red that looks almost jet black in the glass with a giant, dense, nitro creamy head that settles down in a reverse cascade. Decent nitro lace. Sweet, red delicious apples in the nose along with fresh flowers and melons, followed by slight roast and sweet barbecue. Taste is light to medium bodied, silky palate, with a body full of rye toast, pumpernickel, tobacco, and slight ash. Im a sucker for these session nitro stouts and really enjoyed this one.

pours black with a nice tan head and great lacing for a stout.  aroma is bread, caramel and a hint of smoke.  Texture is creamy with light but lovely carbonation.  taste is chocolate, hops, and general oakyness.  dry finish.  Very Nice.
Nice firm chocolatey flavor. Pours a dark black color with a small brown head. Smooth and delicious.

Bottle. Color is black with ruby undertones shone through light.  Characteristic notes are roasted barley, touch of smoked meat, and bitter chocolate.  Almost savory in its lack of sweetness.  A dark and roasted stout, simple yet perfect for charred meats or maybe a smoky chili.

Has a dark black pour with a soft off white foam head that sits thin and light across the glass. The aroma gives off scents of roasted malts, coffee, and barley. The body is light and the carbonation is soft and easy on the tongue.

awesome stout.  Not at all dry, but nicely rounded, malty with a rich dark roast complexity, great mouthfeel and a lingering aftertaste that just makes you want another one.  Bought this as a single and liked it so much I went back and bought a 6-pack the next day, and its been in my regular rotation ever since

Draught, Burger Bar, SF. Huge roast malt flavour, verging on the burnt. Assume this was a nitro pour, due to a thick, creamy head and surging body, which took a lot of settling.  Wholesome, rich and fulfilling.

Pours very dark with a full creamy head.  The head didnt last long, but it left some very nice lacing behind.  Smells of bitter roasted coffee, a bit of chocoalte and just a touch of smokiness in there as well.  Im getting a nice amount of smoke, fantastic coffee, smooth chocolate, and maybe a touch of soy.  Overall, pretty enjoyable.
Pours up thick with a great head like Guiness. Not much aroma. Very chocolatey. Good. I think I just dont like Imperial Stouts.
Very, very BLACK!  Aroma was chocolatey and malty... flavor was weaker than some stouts but still not bad.

Nitro draft pour at Toronado in San Francisco. Dark black, quarter-inch head. Dark chocolate aroma, brewers licorice, fine leather. Super, super smooth, light in body. Sweet with chocolate. A wonderful stout. Enjoyable.

This is a dry Irish stout; not an imperial stout. I read so many reviews that say that they want MORE from this beer. But this is not one of those overpowering stouts.

A very solid offering from a very fine brewery. The beer pours a very dark ruby amber tone that looks black almost opaque with a mahogany colored billowing two finger width head.

The aroma is where this beer shines. The dark fragrant roasts and strong coffee aroma just powerful.

The taste is not shabby either with very refined with hints of espresso and notes of sour cream.  The dark roasted barley fills this beer with slight burnt finish that is pleasant when matched with the other flavors going on. The malts are prevalent, but the hops are not lost in the final judgment.

Medium body and an acidic mouthfeel.

A fine example of the style.

Tasting portion at a North Coast beer tasting event at a local grocery store. Poured into a champagne flute glass. The beer rep from North Coast indicated that the philosophy of the brewer was to make beers that closely resemble the style guidelines for that type of style (i.e., to make the perfect beer for that style), and that Old 38 was a fine example of that philosophy for the dry Irish stout. Dark & black in color, with a nice foamy head. Deep aromas of roasted malts and coffee. I pick up that sweet Irish whiskey like flavor that you typically find in Irish stouts, along with some coffee flavors. The beer finishes with burnt toast sensation and somewhat dry. A little light bodied for a stout, but thats likely typical for this style. Creamy and low levels of carbonation. Well balanced, smooth and light bodied stout. Not a sipping beer, you can have a couple of these easily. Id much prefer this beer than some of the Irish counterparts like Guinness or Beamish.

A: The pour is dark brown in color with a pretty solid tan head.

S: The nose is primarily of dark chocolate and coffee with a pretty solid roasted malt aroma in the background. A little bit more sniffing gives off some dark fruit aromas.

T: The dark chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts all work quite well together in terms of the flavors. The fruits are a bit harder to pick out than they were in the nose, but still there, as is a bit of char.

M: The body is medium with a smooth, mildly creamy feel on the tongue.

D: A very nice, sessionable stout. I was pleasantly surprised by how flavorful it is.
Black pour in glass. Tastes almost like cold coffee. Initially very dry with a smoother finish. Rated 2/3/03
tasted on nitro tap.  nice big creamy head really added to this porter.  medium coffee notes, medium roasty notes.  solid all around porter that doesnt wow but is quite tasty.
Tap at Pony Bar. All the standard characteristics of a dry stout, but all above average. Like a Guinness but with sweeter and with more depth of character. Definitely a sessioner.

12 ounce bottle.  Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours dark brown with about an inch tan head.  The head sticks around for a while, and theres a good amount of lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, and some dark fruit.  The taste is the same as the aroma, but its sweeter than I expected.  Mouthfeel/body is on the light side of medium, its a bit creamy and coating with good carbonation.  Drinkability is good, its smooth, easy, and enjoyable to drink.  I think this is a good overall brew.  Id buy this again in the future.

An ok stout without much body and somewhat lacking in the taste department. This beer is dark but rather transparent for a stout. The smell is mostly roasted malt, chocolatey malt. There is even an interesting hop character in the background. The taste is similar but the feel is so light that it kind of washes out the beers potential. I guess its fairly drinkable, but it wouldnt be my choice for a stout. Its not bad, and if you like light stouts, its probably a good choice. Its just not my thing.
A nice aroma of roast and dark chocolate. Medium to full mouthfeel with a dark chocolate bitterness supporting the roasted malt. Long roasty finish. Yummy!
12 ounce bottle -A dark brown pour -small tan head -taste of fruit coffee, chocolate, thin feel -smooth coff-choc finish

The Old #38 is a brew I have been enjoying for almost a decade, but have just gotten around to rating it now.  The old number is a subtle stout that will nail  you with a chocolate malt surprise.  This is a stout you can count on arriving on time and bringing you a satisfying experience.  All aboard my bitches!

Near black colored with medium sized beige head. Roasted vanilla aroma with some chocolate and licorice, excellent aroma. Medium bodied. Flavor is more dry with licorice and roastiness dominating, some wooden vanilla note also comes up. Aftertaste dries with licorice still, nicely balanced stout.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown, looks black, with a small foamy latte-colored head.  Aromas of grass, honey, light raspberry, and sweet barley, with cocoa and coffee in the background.  Flavor is semi-sweet chocolate, coffee, sweet fruit, and soft nutty notes.  Creamy and sweet with low carbonation.  Pretty good.

Purchased at World Market, Winston-Salem, NC

Thick and dark on pour; good, not great, stout.

North Coast Brewing Company--Old No. 38 Stout.  12 oz. Bottle.

1997 Release.5.40% ABV.

1998 Release.  6.00% ABV.  (3.75 / 5.0)  Dark black color. Dry Stout style.  Nice head followed by medium body and very dry finish.  Flavorful light cherry chocolate flavors develop.  Very dry.  Sampled 2/28/1999.

1999 22 oz. Bottle Release.  7.00% ABV.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Dark Color.  Rich chocolate front and big rich body.  Brew thins after initial taste but remains big and rich.  Sampled 6/20/1999.

2005 Release.  5.60% ABV--46 IBUs.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Mild lace tan head.  Clear thin brown red color.  Cappuccino mild floral hop front.  Creamy dry sweet toasted toffee biscuit mild cocoa fruit body.  Balanced mild citrus hop spice end.  Brown Porter flavor.  Sampled 3/14/2005.

2009 New Bottle Neck Label.  5.60% ABV--46 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Rich lacy light espresso head.  No sediment.  Clear dark black color with ruby edges.  Soft chocolate hop spice mild coffee front.  Smooth velvet creamy silky roasted mellow chocolate fruit bready mild sweet malty Stout body.  Balanced hop spice lingering malt end.  Sampled 8/26/2009.  3 @ $1.69 Each.
From a 12 oz bottle, chocolate, coffee, sticky, full body, light sweetness.Its pretty average but on the bar of stouts
This poured a black color with a beige head. Aroma was light roasted malts and some nuttiness character. Flavor was fairly dry, dark roasted with minimal sweetness

(Bottle, Monks Café Wallingatan, Stockholm) Dark brown colour, almost black, with frothy pale brown head. Malty, roasted nose with notes of chocolate, cocoa and gentle milky coffee hints. Malty, roasted taste with chocolate, coffee and a slightly roasted, gentle bitterness in a dry finish. Medium body, smooth and well rounded. Once upon a time this was one of the beers that got me in to the American craft beer scene. Its still a tasty and well balanced beer, but it seems my frames of reference has moved on a bit.

dark pour with opaque ruby shining through. heavy pour produces a small tan head that receeds quickly with no hints of lacing. aroma is pretty roasty, hazelnut, coffee definitely shine through. palate is fairly thin, but i like the level of carbonation...just right. this is a good stout.
UPDATED: FEB 28, 2010 12 ounce bottle pours dark with a nice tan head.  Thats the best part of it, though.  Flavor is thin and mildly bitter, lacking complexity.  Not so hot.

Pours a thin black. Heavy aroma of chocolate, coffee with some hops on top. Taste is a thin coffee and roasted malt. Works into a bitterness and a hint of a mettalic note. A little thin and not very exciting for me. Aroma was nice but flavor is lacking.

12 oz bottle. Pitch black with a tan sticky head. Really roasty aroma with a bit of chocolate.Bittersweet chocolate flavor with a touch of roasty and hop bitterness. Medium to full body with mellow carbonation and a long dry roasty finish. Good flavorful stout with great drinkability.
Pours a lacing, tan head with a dark brown body.  Aromas of roasted malt and molasses.  Flavor has notes of roasted malt, toast, molasses.  Finish is a little thin, sweet, roasted.
Bottle. Nice dark pour with a wispy white head. Great aroma of dark chocolate. Taste is big roasty chocolate, which lingers and finishes dry. Very tasty.

Bottle. Black with a very thin layer of light brown head. Aroma is sweet and malty with a hint of chocolate rum. Flavor begins bittersweet and a little chocolaty followed by some subtle malt sweetness, coffee and barley malts. It finishes very dry with some burnt smokiness. Smooth and drinkable.

12oz bottle at the Little Rock Saucer.  Deep, dark brown pour with a bit of head that recedes to nothing.  Aroma of semi-sweet chocolate, hints of coffee, molasses and a little toffee.  Flavor is malty, chocolate, mild licorice, hint of day old coffee and light sweetness.  Mild hop, chocolate, coffee finish that is dry and clean.  Medium body with fine carbonation.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Gillys, 2/1/10 


Aroma: Roasted/burnt malts, chocolate, some nuts, coffee, and caramel

Appearance: Pour a very dark brown color with a creamy, thin brown head

Flavor: Flavor is somewhat sweet, malty, with a pretty dry and bitter finish

Palate: This beer has average carbonation and a nice medium body

Overall Impression: 
This is a pretty solid stout.  I enjoyed this one.  A good flavor, a nice beer, it is quite solid.
12oz. bottle, pours a jet black with a tan head. Aroma and flavour are roasted malt. Nice dry stout.

pours dark brown, thick mahogany/mocha head.
aroma, piney hops, good spicy nose with hints of chocolate.
flavor, hoppy, barley palate giving it a celery like touch, caramel, light peppery mouthfeel, sweet chocolate with a nice spicy finish. 
Light bitter chocolate finish, some coffee, toffee like caramel finish. Never thought this was only clocking at 5.6%.
Not bad, nice roasty taste. Nice deep flavor, pretty black look with creamy head.
Bottle at Pauls tasting (new decade). Dark pour with little to no head. Roasted, caramel, toffee malts. Some coffee notes. Decent low gravity stout.
Tap st blind tiger. Poured a creamy black. Big big coffee nose. Lively carbonated. Some light coffee notes and light roasted malts emphasis on light and drinkable. Nice dry finish.

Bottle.  Poured dark brown with a large egg shell head leaving sheets of lace on the glass.  Nose is roasted malt with some chocolate and notes of fig and raisin.  Thin body with a somewhat watery mouth feel.  Flavor is sweet with big notes of roasted malt and secondary notes of chocolate and slight coffee.  Finishes somewhat dry and slightly bitter.  Standard stout certainly no Old Rasputin.
very easy drinking stout and no flaws that I can pick. But it is kinda thin and watery, too carbonated. good flavor and aroma but weak and too faint.

Aroma of coffee chocolate brown sugar excellent. 
Pours a deep brown, tan head.  
Flavor is chocolate, brown sugar, roasted coffee, vanilla. 
Finish is bitter from the  roastiness.  
Medium thick mouthfeel. Very good.

shared by yours truly at pauls tasting. Pours really dark. Strong arouma of prunes and chocolate notes. Nice flavor profile of roasted malts and smokey chocolates. Finishes with some coffee-like bitterness. Nice and tasty, if a little unexperimental.

Pours a deep, opaque sable with a thick, fine-bubbled, fairly persistent beige head. Aroma is strong, smoky and oily with undertones of unsweetened chocolate and molasses and just a whiff of coffee. Smoky flavor has a woody undertone as well as firm tones of molasses and mocha. Texture is smooth and fairly tingly, leaving a satisfying and slightly gritty finish.
Bottle at Pauls tasting.  Pours a deep black with a thin white head.  Roast and chocolate, with a hint of plums.   Medium bodied, plums and cookies.  Long roasty finish.  Tasty.

From an old rating note:  12oz bottle.  dark brown pour with big creamy tan head.  aroma of chocolate, malt and caramel.  light, dry and chalky palate.  tastes of coffee and bitter chocolate. off metallic vibe in the finish also.

12 oz. bottle. Not much of a head on this thing at all. The head was slightly off-white, but it faded away so damn fast. Black body. Sweet chocolate and a slight roast. A lot more pungent than other dry stouts that I have tried. Sweet chocolate malts are coming through foremost. Rather thin and a bit smokey. This beer has a nice roast and subtle sweet chocolate flavor. Smoke and roast are coming through more as the beer warms. Not a bad palate i.e. not as thin as other dry stouts. Pretty good.
very easy drinking stout and no flaws that I can pick. But it is kinda thin and watery, too carbonated. good flavor and aroma but weak and too faint.
Mild aroma with a black colored appearance. Lighter taste and bitterness for a stout.
very light and fluffy- mouthfeel of a nitro beer. Smooth and really drying to the mouth. Little bit of clove spiciness. Really fun to drink, I oculd down a whole session of these.

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  Pours a very dark brown, near black, with a small brown head that fades quickly and leaves a thin tan film on the beer and rim on the edge.  Aroma of dark fruits (prunes, fig, raisins, plum), chocolate, barley malts, and coffee.  The flavor didnt do as much for me, was just too muted.  Notes of dried and dark fruits- same ones listed above- that provide some sweetness and a little tart note, along with malts, chocolate, nuts, and yeast.  Medium bodied, with a dry, light palate.  With more body, the palate would be really nice because of the complexity of the flavors.  Quick, dry, roasty finish, with dried fruits.  After a few seconds, leaves the palate really dry.  Interesting beer, worth a try for anyone who likes dry stouts.

Dark dark amber liquid, light head.
 Smooth, lightly bubbly on the palate. After swallowing, a quick rush of something runs up into the nasal cavity, like a wasabi rush.
 Taste... Complex for a dry stout, simpler than some imperials.
 Soy sauce, raisin, caramel, dark chocolate, hint of banana-like tones, not very heavy on alcohol flavor. Aftertaste of hops, slightly citrus to pine-like..
  Ill buy this one again.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass

The color is a dark black with a deep maroon color when held to the light. Some slight head but no lacing.

The smell is light but has a malty flavor that has a pin of brown sugar and a little chocolate flavor as well.

The taste is some dark chocolate and a little roasted malt. Is a nice even flavor but not too strong.

It seems to be missing a little something but that may be me getting used to Imperial Stouts, otherwise this beer is a nice beer experience. It has a nice even medium body and feels great going down. It dies have a slight aftertaste but only the briefest.

12oz bottle.  Pours a dark deep brown with a small, short lived, dense, tan head.   The aroma is of sweet caramel malt, cocoa, and some roastiness.  Taste is lead by roasted malts, then chocolate and coffee and a long lingering hopiness with some herbal spice.  Body is thin with medium carbonation.

Thoroughly enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours a nearly jet black color, with a small and relatively quickly disappearing light tan head.  Low to moderate carbonation, which is positioned just about right between an English pub ale and an APA.  Notes of caramel, bready malt, prunes, and cherries dipped in chocolate come through in the aroma.  Very inviting, and perhaps evidence of not only the recipe, but also a careful hand with selecting a proper English yeast strain.  There are also some almost acidic and sour characteristics, but they are somewhat restrained by the darker more roasty notes.  The palate is surprisingly light across the mouth, but certainly not insipid.  A complex interplay of the bready/biscuity characteristics of Maris Otter base malt, paired with some caramel, a dose of chocolate, and then the aforementioned dark fruity/slightly sour character.  The finish is semi-sweet a bit roasty, leaving the yeasts character to dance on the palate for a few moments.  Overall, extremely interesting, unique, and well-crafted.

Boy am I glad I got around to trying this one! I should have figured stout brewed by North Coast=good. Anyway, this beer pours very thick and black for the style, with a light brown head. The aroma is very fetching with notes of chocolate, coffee, and molasses. The flavor is very dry and smooth with licorice and coffee on the palate. There is some hints of smoke in the finish. Simple, yes, but very pure and very good.

From a 12 oz bottle into a snifter.  Pours with about an inch of thick head which dissipates over time.  Aroma is of licorice, coffee and cough syrup.  Taste is of pretty much the same with a little tingle from the alcohol and carbonation as well as some soy sauce and skunk thrown in.  Speaking of which, its pretty heavily carbonated, especially for a stout.  Overall, not a bad stout but there are better ones out there.  I really didnt like the soy, licorice and cough syrup taste, pretty much turned me off.

Pours black with light brown head. Aroma of slight dark chocolate, slight smoke, roasty malt, slight coffee, with slight hop spice to finish. Very well balanced in the amount of roast and hops. Thick body and no bitterness in the aftertaste. The balance is especially noticeable in this one. Does not taste like I just ate a campfire like some stouts can.

2009 Bottle - Pours a thin dk brown with a small tan head...aroma is coffee and grain, light roasted malt...flavour is similar, watery coffee and cocoa, minerally finish, thin with seltzer like carbonation...meh...

Pure black color with a thick dark tan head.  Aroma consists of malts, barley, a little caramel, and coffee.  Taste is of malts, some chocolate, and roasted barley.  Has a pleasant chocolaty and roasted barley aftertaste.

Bottle - pours a dark brown, almost black with a tan head that thins fairly quickly.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and coffee.  Nice smooth chocolately taste with a roasted coffee finish.  Very nice brew - will definitely drink more of this as the winter progresses.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2010 Dark and roasted, this one was a slight touch on the sweet side. Nice bitterness to it, powerful bitter but the dark flavors are there too. Soy sauce and tangy dark, not so much roasted toasted dark, although it is both its much more baltic style dark. Definitely getting the sweetness now. Good beer, and easy enough to find.

dark brown color, purplish highlights, fluffy tan head, cathedral lace.  airy roasty malt nose, very mild.  nice roasty malt, bread, hops and chocolate in the flavor.  medium bodied, bitter finish.  a pretty good stout with well balanced chocolate  sweetness and hoppy bitterness.  quite fun.  single bottle from cardinal liquors in frankfort.

12oz bottle pours a deep reddish-brown with a thin tan head.

Aroma has some sweet condensed milk and milk chocolate, along with a nice roasted malt undertone.

Flavors are similar, with that creamy smooth milk quality pulling everything together.  Coffee with a strong pinch of salt come through in the middle, followed by bitter dryness at the finish.

This is a nice beer, simple and light in ABV.  Smooth and balanced, not too shabby at all!

bottle, labelled best before jul 2006 probably by the danish importer. tasted oct 2009, to me, seems to be still fresh and totally unspoiled by age. Impressive!.

dark brown, smooth small light brown head, nice lacing.
chocolate, brown sugar most prominent in aroma. good quality chocolate aroma,mild aroma, very faint hoppy note to it.
flavor is mild, roasted grains, licorice, expensive dark chocolate, faint flowery or fruity or perhaps honey note, a mild sweetness vs roast battle. ends more roasted.

pours very deep brown - almost black with a medium creamy tan head.  aroma is slightly milky with dark fruits and a hint of coffee.  flavor has roasty caramel and black malt, coffee, and bold citrusy hops without being overly bitter.  mouthfeel is rich, creamy and very bubbly with a lingering roasty finish that thins out a bit in the end.

Bought as a 6-pack based on "best rating" at BevMo.  Tight flavors up front, almost sweet for a stout, with a chocolate / coffee base that makes it very easy to drink.  Black throughout, with a hint of red on the edges.  Lingering smooth aftertaste.  Great beer to celebrate the coming of Fall and cooler weather.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2009 For a Dry Stout, this brew is exceptional. A faint chocolate covered raisins smell lifts from an everlasting head and delta mud color body. The flavor is better than usual for a dry stout, and makes you appreciate the substantial yet rather light head of Old No. 38 Stout.
On tap at the brewpub.  Black in color with a decent tan colored head.  The smell is coffee, roasty, malts, and chocolate.  The taste is slight bitter, malts, roasty, and coffee. Ok.
Damn good for an American Stout.  Thickish body, toasty, burnt chocolate, sweet malts, and nice hop presence on the finish.  Dont see often, but grab when I do,

12-oz bottle (Marcellos, Lafayette, LA) - Aroma: chocolate, toasted to roasted; Flavor: sweet, salty, bitter, toasted to roasted, and coffee (malt), finishes dry; Appearance: black color, tan head; Mouthfeel: smooth, creamy, full bodied, moderate carbonation; Overall: a nice creamy, chocolate and roasted, bitter beer.

Heavy alcohol right off the top like an Imperial. Hazelnut and chocolate, a big second wind.

Dark dark reddish brown. Nice cloudy light brown head. Film sticks around.

The flavor has some earthy hay, alcohol, chocolate, hazelnut and a touch of caramel. Malted milk balls. All sweet malts, roasted and very good. Hints of buttery scotch ale flavor with warmth. 

Feels oily and rough. Really sticks around on the tongue. A solid stout, like a nutty, chocolatey porter.

Brewed in the USA... Pours deep dark brown color with a large foamy tan head that dissipates in time. Aroma of chocolate, dark malts, brown sugar and caramel. Taste of chocolate, mild coffee, malts and nuts. Mouthfeel is medium in body with a slight dry finish. Not bad !!!  Well balanced and easy to drink.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2010 Deep brown with a big tan head.  Aroma is of toasty grain and a bit of coffee.  Taste has a bit of chocolate and more roasted grain and coffee, with a bit of a sour acidic flavor in the back.  Not bad, but I feel like somethings a bit off about it.  Could have been my bottle.

Pours a nice dark brown color with a brown head. Aroma is caramel, chocolate, toffee, coffee, roast, and slightly floral. Flavor is chocolate, caramel, roast, plum, some coffee, and a bitter spicy finish.

Dark brown beer with a thin tan head.  Aroma is roasted flavored coffee, chocolate and grains.  Flavor is the much the same with a dry twist and the roasted aspects taking less of a roll.  Slight hint of something that reminds me of vinegar.  Hop bite shows in slight bitterness lining the flavor.  Nice lacing.  Over all, not a bad beer but could use some tuning in my opinion.

Pours a deep black with a thick tan head.  Taste of roasted malts, chocolate and a little coffe.  Soliid stout from North Coast.  

12 oz. bottle
Pours brown with an off white head.  Smells of roasted malt.  Tastes roasty and sweet with some dry chocolatey hints on the finish.

12oz bottle from Orland Park Binnys single rack. Pours dark brown with nice thick and fluffy tan head. Aroma is mostly roasted malt with some chocolate, caramel and light coffee. Flavor is again mostly roasted malt with chocolate, coffee, and some caramel sweetness. Mouthfeel is a little thin but works good for this style. Really sessionable stout in my opinion. Would be a good beer to transition people from Guinness into some heavier stouts. Pretty good stuff and a nice surprise.
Sweet and roasty smell with a flavor to match that finishes with bitter coffee notes and a hint of sour in the front.

Bottle...  Poured deep, dark brown with a light brown head.  Metallic and acidic coffee, with roasted malts on the nose.  Well carbonated and thick, dry palate.  Toasted malts and coffee flavors.  Dark chocolate and a smoked acidic character.  A little hoppy as well and a tangy, bitter-sweet molasses finish.

Has a opaque dark color with a firm dark cream head that lingers for the whole drink. Aroma was a mix of roasted malts and some cocoa. Taste had the cocoa and malts, but also a coffee flavor to it. Beer had a good creamy thickness to it, and the firm head helped that. Overall a decent stout, right on par with Guinness.

Pours dark brown with a small tan head.  Nose is roast, coffee, earth, sweetness, licorice, and some light chocolate/ cocoa.  Flavor is similar with lingering coffee, roast, and licorice.  Interesting stout.

Not the darkest in color for the variaty, almost invisible tan head, coffee is heavy on the nose. Tastes of smoked chocolate and coffee with notes of nuts and a rich, full, even creamy body. A bitter finish. Pleasant.

On tap at North Coast brewpub on 6/28/09. Pours very dark burgundy with nice head.  Dominant coffee aroma, with touch of pine and earthen chocolate.  Little sweetness, then a long dry coffee flavor dominates.  Solid example of the style.

Bottled.  Poured deep brown with a creamy, well-retained cap of dark tan head.  The aroma picked up well-roasted coffee and dark chocolate character with some sweeter chocolate and earthy accents.. soft overall and supple.  The flavor was centered around dry-roasted coffee, with bakers chocolate giving more of the bitterness on the edges.. vanilla and a touch of earth toward the back.. toasty coffee with some sweetness on the finish.  Medium-bodied and dry on the palate with a fine roast to it.. balance was there, and this went down quickly.  No-frills, but it didnt need em.

Bottle. Deep black-red color. Coffee and chocolate aroma. Initial dry mouth feel leads to a smooth, smoky,coffee malt finish. Hops are more present than in your typical Stout. Lots of roasted malt in the finish. A nice Stout.

I do enjoy this beer, although the numbers calculate lower than I would like to suggest.  This stout I could drink for days...unlike the Old Rasputin, which is my favorite.  Its a quality stout with balance and I like to use it as an introductory stout to folks that dont get on well with Guiness.

Been awhile since Ive seen a North Coast brew... and Im glad to have this one in my hand albeit horribly overpriced. 
Poured out a mid sized brown head that is on the foamy side. Ok retention with slippery lacing. Dark dark brown brew. The aroma is of roasted malts, chocolate, orange and wet coffee grounds; none of which are strong. This has a nice soft demeanor. The flavour is very nice and mild with a toffee / chocolate / roast coming out first, touch of hops, fruit and astringency in the middle and finishes with chocolate and coffee. Mouth feel is excellent as this beer put my mouth through a rollercoaster of experiences: smooth, average carbonation, tart, dryness and a coffee bitterness that has some pretty decent legs without ruining the next sipping. As much as I like this I dont find myself drawn to get more. Still, its a very enjoyable beer.

Never judge a book by its cover. Ive had this bottle sitting in my fridge for close to 2 years because nobody was ever eager to try it. Pours a pitch black body. Aroma is light notes of malt and coffee. The taste is smooth, flavor of coffee and some roasted notes.

bottle.  nice solid intriguing dry stout.... Old No 38 really feels like a toned down version of Old Rasputin... nice licorice and sweet malt presence.  feels stronger than 5.6%.  pours a mild black with an average tan head.  wonderful licorice, coffee and sweet aromas.  light to medium body.  really nice flavors throughout... this offers more than your typical dry stout... nice one.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a thick lasting tan head, with extensive lacing, over a dark blackish brown (SRM 25) clear body....nose redolent of the usual suspects, coffee, chocolate, molasses, soy.....taste initially is slightly sweet then in come the heavy roasted tastes of coffee, cocoa, finishing with a nice hop bitterness....mouth feel is rich and chewy, but not as smooth as an oatmeal, carbonation medium. A thoroughly enjoyable American Stout.

"Black body with a small brown cap, lacing is very slippery. Aroma is very mild and slightly sour, coffee, cinnamon ( very hard to detect) along with a made up word Ill call roastedness. I guess the aroma is not bad its just mild and average. Chalky coffee taste, chocolate comes through and the brew finishes dry and smoky. Ok beer very drinkable its just average at best and not worth the insane price I paid for it up here in Canada (25$ for a sixer)"
Tap. Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is quite malty with an underlying chocolate aroma. Flavor is again malty with nice underlying flavors.

Pours a dark mahogany color with traces of crimson shining through. A foamy blanket of mocha colored foam shows decent retention, leaving minimal, skinny rings and flares of lacing behind. The aroma shows sweet burnt caramel and scorched sugars, dark fig and various other dark fruits adding further earthy sweetness. Hints of earthy, smoky molasses adds excessive sweetness. Flavors focus on big, sweet, dark cocoa with vanilla and caramel. Mild earthen notes fail to balance out the sugary flavors. Medium bodied and sugary, the palate resembles a sweet stout more than a dry. Eh, not impressed.

Bottle.  Pours black with a thick light tan head.  Flavor of super sweet malt, roasted malt, and some raisins.  Flavor of roasted, sweet malt with some vegetal notes.  Not very interesting.  Sweet and meh.
6/4/5/3/12 (3.0/5)

Poured black with no lacing and overly carbonated.
Tastes of way too much black bitter malt and overly roasty.
bleh
From bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Sweet aroma, fruity with some raspberries maybe. Rich flavour of liquorice berries and roasted malt. Bitter texture in the finish. Tasty stout.

pours thin black with a nice sized beige head. aroma of coffee, sweet roasted malts, chocolate. drinks with soft bittersweet coffee, dark chocolate, burnt malt, and sweetness. finish is mildly bitter with coffee lingering. not a bad session stout.

Pours dark brown-black with a thin off-white head with poor retention. Aroma of sweet chocolate milk - the kind that came in tetra-packs saying "dutch-style". Taste is sweet, chocolate malt and a bit of milkiness, but lacking in roastiness and a bit disappointing. Low in carbonation, thin body. Meh.

Pours black with a small off-white head. Kind of smells like paint. Taste is dominated by bitter roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, and hoppy bitterness. Maybe a touch of vanilla in the finish? Smooth palate. Very drinkable and enjoyable. Good beer. Long finsh.
12oz bottle. This is an OK stout but I did not feel that it had any qualities that make it stand out. It did have a nice dark color and creamy head.

Black pour, thin off-white head with some retention and lacing. Somewhat lactic nose with notes of bitter chocolate and burnt coffee. Flavour has lactose and bittering hops with some roast, moderate finish retains some of the roasty character. Mouthfeel is a bit middle-of-the-road, carbo is fairly well balanced though. Quite nice.

Shared with smith4498 at Zekes Roadhouse in Miami Beach.  Pours a near black with fair brown head.  Sweet milk chocolate with a good bit of roast.  Like a milk stout actually.  I actually thought this was a sweet stout, rather than a dry stout.  About average.
Shared with Steve.  Decent stout slightly thin on the palate.  Good roasted malts and barley flavor.
Pours black with tan head. Burnt malt aroma. Roasted malt flavor with hints of coffee and chocolate and a bitter finish. Medium to full body with moderate carbonation. Decent.
On tap at The Trappist. This black ale poured with a modest tan head and a smoked malt aroma. There is a substantial roasted malt flavor that leaves a pleasant coating on your tongue.
Black body with a thick brown head. Roastd malt aroma with trace amount of coffee aroma. Taste of roasted malt, little sweetness, dryness, and a litlle bitter finish. Nice lacing on the glass.
Pours dark with a lingering tan head.  Subtle bittersweet chocolate flavor.  Easy to drink, fairly impressive stout.

12 oz bottle served at charlestons (new lenox, Il). Pours a very darl brown pour mixed with black notes, moderate tannish head that sticks around and laces a bit. Aromas are fairly blank, subtle roasted malts mixed with light molasses sweetness, light chocolate, and and underwhelming feel. Initial is lighter in body, light roasted malts, chocolate subtle coffee bitterness, and light barley and soda bread. A little light bodied, but sessionable. Not really a palate sticker, leaves a malty sweetness coupled with coffee bitterness on the aftertaste. Ok.
pours black and small brown head..chocolate,taste is nice throughout..nice stout

Pours black with thin brown head that fades quickly.  Initial aroma of prune juice, chocolate, and some booze.  Taste is initially prunes/dark fruit which turns to chocolate, coffee, roasted malty goodness.  Moderate bitterness.  A pretty good stout.

12 oz. bottle to a Czech Pils glass. The pour was a thick looking black/brown hue, with a little bit of ruby red showing through the neck. The head was a foamy, off white with some good lacing. The aroma was not overly powerful but gave off some roasted notes, along with light coffee, molasses, a touch of resin, and some green olive? The flavor lost the green olive, thank God, and added some grain, a little charred wood, and a touch of cola. The carbonation was a little fizzy and the finish was dry. Some off notes, but fairly decent stout.

Old 38 is an almost black ale with a reddish tint and a tan head that fades to a tight film.  It leaves nice lacing on the glass and stays the whole way down.  It has a roasted aroma thats sweet and a touch tart.  There are notes of coffee, licorice and brown sugar.  It is medium-full bodied and incredibly smooth.  It feels a bit fluffy in the mouth.  The finish is dry and dusty.  The flavor is very roasted, almost smokey, with notes of coffee, chocolate, and caramel.  Its a touch sweet and syrupy, but perfectly balanced.  I think this may be the stout on which I originally developed my palate.  The malt and hops just work together on a new plane of beer existence.  I could drink a bucket of this.  This is like a beer custom made for me.

Bottle. Frothy, light brown head that recedes quickly. Dark brown body. Aroma is malty with roasted malts, bitter coffee and grain with a hint of pine.The flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic and lightly bitter, but in the dry finish, the bitterness goes up a notch. Medium body. Watery texture. Lively carbonation. Weak aroma. The most noticable flavor is the bitterness  not chocolate or coffee or roasted malt. Disappointing.

Six pack picked up at BevMo in San Fran. Dark brown pour with a mid sized and long lasting tan head. Aroma of dried fruit with some nutty and peaty hints to it. Watery coffee and chocolate taste, mouth is way too thin on this one, disappointing from the brewer who gave us the fantastic Old Rasputin.

1/14/09 From the bottle. Aroma is peaty, smoky, with light dark fruit. Appearance is dark brown with a well maintained cream colored head. Flavor is sweet, very smooth, and slightly watery, but not objectionable. Mouthfeel is medium-full bodied with a low grainy carb texture. Overall, big and cool.
Pours dark brown with a nice lacing beige head.  Bet it would look and be great out of a nitro tap.  Dry chocolate and coffee malt flavor.  Hoppy bitterness.  Good dry stout.

To friends I call this Old Rasputin Light, it is far more independent than that, but I love the beer so I suppose I find myself inflating it in reputation to "sell" it. Pours with a deep black color, that shows some ruby tint when held up to direct light. Plenty of lace and good head retention. The aroma is decidedly fruity and nutty. The flavor is slightly more complex with some Molasses and some strong coffee along with nice nutty compliments. Just a very nice stout.

Poured a dark brown with a small light brown head. Roasted coffee aroma.  
Flavor was a mixture of chocolate and roasted coffee.
Roasted malts with mild coffee.  Extremely watery for a stout.  Soft carbonation and very week flavor.

Bottle.  Creamy tan head.  Strong sweet malt aroma, a little roasty.  Initally sweet, hint of roastiness, then very chocolatey, some berry like flavors.  Would almost call it a porter.  Overall a reasonable and drinkable stout/porter.

Tasty stout, real nice and straightforward. Jet black pour with a lasting 3/4" thick khaki colored head and heavy lacing, this looks marvelous. Roasted malty aroma with hints of coffee and sweet milk chocolate. Malty body and very easy to put down. Lively with a moderately bitter aftertaste. Toasted malt with nut and chocolate flavors. A touch of molasses and black licorice. Nicely played sirs.

black. little head to speak of. smells of a bit of coffee. flavors are kind of everywhere, not to well balanced to my pallet. Dry obviously, but also roasted malts, and bitter finish, i like all the flavors individually, but together, they just arent working properly in this one....not a drain pour, just not something i will be having again....
Very very black.  Very very chocolatey.  Fairly decent background of hops.  Medium body, decent finish.  Drinkable.

Pours a bottle-colored brown and, of course, appears black in the glass. Has a good deal of head for a stout. Smells slightly astringent. Burnt coffee and bakers cocoa, plus some brown sugar and cheddar are in the nose. Tastes sweet, almost like a cola, with a toasted bread character and a coffee finish. A funky ham-stock flavor is also present. Too sweet for my taste; more resembling a porter than a stout. Not a good beer.
12/25/2008 - Pours extremely dark brown, almost black. Aroma of toffee, molasses and anise.  Initial taste of burnt coffe and dirt.  Finish is dry and slightly bitter.

(bottle): Pours an almost pitch black colored body, with a humongous foamy tan head. Very vigorous and very lasting. Very chocolaty aroma, a little musty, some.roasted coffee. A lot going on in the nose. Creamy smelling aroma too. Creamy, ashy, bitter chocolate taste. Light fizziness. Not as sweet a taste as in the aroma.. Nice taste, not too heavy or alcoholy.
Pours black into a shaker. Head quickly recedes leaving no lacing.  Chocolate and sour pit fruit aromas. Tingly with upfront espresso and a lasting bitter chocolate finish.
From a bottle poured black with a small head.  Nice flavor of toasted malt.  A little watery but a good lasting finish.
Bottle on new years eve 2005. Pours a black body with a tan head.  Sweet caramel with a light roasty coffee and some minerals.  Light roasted malt.  Thin body pretty dam good.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown, with a medium beige head.  The flavor is salty and bitter, with a lot of roasted malt and the nose is of chocolate and some American hops.  The finish is salty and bitter, with a West Coast twang.

Good aroma of Pine , malt and some breadiness. dark brown with finger high tan head. the smell however doesnt seem to transfer well into the flavor. Notes of coffee and malt with a faintness of hops somewhere. Kind of airy mouthfeel....good dry finish.Milk chocolate shows through a little better as it warms. Id expect more from North Coast.

Deep dark brown almost black pour with creamy tan head and lace. Huge aroma of milk chocolate. Flavor not as much choco as the nose but pretty solid. Hint of coffee as well very dry finish. Pretty damn solid stout.

Bottle. Aged about 1 year. Pours a glossy jet black with about a half inch light tan head. Nose of roasted barley. Good dark malt flavors. Cheap coffee and roasted barley too. Dry, syrupy, over fizzy  mouth. Decent dry stout.

12 oz bottle from msiano purchased at his only shopping destination the Wine King or as I call them the slightly below average King. Not going into detail about a beer that totally underwhelmed me. This would be acceptable for a Saranac or Yuengling dry stout but a North Coast, sorry no. This one needs some serious revamping and I cant figure out why its rated over 3 none the less slightly over 3.5?? WTF??
Pours dark reddish brown/black, dark chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, little caramel, slight bitter dry finish.
Med brown color. Dark chocolate, cherries, oranges and fudge in the nose. Light mouth of fudge and caramel. Somewhat caramelly, moderately bitter finish.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2008 pours black with ruby highlights, a big tan head leaves a lot of lacing. looks great in the glass.  sweetish flavor, noticeable hops in the flavor, sort of like dried apricots.  very flavorful, coffee and toasty flavor. loved it!

Pours a nice dark brown color with a tan head. Aroma is of roasted coffee beans. Black coffee and dark chocolate flavor with a hint of smoke near the end. My only problem with this beer is that its a little thin. Still enjoyable and worth a shot.
bottle, walnut colored pour with a slight tan ring, nose of cocoa, malt and peat, flavor is a malty cocoa, smoke and fruit, flavor is slightly thin

Poured from 12oz bottle into pint glass.
Aroma - Chocolate and toasted malts with notes of semi-sweet chocolate, coffee and floral.
Appearance - Nearly opaque black with ruby red tinges when held to light source. 2 finger tan head with decent retention. Light lacing
Flavor - Toasted and chocolate malt, coffee and well balanced notes of floral and citrus hops.
Palate - Medium mouthfeel. Nicely carbonated for the style. Dry finish
Overall - Goes down smooth. A little heavy on the citrus for my taste. Still, very well made and tasty. Could definitely drink a few.

Crushed with Jakebra.  I done been spoiled by imperial stouts.  All un-imperials taste too thin.  That being said, excellent for something thin.  Chocolaty nose.  Same in flavor, with some coffee-ness.  Solid.

Dark black with slight brown at the edges two nice creamy fingers of tan head leaves a brown splotchy lacing as it recedes.  Dark roasted malts, coffee, and slight sourness/astringency.  Big roasty malt taste, light coffee bean and good hoppy bitterness in the finish.

12oz bottle.  Deep black-red color.  Toffee and chocolate aroma.  Initial dry mouthfeel leads to a smooth, smoky, malt finish.  Hops are more present than in your typical Stout, giving it a pleasant balance.  Lots of roasted malt in the finish.  A nice Stout.

Dark walnut brown, nearly black. Creamy tan head, okay lacing, decent retention. Cocoa, graham, and light roasty aromas. Flavor is very roasted, with coffee notes and a slightly charred bitterness. Semisweet chocolate provides a touch of sweetness. Mouthfeel is decent, but the carbonation is too high. This style would be better suited to a light carbonation to enhance a creamy body. Nonetheless, this is miles tastier than the standard Irish stout fare like Guinness and Murphy’s.

12oz bottle. Pours dark brown/black with a thin light brown head, some lace. Smells somewhat subdued dark roasty malty, slight coffee and dark chocolate. Taste is roasty malts and coffee with a lingering bitter dark chocolate flavor. Pretty good. A little thin, medium body with vibrant carbonation.
Pours dark and nearly oily with a mocha colored head. Very toasty and distinct flavor, sits on the palate heavily, with a malty impression. Good, hearty stout.

Bottle pours a black toffee with toasted caramel malts and light chocolate aroma into a light brown foamy head. Good lacings mostly lasting  Fruity sweet initial finish with a short hoppy-alcohom bite.

Pours obsidian black with a small white head. Aroma predominantly of chocolate with hints of caramel, coffee, and roast. Taste is more roasty than I had suspected it would be. About 50/50 light chocolate and roast bitterness. Pretty good and easy drinking.

Bottle:  Poured a dark brown/black with a chocolate colored head.  The aroma was coffee and chocolate.  The flavor was again, chocolate and coffee.  Overall, an easy drinking dark beer.  I enjoyed this one a lot.
(Bottle).   Milk chocolate aroma.  Black body, creamy brown head.  Malty chocolate flavor, hint of a bite from hops.  Excellent.

pours dark brown with small, thick tan head.  aroma is much coffee and chocolate.  flavor is somewhat a letdown, but i think its due to the very thin body.  not bad for a session beer, but nothing overly special.

Pours a deep brown color with a thin off white head.  Aroma is roasted malt and a hint of coffee.  A lot of malt undertones going on.

Flavor is unfortunately a bit bitter and thin.  The flavor doesn’t quite follow through with the aroma and there’s a really distinct aspirin bitterness going on.  Not entirely pleasant.

Pint - Peaks Brewpub - Port Angeles, WA 
Aroma  Deep dark malt aroma with a lingering of chocolate and coffee. 
Appearance  Dark Brown in color, clear, with a thin head.  
Flavor  Nice dark malt flavors toasty with a chocolate and coffee flavor with that deep rich flavor.   
Palate  Great Mouthfeel, Nice texture with a dry chocolate finish. 
Overall  This is one of the better beer for the night.  Loved the flavor this went down very smooth and was a delight to drink.

12oz bottle. Pours a clear dark mahogany under a fizzy quickly receding beige head. Some lacing though. Aroma is fairly light, mostly a burnt and roasted maltiness with a light anise and chalk accent. Flavor is roasted and burnt malt with a good bit of astringency. Finishes dry and moderately bitter with some coffee and chalkiness. Mouth feel was lighter bodied with a fairly watery texture. Carbonation is active and fizzy.
Bottle.  Poured a dark brown with a creamy, two finger brown head.  Aroma of malt and coffee.  Flavor is dry with malt and coffee.  Body is way too light for a beer like this.  Not impressed at all.
poured dark with creamy tan/brown head.chocolate aroma and hint of coffee.  Taste is malty and a bit dark fruity - good flavor
Bottle. Poured dark brown with a creamy tan head. Roasty aroma with caramel and chocolate. Flavour is dry malty with coffee and chocolate and ends up very dry and bitter.

Yet another outstanding beer from North Coast Brewing. While I haven’t had North Coasts entire portfolio, everything that I have drank so far has been absolutely divine.

Old No. 38 pours a rich velvety black with a thin layer of cappuccino colored foam on top which slowly fades into a ring around the edge of my stout glass. Toasty malts, chocolate, and nuts greet my nose before slaking my thirst as I take my first quaff. A very smooth, creamy mouthfeel full of rich, dry dark chocolate, sweet toasty malts, and a hint of nuts. A very dry stout, each quaff leaves a nice arid bitterness throughout. A good example of the classic dry stout which Guinness has made famous. As I swirl my glass to release more vapors and nose, a rich cappuccino head forms each time, keeping the nose and palate alive. Old No. 38 has a light lemon bitter bite near the back, but it is the dark chocolate, nuts, and malts which rain supreme. A full body, but pleasantly light and easy to drink. A bit more into my beer, I notice some raisin notes in the nose and palate. A pleasant addition to the overall well-balanced flavor profile. As I finish Old No. 38, I am left with a pleasantly mild dry sensation, lingering dark chocolate, malts, and nuts rounding into a mild bitter lemon nip.

For a dry stout, I would rate Old No. 38 from North Coast right up there with Guinness, if not a bit better. A delectable delight and a perfect pairing for some cool seafood fare such as fresh clams or oysters.

Pours a black/dark brown with a one or two finger creamy tan head. The nose is earthy, slightly sweet, rich, molasses, caramel, chocolate. The flavor is chocolaty, crisp, dry, caramel, very sharp flavor, lightly roasty. The mouthfeel is pretty sharp and dry, alcohol shows slightly.

Bottle, black pour small brown head.  Aromas of toasted malt, roasted coffee, and some very dark chocolate.  Flavor is coffee and some chocolate.  Very dry and chalky, but the mouthfeel is still pretty nice.  Again I find that I can pass on the dry stouts for the most part.

Dark mahogany pour with a stiff khaki head.  Aromas of slow-roasted coffee, bitter chocolate, and vanilla.  Flavors aren’t as aggressive as with other stouts but are pleasant.  No really off tastes...a good solid session stout (if there is such a thing).
12 oz bottle. Black with a tan head. Roasty aroma with some coffee and chocolate hints. Dry roasted flavors. Very dry finish. Smooth mouthfeel. Good stout.

Color of strong black coffee... the inch-plus sand dune head is thick and firm. Roasty aroma with hints of sweet cherry, wet iron, and cocoa. Roasty and bittersweet flavor, faint coppery and old milk taste. As the long espresso bean and sunflower seed aftertaste fades, a tin can flavor becomes annoyingly persistent. Creamy, lightish mouthfeel, which is appropriate to the style. By the end of the glass, the foam still remains, undiminished in size. A decent Irish dry with metallic off-flavors.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a black color, which proves to be a dark brown when held up to the light . 1/2" tan head with some rings of lace. Aroma is roasted malt with some minor coffee notes. Smooth dry palate. Flavor is roasted malt with coffee & bitter bakers chocolate. An average dry stout.

12 oz. bottle from a Cost Plus "Beers around the World" type of box.  Low expectations, especially after some of the drain pours in the box.  Dark pour with latte colored head that left just the smallest but firm lace patch.  Scent is dark roast malt and coffee(nuts? caramel?).  Smoother scent than I expected.  First taste impression is deeper, richer, and more of a full flavor than I would have guessed.  Doesn’t fill up the mouth like a really good stout does though, at least what I think of in a GOOD stout.  Bitter finish.  A bit tinny?  Left the mouth drier than I like from a beer this dark.  I want that salivation that just won’t stop.  Getting better as it warms, however.  I think I might be generous with this score.  I’m decently buzzed, and maybe just being nice damnit.  Do I have to buy this beer again, just to rate it?  It doesn’t hold a candle to Stone or Port or AleSmith or Lost Abbey.  No, I ain’t buying it again.

Bittersweet coffee grounds and toasted malts in the nose.  Opaque black body is topped by a decent, fine bubbled, tan-brown head that lasts well and leaves some lacing on the sides of the glass.  Roast and biscuity malts blend well together.  Dry body with creamy texture and very nice soft bubbled effervescence that enlivens the tongue and cheeks.  Snifter.  Cellar temperature.  Bottle (Bottleworks, Aug-08).

12oz bottle from Peace St. Market, Raleigh. One of the first dry stouts I really appreciated, this one remains solid and enjoyable to me. Nice toasted malt aroma, thick body, slightly thin mouthfeel, and a rich roasted quality with a pleasing dry finish. Nothing to make it stand out from the pack, but very enjoyable.

Pours ebony with a thin tan head. Aroma is roasty, and it tastes of roasted coffee and dark chocolate. Definitely a little thinner than I was expecting, but the lightness on the palate isn’t necessarily a bad thing. I liked this one.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear dark mahogany with a beige head that fades fast into a soup scum and spotty lacing.  Nose is smoky burnt malt and light coffee.  Taste is similar to the aroma with some powdered cocoa in the finish.  Lighter than expected mouth feel.  Meh, nothing to write home about.

Bottle thanks to beerbill!  Pours a deep brown colour, not quite black with a thin but solid tan head.  Smell is fairly roasty, with hints of coffee, and a reasonably strong floral hops in the nose too.  Flavour is strong dark chocolate with some other roasts in it, as well as some sweet dark fruit notes.  It’s not quite as creamy as it probably could be, but it’s pretty nice.

Dark brown with ruby highlights and a thick tan head.
Strong chocolate and coffee. Good dark roast aroma.
Flavour is bitter burnt roast, some coffee. A little light on the palate.

12oz bottle. Nice blend of good roast character and leafy hops in the nose. Crisp and fresh. Pours a deep black-brown with a tan head. Flavor is a really roasted, crisp fresh stout. Nice dryness, minimal sweetness and a touch of caramels. Nice roasty dryness. Clean, with a long draw of leafy, grassy hops that created interesting play. Enjoyable.
