12 oz poured deep brown/black.  Tan head that lasted until the end of the drink.  Roasty aroma with some bread-like smells.  Coffee like initial taste.  Some toffee and roasted flavor.  A bit on the dry side.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Black with lasting brown head and lace.  Roasted coffee and dark chocolate aroma.  ROasted chocolate with mild dark fruit and clean bitter finish.  Medium body and carbo.  Slight carbo bite.  Lingering bitter coffee.   Very good.  Could use slightly more body but I guess that’s par for the dry stout style.
bottle. pours black with foamy brown head, some lacing. roasty aroma. solid bitter solid to follow up. palate is light, develops a creamy quality as it warms. dry finish. nice easy drinking stout.

Bottle.  Not much aroma here, though I let it warm.  Poured deep black with a thick tan head.  Full flavour of coffee, toast and malt.  Lingering coffee and malt finish.   Another good one from North Coast.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle. This beer is rich. Taste like a good stout should. Smells like coffee. Tastes like chocolate and coffee. Smooth beer that is very easy to drink. Is a nice beer to sip. Would get again,
Old 38 has the bitter, chocolate, coffee flavors of a great stout. Unfortunately the flavor is too mild, as if it was watered down slightly. To bad, it was almost a really nice beer

Pours a dark brown nearly black with a creamy beige head. Aroma is very chocolaty and coffee and pretty sweet/malty. Flavor is mildly bitter but still mostly roasted malts like chocolate and coffee and a bit of a nuttiness to it. Fairly dry on the finish as well. Medium bodied. Not a bad dry stout at all, and a good choice at the bar/store, but if there is something fuller in body with some more complex flavors, go for that instead.
Warm roasty flavor and aroma.  Some hop bitterness and overall well-balanced.  coffee tones are present.  Not too heavy, but not thin either.  Solid.

This brew wasnt my cup of tea.  It was a bit more smokey/nutty than I woudve liked.  Overall, Im not a huge fan of North Coast.  Theyre not quite malty enough (except for Old Stock) and seem a little thin.

12 fl oz brown bottle. Dark brown pour, sizeable fluffy beige head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee/roast malt. Flavour echoes aroma - coffee and cocoa up frontt. Dry roasted finish. Medium body with tight fine carbonation.

Single from Three Cellars Milwaukee.

Rich, well blended hint of coffee with a slight feel of alcohol. some earthy malts, light sweetness, nutty.

Metaphorically speaking, this seems to be the younger and smaller brother to North Coasts Old Rasputin Russian Imperial Stout. Some of the same basic characteristics are present, such as the coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, brown sugar, et cetera, but without that profound eye-opening flavor and high alcohol content. Also considerably watery compared to the Old Razz. Other than that it is excellent. And by excellent I mean that this would be the premier beer for most breweries, thats how good it is. Yet in this case it plays 2nd fiddle to the virtuosic Old Rasputin. Either way, you cant lose, as everything North Coast touches turns to gold.

Near black in colour, ruby edges, small but lingering beige coloured head, good lacing.  The aroma is lightly sweet, underlying sourness provides a distraction, some very light chocolate and coffee.  The flavour is slightly roasty, some earthy malts, light sweetness, nutty.  Lightly bitter mouthfeel, medium/light body, medium/light carbonation.  Finishes with some chalky bitterness, ending sweet.
Its fairly decent, the coffee and roast come out more as this warms.
355ml bottle obtained in a trade with JohnnyJ, thanks John.
Opened on December 30, 2007
No date.
Bottled. Poured dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma is slightly roasted and some coffee. Flavor is dry coffee with some roasted and earth notes. Body is slightly thin.
Pours a dark brown with a very large chocolate coloured head. Wicked rich in chocolate and coffee flavors. mid palate i taste roasted nuts, and it ends with a bread like finish. very sweet.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours black with a huge creamy and tan head. Roasted malt and somewhat wet woody hops note. Flavour is hardroasted malt and solid bitter. Goes into a more smooth flavour before the finish with a creamy texture containing notes of coffee and malt. Mild chocolate note too. Dry bitter finish with more of the same roasted malt flavour coming through.

Pours dark with a dark tan head.  Lots of roasted malts with dark chocolate and coffee.  Decent balance from hops at first but to much sweetness on the finish.  Could be a lot better if not for the lingering sweetness.
Hmm. Over rated. Not firm-bodied. One of the least exceptional stouts Ive had. On tap at Humpys in Anchorage. Watery. Roasted coffee. Not very memorable.

Pour is dark with medium fluffy tan head.  Aroma is of bittersweet chocolate.  Flavor is somewhat sweet with more cocoa flavor as well as very light hints of coffee and a toasted malt.  Coffee prevails a little more in the finish.  Not much hop bitterness.  Very smooth and well blended.  Does have a dry finish.  The more I drink it, the more I like it.  Good brew.  Would buy again.

Pours with a largish, creamy, light brown head covering a black body. Lots of coffee, dark chocolate and flowers in the aroma. Taste is of coffee grounds, bitterness, and caramel. Watery mouthfeel, with light carbonation.

Dark body, thin lacing head. Taste :Choc, malt, raisin. Lite to medium head, dry finish. Nice aftertaste. Somewhere between a great brown ale and an ok stout. Only the chew is in question. Do like the taste combination.

Black with a thick tan head. Aroma is rather restrained roasted malt and sesame seeds. Flavor is very dry, ristretto espresso. As it warms, there is a flavor that reminds me of cottage cheese. Its not as bad as it sounds, believe me. It is smooth, I guess. There is nothing really remarkable about this one, its just a decent stout.

Bottle from Booze Bros. in Reno, NV. Poured a very dark brown, almost black. Smell of coffe and chocolate. A little on the dryer side for a stout, which really brought out the roasted malt flavor. Great brew!!
12oz - Aroma of dusty dark malts, cream and chocolate.  Pours black with a big brown head and good lacing.  Flavor matches aroma.  Palate is dry.  A tasty easy drinking session stout.
Very solid stout.  A coffeeish roastiness to it.  A little light on the finish, but good effort.

Poured a big head which diminished in size but remained for a long while.  Jet black and beautiful to the eye.  Roasted chocolately smell.  Not an overwhelming taste but all the usual suspects in a stout are there:  chocolate and malts.  The best of the 3 stouts Im tasting this session, but nothing I will rush out to buy again.  Id take it if you gave to me in a heartbeat though.
Black-brown, oily pour, firm brown head with generous lacing. Rich coffee, cocoa, and roast. Creamy mouthfeel, richly malty, long finish that is moderately bitter and dry. Superb!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Decent effort.  Pours a very deep, dark brown with tan head that fades fast. Aroma is chocolate roast with hints of coffee.  Taste is chocolate and butter, very smooth finish.  Would drink again.

Blackish pour with a med-lg tannish head. Aroma is roasty with some dark chocolate.  Flavor is chocolatey with some roasted coffee.  A tad buttery.  Not a bad dry stout, but this one always seems bland to me.

Poured a very deep brown almost black color with a dark tan head. The head went down fairly quickly to just a wisp of a film. There was a mild chocolate aroma. The flavor was a bit smokey and later a sense of a light chocolate flavor in the dry clean finish.

bottle poured into a snifter has a transparent brown ruby in color and a thin layer of tan head. aroma has cocoa, dark malt, light roasted coffee, some sweetness, and toffee. there is something interesting in the nose that may be hops. roasted malt body with some coffee and caramel. some sweetness is present and it finishes going dry with carbonation on your tongue and light biting bitters. little touch of chocolate pops in from time to time. argument could be made it is a little thin but it is a dry stout and i am partial to liking there beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown-black colour with a beige head. Roasted malts, some tar and a hint of perfume (which is difficult to define). Flavour is a hint of sweetness followed by roasted and perfumy notes. The finish is dry and bitter with laods of coffee beans.

Served cold from a bottle. The aroma is a delicious blend of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. It pours a deep, oily black with a nice-sized tan head. It is remarkably smooth and easy to drink, the flavors are mostly roasted malts and coffee. it has a great mouth feel and leaves no discernible aftertaste. a fantastic stout.
On tap at Plan B, W Hartford CT. Standard stuff, some coffee, mild chocolate, mild roastiness. Fairly thin mouthfeel. Nothing special, but nothing to complain about.

Let me first start by saying there is no aroma for some reason.  But it pours a deep black with a huge tan head that lasts quite awhile before I take my first drink.  Huge biscuit and toffee flavors with a nice smoothness.  Very drinkable and right on with the alc content with this one.  It all comes together nicely with a lingering finish.  Nice beer.

Quickly descending beige head, really dark brown body, not quite black. Roasted malt aroma, with coffee and chocolate. Main taste aside from the roasted malts was of bitter dark chocolate. This is a little on the sweet side. Hints of coffee are in this beer. Not as thick as I would have liked it, probably would be better off the tap than out of the bottle.
Bought in Kolding.Black with small beige head.Aroma of licorice and coffee,feels rosted and mild a littel to thin to be a good stout but o.k.
pours a deep black with little to no head.  toasty, roasty aromas.  notes of chocolate, rhubarb, and coffee.

Pours deep dark brown, slight reddish tint. Medium tan head. Aroma of coffee bean and cocoa powder with some milk chocolate notes. Flavors enter gorgeous but then leave fast and cleanly like a good lover the morning after. A little thin but good.
12oz bottle. dark black, small tan head. roasty aroma. flavor of coffee and roast. very dry finish

Dark mahogany black pour with 1/2 a finger of tan head. Malty coffee aroma. Very chocolatey, roasted barley, coffee flavor - definitely on the sweet (chocolate) side. Solid brew but a little thin for a stout.

Pours a nice deep black with a lots of bubbly light brown head. Lots of carbonation on this one.  Aroma of malt, and toasted barley, chocolate and coffee. Flavor of coffee, malt, chocolate and roasted barley. Has a slightly dry finish.  Worth trying once, but I probably wouldnt go out of my way to get more.

~Pours a dark reddish black colour. Creamy off white head. Lots of lacing.
~Sweet Smokey Scent. Hint of berries.
~Woodsy choclate coffee flavour. 
~Good stout.

pours beautiful black color. roasty, charcoal a little coffee on the nose.
very sweet malts with a little bitterness on the end. full body but just enough to hold it all together, drinks nicely but i think its too sweet to be a session stout for me.

Bottle. Pours almost black with a tan head. Roasted malt aroma with hints of sweet chocolate and alcohol. Medium/full body. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, and sweet bourbon. Not the best stout in the world, but pretty good.

Dark brown with a 1 finger head. Nice roasted grain, nutty smell. Rich, hearty roasted malt and lightly bittersweet chocolate taste here with a light hoppiness to finish. A good everyday stout. 012706
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: From bottle : Pours a very dark black, with little carbonation bubbles clinging to the bottom sides of the glass.  A thin light brown head forms, then quickly shrinks to small lilly pads of foam on the surface of the beer.  Nose is strong malt, roasted and coffee smells.  When i go to take a sip, there is a strong carbonated feel, then it quickly fades to smoothness.  Taste is also very malty, not so much roastedness as there was in the smell though.  Strong presence of wood and oak chips, some coffee, and ends with a little hint of alcohol.  Thick bodied with a nice mellow aftertaste.  Only suggetion is that it is a little too carbonated, but other then that, a very worth while stout.
Black with medium light brown head. Aroma has trong coffee notes, roasted malt and chcolate. Flavor is sweet with roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Somewhat watery ind the end.

Juen 2006 - Dark brown with reddish highlights.  Faint roasty aroma.  Carbonation hits you right away and a bubbly roasty flavor then takes over.  A touch of wood (but not a burnt flavor) is present with a shade of licorice.  Mouthfeel is really carbonated, yet smooth, but the flavor is thin.  Alright, but not special.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a very dark brown in color with a strong tan head.  The aroma is chocolate, some coffee, roasted malt, and a hint of licorice.  The flavor is mostly semi sweet chocolate and coffee, with roasted malt and light citrus hops thrown in for good measure.  This is a solid yet unspectacular beer from a weel respected brewer.
nice brown black pour with brown head, excellent caramelized sugar taste with chocolate/oak/coffee notes.   Leaves a very pleasant and long-lasting taste on the palate

bottle pours dark, opaque brown. with small but lasting tan frothy head.  Smells burnt brown sugar.  Tastes equally of coffee and chocolate with some alcohol in the back and a long bitter finish.   Could be a little sweeter and I detected some tin.  Palate is mostly smooth, coating the mouth and tongue with just a litttle too much carbonation.  Overall delicious and extremely solid.  Dont drink too cold.

Bottle. Black in color, very nice nitro-like creamy head. Aroma of bread crust, vanilla, pepsi and caramel. The flavor is expansive: it starts pretty mellow, a little acidic, then the coffee-like bitterness takes the lead with impressive intensity. The bitterness lingers for quite a long time. The palate starts a little watery but ends on an elegant and sustained dryness. Faithful to the style.

Poured an attractive dark brown with some garnet highlights and nice tan head that dissipated to a small tan ring. Aroma is of caramel, chocolate, and coffee. Flavor is also of caramel, chocolate, and coffee that is balanced by the hop presence. Mouthfeel is pleasant and little lacing was left on glass. This was a nice beer that I enjoyed especially after it warmed a little which enhanced the flavor. Very smooth with high degree of drinkability.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2008 Bottle thanks to beerbill. Pours a dark brown with a great tan head. The aroma is fairly light; some smoked malts. The taste is mostly light coffee, roasted malts, some hops, brown sugar and engine soot. Quite nice. Well made and an easy drink. Id drink this all night. The body is a little thin, but overall quite good. A damn good stout.
exceptional stout, this is the beer that got me to start looking for North Coast offerings, and I wasnt disappointed.

12oz bottle. Nice, but not overpowering roasted malt aroma. Slightly charred wood. Black liquorice... but sweeter. Dark, but sweet chocolate. Pours Nearly opaque with dark brown highlights. I was looking for a little more of that sweetness on the tongue. Lots of roasted malt. Rock hard on the palate. Mild bitter astringency. Finishes with a lingering roasted maltiness.

Pours almost black with a nice creamy/tan head. Smells of some malts, coffee, toffee, chocolate, smokey and nuts. Subtle flavors of sweetness along with every flavor the aroma promised. A little dry and bitter finish, same with the carbonation, a little. Had everything you could want in a stout just more mild than I would like in each category. I very much enjoyed this and could drink as many as I please.

Pours almost black with a creamy, foamy semi lasting tan head.  Smell is nuts and cream and roastiness.  Hazlenut creamer like notes.  Flavor is dark and roasty, slighty sweet, and with a light shortly lived slightly dry bitter finish.  Average body.  Not too thin but not as thick as I prefer.  Moderate carbonation.  Pretty good standby stout that you could easily have more than one of.  Not unhappy that I bought a 6 pack of this in Las Vegas.  Nice beer.
Pours black, creamy head.  Nice stout, roasts, bitter chocolate, some dark fruit.  Good.
Well made beer, nice dark malts in there with enough hops to balance but not overpower.  Solid ... Ill get this again.

Pours out a nice head that falls and leaves a strong lacing. The smell is chocolately with a little coffee. Smooth and inviting. Taste is bitter chocolate with a nice coffee aftertaste. This is the hoppiest stout Ive ever had, but it is from the west coast. The hops even out the flavor as you drink. Feels smooth in the mouth. Its a little different than the malty stouts I predominately try, but still very nice.
350 ml bottle from Pizza Port.  Black with a fizzy white head.  Chocolate aroma.  Dry milk chocolate taste with some roasty noes.

Near black with a large deep tan head.  Sweet roasted malts, molasses, coffee, chocolate, and soft sour dark fruits in the aroma.  Flavor is a little on the harsh side.  Intense roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, nutty, with the dark fruits nearly hidden.  Nice body.  A real nice stout, though maybe a tad harsh.  Could use a little mellowing.

Bottle.  NIce dark color with a brown foamy head.  Perfect amount of carbonation.  Sweet malt and chocolate aromas.  Coffee and chocolate flavors, a bit of toasted malt.  Well rounded, a nice suprise.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2008 Pours a near black with medium sudsy tan head.   Sweet/sour aroma of chocolate and hops.  Metallic flavor at first sip, but then lots of  bitter chocolate.  Roasted coffee in the finish.   Body is light for a stout.

12 oz. from Riverside.  Aroma allows nice floral notes to emerge from the chocolaty malts, though the aroma seems a little light.  Beautiful appearance in the glass, with a stable one-finger dark tan head.  Coffee, chocolate, a little nutty, but with some hops lingering nicely on the upper palate in the finish.  A little light for a stout - if this were mislabeled as a porter, this would rate higher - and just a tad bit too carbonated.  Overall a nice entry; the flaws are very minor, and theres a lot of good stuff going on here.

This is a solid performer.  Nice well rounded biscuit malts, burned nuts, chocolate, coffee, and toast.  It wasnt balanced enough with hops, as it was too straightforward for me.  Easy drinking stout.
dark with lots of rich foamy head, dry soft aroma mellow flavor full bodied heaviness

Pours dark brown with a blood red hue and has a nice tan head.  The aroma has roasted malt, cream, milk chocolate and light spicy hops.  Medium / full body that is lush and smooth with gentle semi-sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts with the aroma traits with all of them being very smooth and accommodating.  The finish has some woody hops added.  Overall a nice stout.

Ive yet to be disappointed by a North Coast beer, and this is no exception.  This stout offers lots of roastiness with not a lot of accompanying flavors Im accustomed to in a stout (coffee, chocolate, liquorice, etc), but was quite dry and certainly lives up to my expectations for this style (dry stout).

The beer pours a non-viscous black-red, with abundant cumulus-like head formation which had pretty good vitality.  Aroma was pretty minimal, but offered a small quantity of roastiness.  Flavor was very roasty and dry, like having a mouthful of cinders, which for me is a good thing.  Mouthfeel was clean but a bit thin.

All-in-all, I thought this a very nice dry stout.  Im not sure where I got this particular sample, but I believe I picked it up during Murrays Wine & Spirits going-out-of-business sale.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a very dark brown, not quite black, with a moderate beige head that lasted through to the end of the beer and left partial lacing on the glass.  Light but pleasant aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.  More flavorful than the aroma would indicate with roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee all present.  Light bitterness at the finish.  The mouthfeel was a bit thin, otherwise an overall solid brew.
Pours black with good beige head. The  aroma has lots of chocolate and roasted malt. The flavor does not quite live up with with a medium body and not much bitterness.

(Bottle) Pours a very dark brown color with a beige head. Dusty malt aroma. Taste is of cocoa and sweet coffee. Thin mouthfeel, especially for a North Coast product. Smooth and dry finish. Not a bad beer, but slightly disappointing.

On tap at Small Bar- Division, Chicago.  I probably shouldnt even rate this beer, as I dont like dry stouts as an overall style.  It was better than Guiness, but nothing too complex.  I guess it was fine for what it is-- a dry stout.

Black pour with a dark tan head.  Nice moderate dark chocolate/powdered cocoa aroma, maybe some licorice in there too.  Good roast component up front, followed by a lightly sweet chocolate malt character.  Not really a thick enough mouthfeel, but the overall balance here is nice.

Bottle. Dark prown appearance with small head that disappears quickly. Body is watery-light.  Carbonation is too much for my taste. Malt presence is relatively subdued, finish was much better than initial sip. Highly disappointing having recently rated Old Rasputin my top beer.
12oz...I was happy to find this beer at BevMo, as I was getting burnt out on nitro-cans getting damaged during shipment...not bad for a CA brewer.

(bottle) Pours dark brown with an off-white head that disappears.  Taste contains some roasted malt, coffee, and upon warming some hints of brownie.  Taste is quite chocolatey with a pretty nice finish of roasted malt/coffee bitterness that lasted a bit.  Somewhat light bodied(could be a tad bit thicker), aggressively carbonated initially, but once it warmed it tasted much better.  Not a bad brew.

Pours almost black with a nice creamy head.  So far so good.  A touch of hops in the nose,  some chocolate...not much else.  Has someone ashed in my beer?  All I can really taste is heavy smoke and skunk.  I can find the malt and hops underneath,  but no coffee.  I bought this to send as an extra,  but didnt.  Im kind of glad I didnt waste the guys time.

You know....I like North Coast beers alot, but this one was not a very good example of either a stout, or a beer from North Coast. The roasted malt tasted like it had been in a garbage can, or maybe an ash tray....when its that bad its just too hard to tell. Pour was too light for a stout (although Im probably just being picky at this point). Nose was nothing distinguishable. A very disappointing buy.
Light  ruby red color.  A thick tan head. This is a very pleasent light stout.  A ton of tobacco and roast malt.  One of my favorites.

Very beautiful light tan head straight from the bottle, and a lovely dark brown through the glass.  The taste is malty chocolate-coffee but isnt over-developed.  This isnt like most stouts, as it finishes very smooth and sweet.  One of my favorites.

Dry stouts seem to get pushed aside it seems, sometimes I am not looking for some huge complex coffee/chocolate/oatmeal monstrosity.  This is a great example, I wish i could have it on tap.  Very toasty, take a 16 oz Beamish and burn it down to 12 oz and you would have this.

Pours to a jet black with thhick tan head that lingers well and leaves excellent lacing. Nose is a pleasant malt chocolate-toffe, and the taste follows suit perfectly. Mouthfeel of this medium bodied beer is sweet and slightly tingly, and the finish is smooth and sweet.

A nice tasty beer.

1 inch head, frothy, light-brown.  Weak aroma, toasted, burnt, mild coffee.  Nothing much else.  Not very impressed.   Would have expected more from the brewery that produces Rasputin.  Coffee was th eonly distinctive aroma or taste.  Im not sure how old this bottle is since I picked it up at KClingers in Hanover, PA.

i get a kind of fruity cherry like flavor and then the coffee.and that coffee flavor is a bit bitter like old or burnt coffee. i get alcohol. a port wine like aroma. a bit strange and i get into that. a bit light and refreshing in substance yet it is quite a bit heavier on the flavor. noticeably harsh and laid back bitter finish that dissapates in some order. freaky little number. slick/creamy

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2010 Creamy and smooth.  Head lasts and lasts.  Pours a medium brown yet looks black in the glass.  Procured at Half Time in Poughkeepsie.  Missed out on the coffee notes.  Mellow crisp finish.  Body surprisingly light.  Nice bottlecap.  Re rate 10/14/2010:  Some truly pleasant crisp yet muted coffee tone.  Moderate body with some toasted malt peeking thru.

Bottle poured into pint glass.  This is a great dry stout.  Pours out a nice dark brown colour with a medium brown head.  Great creamy lacing.  Aroma was unsweetened chocolate.  Flavour was more milky chocolate with a hint of bitterness.  Really enjoyed this beer.

This was a classic dark stout with a very rich taste and heavy texture.  The aroma and flavor have a strong roasted coffee sense to them.  A very drinkable and enjoyable stout, but not soon to become one of my favorite stouts.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 This is a good, rich stout with a decent, but not very long-lasting head and rich flavour for a dry stout.  It is overall well-rounded and balanced, but the coffee and bitter elements seem just a tad too strong.

Ive been disappointed with any stout not carrying the word "imperial" in front of it for some time now. Old 38, then, is a pleasing reminder of what a good basic stout can be. Poured coal-black, with brown highlights when held up to the light, quickly dissipating head. Nose is heavily coffee-based, with big roasted chocolate coming through as well. Taste has more chocolate, coffee, and tons of malt. Finishes clean. North Coast hasnt let me down yet.
Bottle: Pours a dark reddish brown with a thick frothy head, aroma of chocolate and malt, taste is somewhat bitter and quite malty.  Im not a big fan of this one.

Lots of Chocolate. Lots and lot of chocolate. Chocolate aroma, chocolate flavor. Too much bitterness. Actually I didnt know it was a Dry Stout until I started my firs on. Never liked Dry stout. Still dont
Fairly pedestrian Stout. Chocolate flavor - malty and not m any hops. NC makes a better stout with Rasputin.
9/27/05.500ml. Dark brown with beige head. Coffee roast aroma with bitter coffee dry finish.

Man. I had been used to some weak stouts without much personality. But this one is rich and deep with heavy chocolate tones that are firm, but not so strong that you are tasting a cocoa bean in your mouth. There is also a firm roasted coffee taste in your mouth that stays there as well. This stout has the most personality than any other I have had in a very long time. Most of those others I would pass on in the future, but this one Id stick with for a while.
Seems like a middle-of-the-road stout: not too sweet, not too dry.  Very drinkable.  Id have this again.

Pours black with a fluffy mocha head.  Nice roasty malty aroma with some dark chocolate and coffee.  Taste is of chocolate, coffee, and some molasses.  Pretty good, very drinkable.

Darkly roasted, burnt malt aroma. A dash of salt and pepper as well. A moderate amount of chocolate and fresh coffee in the flavor. Some fruity hoppiness lingers at the end. Dry, roasted finish. My burps taste good so thats a good sign! Overall, nice.

Pours almost black w/ a full, creamy froth. Superb hangtime receding to a full canopy and sticky, clinging lace. Aromas of chocolate and Belgian granite. Full nectar w/ ample creamy residual effers. nutty, buttery aroma. Pours an opaque black, tan head. Chocolate, coffee, nuts with a dry finish. Oily, buttery palate. Kind of grows on you as you drink it.

Dark burgundy. Big head. Rich exotic aroma, with chocolate and  alcohol note. Just hinting toward too sweet chocolate. Flavour tends toward the sweetened chocolate as well. A bit of strength in the finish with good coffee notes.

Tasted 2007-04-06. 1,5 years old, 35,5cl. Black with light brown head. Aroma of chocolate, burned malt and a bit of smoke. Very smokey taste of coffee and roasted malt. Its a good beer, but better exists!
Pours almost black with some head, flavor is dry, some cocoa, and toasty maltiness, it has nice body, i really enjoy this stout.

Pours a burgundy-brown with a creamy tan head that has some staying power. On the nose are: dark roasted malts, cocoa, and molasses. Simple but nice. Medium-bodied yet thin in the mouthfeel it finishes with some hop bitterness, a refreshing change from most of the dry stouts that Ive sampled. The flavor is of dark roasted almost burnt malt, coffee, a touch of chocolate and a nicely bitter hoppy finish. Many dry stouts finish bitter from the aggressive roasting of the malts and a burnt, dry finish. Old No. 38 does possess some of those flavors, which make it difficult to pull out any distinctly hoppy flavors, but the bitterness of this finish is more of the "squeeze" you get at the back of the tongue rather than a characteristic of its flavors. While Im not a huge fan of this style, I am a fan of this beer; a nice dry stout.

Bouteille 12oz, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur noire-rouge et transparente. Bottle. Small light brown and quickly disapering head. Black color. Fair display of lacework. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, liquorish, roasted malt and nutty notes as well. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation. Light to moderated sweet and bitter flavor. Light bitter coffee finish. Quit nice.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2007 Robust malty with a slightly coffee aroma, poured a dark brown with a large creamy head that was slightly tan in color, head stayed on most of the way, eventually giving way to thicker creamy cap, left good lacing on pint, great roasted malt flavor with chocolate, coffee, walnut, slight smoke and slight burnt malt flavors mixed in. Slightly sweet taste gives way to very slightly bitter with a light touch of smoke, very nice balance. Slightly heavier than light body, creamy and smooth texture, lively carbonation at first gives way to a nice soft carbonation, a very nice medium bitteersweet semi-dry finish. A very good stout! This has become one of my favorite Stouts. A great job by North Coast on Old#38. Will definitely drink many of these. Served in a Pint.

Quite a good stout, with a nose of coffee and roasted walnuts. The palate brings through the coffee notes in a understated way, with roasted ( if not burnt) walnuts coming through a tad too harshly. Somewhat offset by a nice, smoky alcohol bite that is just at the threshold of ones awareness and a bit of hops mingling with the roasted barley in this brew.
Black.  Sweet nutty aroma.  Swet smooth taste.  Slight nutty aftertaste but not overpowering.  Good medium texture.  Close to light texture but thick enough.  Too nutty a stout for me though.
Dark brown body with coffee and chocolate malts and the usual roasted character.  Smooth finish with similar taste.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2007 Bottle. Opaque brown-black with a large, lasting cap. Aroma is peppery-spicy, with some sour cream, chocolate, raisins, dark-roasted coffee and nuts. Very nice.  Sampled a six pack.  Poured very nice with a high carbonation factor and a nice dark dark stout appearance with subsequent settling.  Aroma was very dark coffee and malt base.  A very nice stout.

Pours  clear reddish brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and a hint of smoke.  Toasty with flavors of cocoa, roasted malt, and coffee.  Mouthfeel is a little creamy, but slightly thin.  Its a good dry stout.

Bottle at the Rover, Göteborg, Sweden. Clear dark reddish brown, medium creamy beige head. Roasted malt with dark fruits, coffee, and some butterscotch notes. Medium bodied, quite smooth. Well balanced, some sweetness and a moderate bitterness that mixes well.

Lots of roasted coffee and a surprising amount of bitterness. Mouthfeel is very full and creamy. I really enjoyed this beer.
Bottle.  Cocoa powder malt and wood ash aroma.  Dark brown with giant tan head.  Ashy cocoa malt flavor with mild hops finish.   Very nice stout - a much better choice than Guinness in the states.

Bottle. Creamy lightbrown good mostly lasting head. Dark red-amber colour. Moderate malty and moderate hoppy (flowers) aroma. Well balanced between hopps and malt. Moderate bitter flavor. Nice chocolate notes.
Long bitter hoppy! finish. Creamy palate. Great stuff.

Aroma creamy, ethereal, dissolving into a very smooth roast.  Almost no head, but looks as if a bit of mist hovers over the top of the brew.  This one smells and looks better than it tastes...the taste is sour and roasty: the sourness dominates and the roast is unrefined. I think this one would be greatly improved if the sourness were diminished or eliminated.

Appearance: Pours a distinctly brown color, with a mediocre tan head that quickly subsided while my head was turned for a few moments to watch a Seinfeld episode.

Smell: Black malts and bittersweet chocolate lead with some toffee and floral hop notes lingering in the background. Theres a slight sourness here.

Taste: An unmistakable roasted malt taste from beginning to end. A brief suggestion of chocolate, but its mostly just a coffee-like flavor throughout. Again, slightly sour. 

Mouthfeel/Drinkability: Short, simple, and to the point. Not unlike this review itself. A rather thin body - thankfully the carbonation remains somewhat low. A very "easy" stout. Let me just finish with a joke. What do you get when you cross a baked potato with a --Nevermind.

I think this is an excellent version of a classic stout.  It has notes of coffee, cocoa, and herbs which translate nicely into the mouthfeel.  It has drinks quite densley and pours perfect dark brown/black.

Bottle. 12 fl .oz. Very dark, almost opaque, amber color with fluffy off-white head.  Roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Nice full-bodied, creamy palate with a dry finish. Excellent malty, bittersweet flavor.

Very good beer.  Bottle pours a deep black/brown color with a creamy tan head that left a residual creamy film on top.  Loads of homemade caramel/toffee in the aroma. Pours a very dark brown with a one finger tan head.  Red color shines when held to the light.  

Aroma is dark malty chocolate and coffee with English noble hops in the nose.

This is one of my favorite stouts.

Pours water dark brown with medium brown head.  Chocolate coffee aroma with malt.  Very carbonated... light on the flavor.  Not a big wow factor.

[Bottle from Faaborg.]  

A very nice dry stout with a good beautiful head with aroflavor-notes of dry burned coffechocs added with some smoky dried fruits. Dry aftertaste.

Pours a dark brown with medium tan head, some lacing.  Aroma is sweet, dark chocolate, cherry, faint licorice, molasses. TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown that looked black in the glass, but showed red highlights when held to the light. It had a large tan head that mostly lasted. The aroma was moderate to heavy roasted, dark chocolate and mild coffee malts and lightly hoppy. The initial flavor was lightly bitter with coffee and chocolate, while the finish was lightly sweet and moderately to heavily bitter with something like burnt toast of an average duration. The body was medium to full, dry and a little oily with fizzy carbonation and a light metallic finish.

Pleasant smoky, earthy malt flavor--with a hint of blackstrap in the finish. Old No. 38 is an easy drinkin stout--exceptionally light. Little body. Lacks the silky mouthfeel of better stouts, though. (If its coldish outside and you really want a stout and youre in the mood to drink 3 pints--or more--this a perfect choice.)
Great aroma, full flavor. Dark color and a choclatey nut taste. Doesnt linger any longer than it needs to.

Pours a pitch black with a medium light tan head.  Pretty big roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, and walnuts.  I really like the nose on this one.  Taste isnt as good as it smells.  Still not bad though.  A little light for my taste for a stout, as I love the imperial stouts.  Pretty roasty but not very much chocolate.  Kind of a bitter roastiness.  I wish it was a little more full bodied.  Kind of a burnt wood taste in the finish which I really wasnt digging.  A little disappointed in this one.

This black stout has a nice nougat head, that leaves a good, thick lace. The aroma has notes of dark roasted malt and the mouthfeel is oily. The flavour has a nice bitterness all the way through and it develops further in the finish. It has notes of roasted malt and nice, strong licorice, light sweetness and a hint of coffee. Later I also get notes of chocolate.

Pour was an attractive dark brown with a nice light tan two-fingered head.  A bit of lacing but nothing dramatic.  The aroma was of coffee, cane sugar and some roasted malt and barley.  The flavor was smoky initially but it didnt manage to hang around once the beer opened up.  Initially the combination of smoke, coffee and roasted barley made me think that this one might be a real sleeper hit, however as it opened up it lost steam.  It ended up reminded me more of a sweet milk stout.  This beer was a medium bodied brew that as is often the case with these microbrews, had a world of potential but fizzled.
not to impressed with this beer. strong hoppy taste. bought from a beer store in tampa fl. if you like hops you might enjoy this more than me.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours dark with a tan head. Aroma of roast, coffee, and fruit. The flavor is roast, coffee, fruit. Good beer.
Bottle - a huge coffee nose.  Black body and a huge, creamy beige head.  It looks nearly like a nitro pour.  The brew is big and roasty and full of coffee.  Very nice!
Pitch black with a nice good light brownish head. Roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, vanilla and a bit smoky. Slightly sweet with a dry finish.

Bottle. Pitch black colour with a nice good lasting light brownish head. Aroma of well roasted malt, coffee, chocolate. Flavour is sweet,some vanilla,  bit smoky, good toasty maltiness, dark chocolate, coffee. Dry roasty finish.

Pours a totally opaque, very dark brown body with a beige head with white swirls. Fantastic retention, lacing thin but everywhere. Looks incredibly appetizing. Aroma is very subdued. Most noticeable traits are roasted malt, coffee, lactic acidity, chocolate, hazelnuts. Flavor is very coffee oriented, seducing at times, the roasted malts coordinated in a breathtaking balance. This really is an excellent dry stout. Very true to style, nicely done. Coffee with creamer and the slightest touch of sugar is a noticeable flavor deep into the reserved finish. Palate is also very smooth, nice carbonation levels and a broad mouthfeel. Very well done beer, could be my favorite of the style, a style which to me is usually quite tedious.

An  average dry stout. Stouts should jump out and let their presence known. This one shows up but thats it. The pour was a dark brown with a chocolate/cream aroma. The taste was very carbonated....which is where the problem lies. The carbonation subdued the coffee/caramel taste and made the beer seem empty.
