text: 12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of chocolate, toast, and dark coffee.  Poured dark brown in color with a hint of ruby.  Large, light brown, thick, foamy head lasted throughout.    Great lacing.  Flavor of chocolate, coffee, sugar, and cream.  Medium sweet, lightly bitter, not sour.  Medium body.  Slick texture.   Soft carbonation.  Medium dry cream/chocolate finish.  Overall a nice, smooth dry stout.

Bottle. Pours dark brown. A tight bubbly tan head sits atop. Aroma is robust roasty malts, burnt chocolate, and coffee. The flavor is again quite robust, lots of burnt malts, toffee, even some hops for balance. A very solid Dry Stout.
Bottle.  Great toasty coffee/ bitter chocolate roasted malt taste. Super smooth.  Medium to high carbonation.  Easy drinking but high in flavor.  Left a nice lace on the glass.  Nice.
Dark ruby/brown with a tan, shortlived head. Roasty, licorice aroma. Foamy mouthfeel, excellent balance, roasty and hoppy. Excellent, very drinkable. A little light for a stout.
Bottle.  Pours a dark brown wiht a light tan head.  Light aroma of coffe and roasted malts.  Taste is chocolately with a bit of bite on the end.  Very easy drinking, a good beer.

Pours a dark brown thats almost black with a large light tan head.  The smell is actually refreshing to me.  Very milky at first, with some mild chocolate and roast there, maybe some vanilla.  Taste is dark chocolate, and some vague citrus tang.  Bit of roast on the sides and back of my mouth.  Finishes more roasty, but still fairly wet on the palate.  Mouthfeel was a bit thin, and the carbonation is fairly high, but I think the texture is pretty good.  Not overly creamy, but still pleasing.  One of the more easy drinking yet still flavorful stouts Ive had.

Rich aroma of coffe and chocolate. So dark brown, its nearly black, and there are red hilites. The lasting head is tan. Starts sweet like a milk stout, develops some tar and coffee, a hit of carbonation, and then toasted malt. Then bitterness seals the finish. The result is lasting toasted malt and bitterness. Must be well balanced.
12 oz. bottle.  Very dark brown in color with a small off white head.   Aroma is chocolate, toffee.  Taste is chocolate, caramel, with a roasty lasting bitterness.

Appearance is very dark with reddish hints.  A thin medium tan colored foam appears but not for long.  Aroma is caramel malt and is on the sweet side.  First taste brings a nice sharp robust zing.  It is dry in the mouth but has a hint of sweet malt in the flavor.  Some barley can be tasted and there is a bit of a brandy taste without the warmth.  At mid glass some dark fruit begins to come out but the dryness and barley themes remain and might even be enhanced.  Others have noted a chocolate flavor in this beer but I did not notice it.  The dry stout style is not an exciting style to me, but this one had some zing and life but you had to look for it.

Bottle. Poured black with a tan head that left light lacing. Roasted aroma with dark chocolate and coffee. The flavor followed up the same with chocolate and coffee. Light body for stout, dry, and a coffee bean aftertaste.
I liked this beer.  I will drink it again.  I dont need to rehash what everyone else has said, but I would recommend this beer to be tried.

Pours chocolate colored with a fluffy brown head.  Aroma of coffee and chocolates with some roasted malt.  Taste is pretty much the same with the coffee being most prominent.  I would have again... maybe.

Aroma:chocolate fidge,small rosted malt...
Appearance:dark,huge head...
Flavor:rosted malt,light chocolate fudge....
dark chocolate colored thin head. aroma bitter coffee roasted barley. taste bitter and dry with a hint of sweetness. body very thin. i could take it or leave it. id probably leave it though

Dark chocolate brew with cappuccino froth, with aromas of fruit, then bread and chocolate.  Tastes a bit tired and old.  Some chocolate comes through but Old No. 38 is forgettable, like something outdated failing to prove it still matters.  Not enough, but decent in a common kind of way.

Pours a dark black with ruby when held to the light.  Larger foamy light tan head that left some lacing and sustained.  Aroma was fruity at first, nutty, caramel, light coffee and hints of milk chocolate.  Flavor of cocoa, toasted malts, some cappucino that lingers, dark fruits and a nice hop bitterness.

Bottle, Pint

About what one would expect from a stout. A little salty aftertaste though. Mild roasted malt taste with just a bit lighter than creamy mouthfeel. Aroma sort of escapes the nose.

Bottle.  Very dark brown tending toward black.  Big fat tan heard.  Nose of roasted malts and chocolate.  Slightly bitter which adds to its character. Very nice and smooth mouthfeel.   While there are stouts with more flavor, more body, and so on, I cant think of one more drinkable.
Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours black with a decent size tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and slight fruit. The flavor is roast, slight coffee, fruit. Good body, good brew.

Dark-dark brown color with creamy mocha head. Aroma is molasses, coffee and burnt malts. Yum, nice malt flavors break right out of the glass: roasted malts, chocolate malts and a pinch of black patent burnt malts. Theres also a Monday morning hot cup of coffee flavor too.
Bottle. Dark brown stout with a thin, pale foam. Not very "heavy", but has a nice roasted aroma and a hint of fruit ? There is a slight bitterness in the finish.

tall, thick, creamy darkish tan head.  blackish brown body with only a glimpse of golden brown at the edges.  columns of lacing.  deep roasted chocolate malt aroma.  mouthfeel is highly carbonated for a stout, but creamy and thin outside of the fizziness.  flavor is dry roasted malt, a little chocolate malt, and some hop bitterness.  interesting "west coast" stout.  bitter and smooth malty finish.
Bottle. 12fl. Dark brown it need´s more color, it is too rosted for that color. and it feel´s fizzy.

12 oz bottle, via slob.  Pours a clear dark mahogany under a fizzy quickly receding beige head.  Some lacing though.  Aroma is fairly light, mostly a burnt and roasted maltiness with a light anise and chalk accent.  Flavor is roasted and burnt malt with a good bit of astringency.  Finishes dry and moderately bitter with some coffee and chalkiness.  Mouthfeel was lighter bodied with a fairly watery texture.  Carbonation is active and fizzy.  Overall, nothing exciting going on here, move along people.

Bottle.  Light roasted malty aroma with sweetish notes.  Dark amber brown color.  Flavor is also roasted malt.  Not overpowering.  Hops are noticable but not overpowering either. Slightly bitter finish. Nothing extraodinary but a very drinkable stout. Good smooth flavor.
12 oz bottle. Smell was a bit sour, odd. The taste seemd very typical, nothing unique. Old rasputin kicks this beers ass.

[bottle @ The Other Side Cafe] Pours a dark brown, nearly black color; not much of a head to speak of. Roasted malt and slight coffee aroma. Slightly sweet, dark malt flavors, with a bit of acidity. Very subtle chocolate notes towards the finish. Pretty nice, overall.

Pours with a frothy, three finger thick, brown tainted, tan colored head the leaves a light lacing pattern on the sides of the glass.  The beer itself is a almost black color with a brownish tint to it.  The aroma smells softly of dark grain and burnt raisins.  A light roast grain tartness hangs around towards the end of the aroma along with black coffee aromatics and heavily toasted malt notes.  In the middle there is a soft, sweet, dark chocolate note that helps to mellow out the other more roasted notes.

The beer starts out soft and creamy with a mouth coating quality to it, but the carbonation quickly adds a zippy note that tends to balance this out.  Finishes with a burnt grain and hop bitterness as well as a black acidity.  Sweetish, dark malt notes intermingle with chocolate and a sweetened espresso character never quite balancing out the dominant dry roasted grain notes.  This beer strikes a light crispness up front despite the color, yet in the finish has a mouth coating creaminess to it that adds to a perception of heft.

All in all this is a great beer to sit down with over a couple pints.  Light and quaffable, yet at the same time chewy and interesting.  If I had to perfect this I would add a touch more chocolate and sweet malt notes to balance the roast acidity, but then it would not be nearly so quaffable.

Purchased: <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Tucson, AZ
Pours a dark black, with a creamy head. To me it tasted very close to Guiness, but I think a bit better. Overall I enjoyed this beer, more than Guiness :)

12-oz. Pours fairly opaque black with a thick, sudsy tan head. Neutral aroma, other than some mild chocolate notes, which is something of a surprise for this brewer tackling this style. Maybe the beers just a wee bit too cold. Big roasty and chocolate flavors, though--not a heck of complexity here, but nice clean finish. Drinkable and satisfying, and not at all a disappointment, but not a beer to move heaven and earth to find.

Smoked malt nose, malt, coffee and chocolate as well, darkest auburn, wears a small tan head. Smoked malt flavour, with a good belt of roast coffee, balanced and nicely bitter. Pleasurable offering. Thank You Radek.

Bottle.
Dark brown with creamy tan top.(4-)
Light creamy, roasty, slightly smoky aroma. Hints of chocolate-coffee.
Medium bodied with coffee roasted character. Medium dark malts dominating.

Pours a slightly thin, somewhat translucent deep ruby brown. Looks almost like a dark ale rather than a Stout. Produces a thick, rocky and long lasting light tan head. No lacing. Mild, but pleasant aromas of charcoal, coffee beans, Bakers chocolate and dark roasted malts. Mouthfeel fairly thin and watery with a slightly fizzy carbonation. Initial flavor is of charcoal and charred malts followed by a balancing subdued malt and toffee sweetness. Some chocolate and coffee notes also come through. Finish is light and thin, but with a pleasant minerally/charred wood dryness. A solid, but kinda lightweight stout.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2006 Deep brown, medium brown head.  Aroma of toasted malts, chocolate, good amount of hops.  Flavor is even more bold, hoppy and roasty, a little dry on the finish.  Very good.  This reminds me of Old Rasputin, a lot, almost like this is his little brother.  If you want to session Old Rasputin but dont want to get wasted, this could do the trick.  Ill be drinking this a lot from now on.
Pours the color of black coffee with a light tan head.  Mild chocolate, coffee and roasted flavor.  Goes down very smoothly.  Pretty light textured stout.   Definitely an enjoyable beer.
Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma is of dark fruit, roasted coffee, and some spice.  Roasted flavor of coffee is apparent along with a slight spicey finish.

Pretty good stout, here.  They did an excellent job of producing a stout that was distinctly different than their flagship beer, but still delicious.  Nice roasty flavor, but a thinner mouthfeel, almost porter-like.

Bottle, Sept 2006.  Dark brown color, with a slight hint of red.  Nice color.  Head was a nice light brown.  A nice roasted and sweet smell.  Taste was a little sweet; main tastes were nutty and light chocolate.  Bitter end, but not too much.  Overall an average stout.
A great stout.  Aroma of chocolate.  Tastes of licorice, seaweed,  roasted malt.  very complete and balanced.  Full bodied but not heavy.
Bottle. Dark brown color with tan head that laced the glass. Roasty aroma with hints of milk chocolate. Flavor is similar, slightly sweet on the tongue. Full bodied. A solid stout.
Dark brown/red with lightbrown head, a little peppery in smell, sweet taste with some fudge, burnt, long bitterness
Dark with a tan head.  Not very malty.  Sort of dry and flat throughout.  Some malt flavors but not with much else.  Straightforward and clean.

A pretty typical stout. I have noticed that North Coast  Brewing Co. is usually not typical about anything. A couple of their brews will slap the shit out of you (Old Stock Ale - Old Rasputin). This is a little more tame. Typical but good.
Pours with dark brown nearly black with a big light brown head. Smells of a sweet coffee. Taste is a roasted nutty flavor with some bitterness at the end.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2007 A nice dark brown stout with a thin, pale foam. Not very "heavy", but has a nice roasted arome and a hint of fruit ?
There is a slight bitterness in the finish.

Bottle from trade with gputty. Pours a dark brown with a medium tan head that lasted most of the beer.  Left some fairly decent lacing. Has a medium body. Aroma of roasted coffee with a hint of cocoa. Taste mildly like dark chocolate with a dry slightly bitter finish.

Quite a dark berr that held its head for a long time.  Nice aroma and really pretty good tasting.  Its a heavy beer and one that would be good from time to time but not so sit and drink it all night long

12 oz bottle.  Dark burgundy brown but not impenetrable.  Big, chunky balsa head.  Sweet molasses and musty basement.  Watery, Bakers chocolate leads to crabapple sourness.  A little carb, and little coffee.  Dry, Elmers glue finish.
12 oz bottle. Garnet with a big tan head. Roasty nose, chocolately. Flavor is malt and bitter chocolate. Solid, albiet one dimensional stout.
dark in color with relatively large tan head.  More carbonation thatn I expected.  Flavros of dark roasted  espresso grounds.  Nice bitternrss.

Pours dark brown with medium, very ice tan head that laces well.  Nose is roast malt and a kind of olive scent I associate with dry stouts.  Bitter coffee flavor moves into a rather spicy middle that reminds me of a Mexican chocolate I once had that contained chilies.  Rather watery mouthfeel, but good bitter aftertaste that lasts some time.  Some herbal hops flavor in the finish, which is a fault for this style.  Overall very drinkable.

Bottled. Pours a dark brown with garnet highligts and a creamy/lacy tan head. The aroma is coffee, chocolate, vanilla and molasses. The body is creamy medium with fine carbonation. The taste much bigger than the nose, with coffee, smoke, roasty malt, vanilla and a hint of dried fruit. Spicy bitter dry finish with a bigger hop presence than many stouts.

Bottled. Brown/rubyish colour with mediumsized brown head. Aroma is raisins, sweet malts and dark chocolate. Roasted malts, toffee and chocolate in flavour. Hops become present in the aftertaste along with roast. OK stout, though its a bit thinpalated.

12 oz bottle (left in bottle while drinknig). Aroma wasnt very intense but the flavor was great-- intense roasted malt, hops and some roasted coffee as well. Not my favorite but I would definately buy this one again.
Pours an opaque black with a quarter-inch dark tan head. Roasted malt in the nose, coffee. Flavor is very dry: roasted barley, coffee with a very smoky bitterness at the end. An enjoyable stout.
Black colour with a brownish mostly lasting creamy head. Aroma and flavour of malts and coffee. nice palate.
12oz Bottle.  Very nice beer.  Aroma is of coffee and roasted barely.  The taste is nice and smooth.  I really wnjoyed this stout.

Bottle at home. Black - off-white head.
Aroma: a little alcohol, coffee, roasted barley, some hop. Taste: Nice smoke, roasted, bitter/sour hop, coffee, chokolate. Aftertaste: Thin, bitter, smoke, burned.

11/05 Hopleaf-10.5oz pour. Nitro pour. Black with 1.5 finger cream/khaki colored head. Aroma is buttermilk, coffee, and sweet dark roasted malt. Mouthfeel is full, but it seems gassy full instead of malty full. Taste is buttermilk, coffee, light milk chocolate, light dark roasted malts-rather unimpressive. Not bad, but certainly nothing special.

Bottle.  The stout poured cola black and settled with a nice large dark tan head.  The aroma was malt and hops.  Flavor was hoppy with a bitter malty aftertaste. As a rule, I prefer sweet stouts.  However, I woulld drink this again and might even choose it over Guiness if those were the only two stouts on tap.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is close to black. Aroma is roast malt and coffee. Taste is coffee and bitter chocolate.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2006 pours black with little head.  aroma of black patent and roasted barley.  light body with flavors of burnt malt and bitter chocolate.  If you compare this to rasputin or not, either way this is a pretty weak stout.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2006 12 oz. bottle.  Pours jet black with a roasty, licorice nose.  Nice tan head with thin head that left a little bit of lace.  Smooth malty, coffee flavor.  A solid stout, although a bit on the thin side.

"I was dissapointed in this, my second North Coast offering. After enjoying Old Raspy so much, I was pumped to try Old No. 38. The stout pours black, with an average sized head. The aromas are of coffee, and burnt malts. The mouthfeel in this stout is definitely too thin. The taste follows the smell, as usual, and the burnt malt overrides most of the flavor. There is some sort of metallic/acidic aftertaste to this one too, which is not at all enjoyable. Back to Old Raspy for me!"

From 12oz Bottle.  Pours a deep, chocolaty brown color with a thick finger of large bubbled, toasty head.  Aroma of burned white toast, a touch of bittersweet chocolate, a splash of vanilla, and a suggestion of dry oak.  Pleasant and well balanced in a classic dry stout sort of way.  The mouthfeel is medium to heavy boied with an initial crispness to the carbonation that gives way to a creamy smack.  More of the toasted, bready malts from the aroma come forward on the palate, along with a whisper of anise.  Final smack of an mild bittersweet mocha espresso with a sprinkle of grassy hops.

Draught - Hog Island Oyster Company- Pier 1 San Francisco.   A nice black, nitro stout, loads of roast coffee toast burt flavours that complemented the oysters really well. Quite hoppy for a stout, something that Im coming to expect with beer here.

Mild malty aroma, a bit on the week side for a stout.  Nice black body witha brown sudsy head with a reddish hue.  Nice crisp nose, a clean malty finish.  Medium to low body, a little too much carbonation.  Another ok stout.
From bottle.  Pours black with a rich light tan head.  Nose is rich, roasted chocolate.  Flavor follows with a touch of bitter.  Body is a little watery, but otherwise a solid, if uneventful stout.

Creates a giant sized head that doesnt die easily. A whole lot of lacing. Color is black or found to be dark brown if examined closely. Nose hints of roasted barely and the flavor is the same with addition of coffee and creamer. An above average stout. This should be more available.
Deep transparent walnut colored body with a decent tan head that laces your glass. Coffee and chocolate mocha aroma. Flavor showed a bittersweet chocolate and coffee with a nice light hoppy bite.

12 oz. bottle
Aroma: Roasted malts and chocolate with berry underneath.  A sugary sweet scent.
Appearance:  A truly beautiful milk chocolate brown with red tinges in color with a head of light beige bubbles that laced and sustained nicely throughout the glass.  I did not think this would be the case after the pour as there was not much head present but I was presently surprised by the final result.  There was a small amount of sediment present that floated and settled but it was not enough to consider as much of a downgrade.
Flavor: Started lightly sweet chocolate and caramel with the roasted malts mingling nicely.
Palate: Medium bodied mouthfeel that finished mildly hoppy and slightly dry that made it a little bitter at the end but pleasant.
Overall: Another nice stout offering from this brewery.  No complaints here and definitely worth enjoying again.

A nice stout, but only that. Poured dark brown-reddish with a tan head on top. The aroma was more coffee than chocolate, but both were present. The flavor started out coffee but turned to a nice choclate touch in the finish, especially as it warmed. There was good old west coast hopping (cascades?), but it was pleasant and appealing and not overdone. Nicely balanced for a stout and the mouthfeel was moderate and not overdone.

Bottle. Dark reddish brown color with thick creamy head. Sweetish aroma with roast barley, berries, coffee, smoke and tar. Also the flavor is sweetish with roast barley and tar-like smokiness. Mild and soft finish with roast barley. Not dry and falls short on roastedness to be a stout, but anyway very tasty.
Bottle.  Pitch black color.  Very roasted malt and chocolate aromas.  Caramel, coffee, and chocolate flavors.

From bottle.  Dark Pour with ruby highlights.  Beautiful 1-inch thick tan, fluffy head.  Nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, barley, and chocolate.  Flavor of chocolate with some sweetness from caramel, and alot of bitterness from the roasted barley.  Fruity notes in the aftertaste, but I cant pin down the flavor.     I had to have this with Tillamook Mild Cheddar to cut through the bitterness.  Thick, chewy mouthfeel.  Full bodied.
Pours dark with offwhite head.  Aroma is of roasted malt and nice hops.  Thin and a little watered down, but great flavor.  Nice smooth beer.  Shows off the roasty malts.
12 oz Bottle-pours a dark brown color w/a tan head-almost looks like a root beer! Kind of hoppy for a stout, has the typical stout roasted aroma & flavor. Long finish. Somewhat Bittersweet.
Aroma slightly sweet and roasty, bitter coffee, with good, dry hops showing up late in the sniff. Pour is very soda-like. Lots of levels of roast in the mouth, very dry and refreshing.

Pours dark black with a small tan head that quckily dissapates.  Aroma was of coffee.  Taste was of bitter coffee beans almost tasted "burnt".  Finish was EXTREMELY dry, like chewing on rubber bands.  Not my thing.

Pours a dark brown, but not quite opaque.  There are red colors beneath a creamy brown head.  The Aroma is a roasty malt, but little else is noticable.  The flavor is roasted malt and a coffee that is not presant in the aroma.  The roastedness leads to a medium finish that has a bit of a creamy feel to it.  Its clean and dry, and the flavors are distinct and noticable.  Its a solid stout, but falls short of a top notch offering because it is only slightly greater than two demensional.

Roasted malts dominate the profile of this beer.  In the nose, and as well as flavor the roasted barley is very evident.  Light malt sweetness balances the sharpness of the roasted malts with a light hop bitterness .  Color is more like a porter in my opinion, but with ruby highlights a very nice color.  A very drinkablt stout.

12 oz bottle  dark brown pour small diminishing head . caramel/coffee aroma . dark chocolate -sour cherries -coffee flavor with a noticable hop bitterness . medium bodied and smooth ..
good stuff
Black color with a light tan head.  Nice lacing.  Light roasted malt-coffee aroma and flavor.  Bitterness is noticeable but not overpowering.  Smooth dry finish.  Medium body.  Good beer.
Bottle. Brown lasting head. Black body. Heavy coffee hops aroma. Smooth coffee flavor and bitterness at the end.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2007 On tap at the Map Room, Chicago: Pitch black color with a nice fluffy tan head. Nice milk chocolate and roasted malt nose. Very sour milky taste - which I found to much for my liking, also coffee beans taste.
UPDATED: APR 9, 2007 Opaque brown color, nitro head. Sour milk in the body, light chocolate. Roasted malt tastes too, with a tobacco end. Lingering coffee bitter. Meidum body. Smooth and reserved.

Very decent appearance.  Dark brown color with tan head.  The flavor is roasted malt, dark chocolate, and cherry with some well done coffee, not quite burnt.  That sour cherry, acidic mouthfeel/flavor always hits me wrong with stouts of any kind.  Very dry on the finish.

A roasty and milk chocolate aroma. The appearance is pitch black with a moderate tan head. The flavor is very dry but also hint of some sour grapes among the big coffee flavors. A decent body on this one. The finish is somewhat bitter with more sour hints. A good dry stout.

The aroma is a balance of sweet and sour with rich undertones of espresso.  It has a delicious dark brown hue with a light brown head to it.  Rich mocha flavors give way to tight long dark bitter chocolate waves.  Despite the richness in flavor the beer remains light and unassuming in the mouth making it very drinkable.  Like a great freshly ground south east asian coffee blend this beer provides both substance and astringent aspects that make it truly delecitble.
It was dark brown in color with a small diminishing head.  There was a lot of carbonation in this beer.  There was a carmel aroma with a smooth coffee / chocholate taste.

This is a dry chocolate-like roasted almond in a bottle with a smooth finish which makes it easily drinkable and tasty at the same time. It reminds me of those coffee beans you get a gourmet coffee drive thrus.

As expected, a dark brown to black color but with a fairly thin light tan head that setles a thick (consistency) tan.  Aroma was coffee like with a slightly sweet tone.  Smooth and very drinkable with more ocffee and lightly sweet flavor and a smooth finish that leaves the palate cleanly.  Very good!
Very Good, mothing speical about this particular stout but it is what it is. A nice malty, toasty and mild coffee with a moderat carbinated taste. Enjoyable.

Bottle. A slightly rushed pour yielded a large tan foamy head that quickly produced a beautifully laced glass. This dark brown brew has a slight red undertone when held to the light. The  aroma is a chocolate with coffee. Soft carbonation with a tiny bit of sweetness to balance the bitterness. I was very pleasantly surprised.

(03.11.06) On tap at Firkins, Libertyville, IL.  Black hued stout with long-lived large creamy tan head. Good lacing. Soft carbonation.  Slight roasted malt aroma.  Medium-bodied stout that starts dry with tiny malt sweetness and chocolate/coffee flavors. Finishes dry with light lingering bitterness. A very good drinkable stout that went well with a popcorn shrimp appetizer.
Solid Stout.  Pours dark brown.  Nice malt and coffee aroma, coffee and malt in the motuh with some decent bitterness as well.  Nice feel in the mouth.  A keeper.

The aroma is just what it should be. There is malt, chocolate, coffee, and nuts. The appearance is super dark brown with a medium, persistent, foamy head. The flavor is bitter but also sweet with plenty of toasted malt and coffee. The palate is what it should be for a stout. The aftertaste is bitter and very coffee like with hints of mocha.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Pours a very beautiful, clear, reddish mahogany with a dense, creamy beige coloured head. Roasted, lightly burned aroma. Medium body with accents of lightly burned malt and a hint of coffee. Light underlying sweetness all the way through. The malts leave quite some bitterness on my palate in the finish. 260206

This is a beautiful pour.  I pushed this one in the glass to reveal that dark head of cream.  This is such a perfect balance of roast coffee that starbucks should carry it.  I am not used to the term dry stout, but the finish is perfect.  Nearly perfect/
Bottle:  Poured dark brown with thick medium lasting head.  Definate chocolate coffee type roasted malts with just enough hop to make it a great beer.

From the bottle.
Pours like a dark cola with little head but beautiful ruby highlights low in the glass. Dark roasted whole grains dominate the nose; the flavor is very dry, with black coffee as the prominant flavor, only the sort of black coffee that you get at hour six of a nine hour flight, having started with less than the best of beans, having been brewed under less than ideal conditions, and having spent three or more hours bubbling away on a hot plate. That said, I do get a decent if subtle hint of raspberry liquor in there as well; I may not want raspberry syrup in my coffee but it complements nicely in this particular beer . The finish is astringent and bitter; the mouthfeel is thin and relatively uninspiring. 
Ive got a lot of respect for the brewery, but Im just not finding much to enjoy in this particular beer.
UPDATED: APR 18, 2006 Bottle. Light blach color with light head. Mild for a stout. And a bit dry with a little oaty taste. A bit to mild for me.

Bottle: Poured a clear light black color stout with a bigger then average creamy off-white head with pretty good retention. Aroma of coffee was pretty intense with some roasted malt. Coffee taste was not as dominant as I would have expected because of the aroma. Body is quite light with low carbonation. Hops level is definitely too low for my own taste. Not bad overall but a bit boring I guess.

Dark brown that transmits just a bit of light, tan head, frothy.  Aromas are nice-of dark chocolate, burnt malt, maybe some molasses.  Flavor is sharp of espresso and charcoal.  A hint of fleeting molasses flavored sweetness in the background.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours dark with a hint of brown. Very hoppy and robust stout. Head is fuller than many stouts. hits a nice balance of bitter and deep.

bottle - Pours black and opaque with a moderate, long lasting head.  It has a pleasant aroma of roast, chocolate malt.  The mouthfeel features light carbonation and a medium body.  Flavors of roast malt with coffee and chocolate notes are apparent followed by a moderately bitter, lingering finish.  Kudos to North Coast.  This is a nice stout.

Pours a black color,but not pitch black like some of the imperial stouts, with a medium sized beige head.  Aroma is malty with slight hints of roasted coffee and chocolate.  Taste is much like the aroma, malty with weak coffee and chocolate flavor.  Good stout, but not great.
On Draught.  Deep blackish color with nice frothy head.  Sweet smelling and tasting.  Quite hoppy which was evident from the bitterness.  I enjoyed and will have it again.

12oz bottle.  Dark ruby red with a medium sized tan head.  Muted chocolate and roastiness in the aroma.  Bittersweet chocolate flavors, bolstered by a vanilla character.  Husky astringency in the finish with a lingering bitterness.  Mouthfeel is light medium, rather dry.
Plenty of roast but still manages to have some sweet cream and vanilla flavors.  Not particularly dry and a bit light-bodied, but certainly not bad.

Dark but not motor oil-dark like some others; medium, frothy head.  Aroma shows vanilla, some coffee, some chocolate, and quite a bit of roastiness.  Flavor somewhat flat and one-dimensional, most notably of roast and coffee; some chocolate and vanilla do peek through, though.  Too thin for the style, but moderately sticky.  Good but roastier than I really like.

12 oz. bottle shared by jerc. Translucent dark brown colour with a mostly diminishing frothy off-white head. Soft cocoa, light citurs, and coffee aroma. Roasted coffee, light chocolate, some citrus flavours. Light to medium bodied, smooth, but not really stout-like.

Old No. 38 Stout pours to a beautiful, deep ebony color, with a creamy tan head, and a moderate carbonation. The nose is just packed with big stout aroma. Coffee, roasted barley, chocolate malt, and some piney hop aromas flood the nose. The palate is firm with lots of good dark malt flavor. Very vibrant and robust flavors of coffee, dark chocolate, roast, and some nice fruity estery flavors coat the tongue. This beer finishes with more chocolate malt character up front, then ends with a very long, dry, roasty, and piney hop bitter finish. 

This is an exceptional domestic version of an Irish classic. Without a doubt one of the best domestic versions of this style being brewed today. This beer would work well with a number of dishes. Stout and shell fish are a natural together. I would pair this beer with lobster, crab, clams, mussels, or scallops. This would also make a wonderful desert beer. Try it with chocolate layer cake, or chocolate pudding.

Bottled.  Pours very dark brown with some dark ruby colored hues.  Small, light tan head when poured from about 4 inches above the glass.  Fades quickly with some lacing.  Chocolate malt aromas with a bit of toffee and coffee.  Roasty flavors with a bit more of the chocolate flavors, also a bit of plum flavor.  Finishes dry.
Dark black nice creamy almost tan head that left lacing. Big dark chocolate and coffee flavor along with some roastiness, and very smooth.

A frothy white head forms on the penetrable black pour.  Chocolatey, espresso notes fill the aroma, but unfortunately they are tainted by a plasticy undertone.  The body is well anchored with a coffee roastiness, but comes off a bit thin in the middle.   The coffee subsides to a nutty finish that also carries the plastic taste.  Infection?  Need to try again because this did show promise.
"A nice beer. pour a brown/red with a nice tan head. Smelled of coffee and chocolate. Tasted of coffee and choclate and a little hop to this one. Mouthfeel was well balanced."

Bottle, courtesy of Jacob Lövenlund. Black brown, thin off white head and low condition. Pleasantly buttery with some sweet coffee and gentle liquorice in the nose, solidsweet chocolate, coffee, liquorice and roasted barley in the mouth. Dry bitterness in the finish with Roast barley and coffee notes lingering longest.
Bottled. Dark reddish-brown with a tan head. Chockolate, coffee and a light fruitiness in the aroma. Coffee-dominated flavor. Light dry finish. A lovely stout. (060113)

The bottle poured a clear dark garnet colored beverage with a medium sized creamy tan head that was mostly lasting and left good lacing on the glass. The aroma was a complex mixture of dark chocolate, roasted malt and wet charred oak. There was also a note of sweet dried plum in the background. The body was medium-full with lively, sharp carbonation and a slightly watery texture. The flavor started off moderately bitter but dissipated quickly leaving only a hint of bitterness. The finish was long, dry and lightly bitter.
Pours black with a foamy tanned head. Smells of roasted malts. Aroams of burnt malts and coffee with caramel and vanilla. Medium- to thin bodied. Sour finish with hints of coffee.

On Tap at Bitter Creek Ale House:  Dark with a slight red tint and no head to write of.  Charcoal and coffee grounds is what this is all about.  It has a thin body and seems to be lacking something.  I expected a bit more from North Coast.
Bottle. deep dark brown ith a perfect tan head.  Brown sugar malt raisin alcohol wafting off.  Extremely smooth wood coffee chocolate. Would drink this again in a snap.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2006 January 2006 Bottle from Premier in Buffalo. Very dark brown - black body with a small khaki head. Very roasty almost smokey aroma. Malty foundation to a moderate roast, slightest notes of chocolate. Average palate. Much better than previous sample. 7/3/6/3/13

January 2006 Bottle at Brewnosers meeting. Very dark brown, small beige head. (3+) Sweet malty aroma, with very slight notes of roast. Flavour and palate are a bit thin with just a big of malt and muted roast. Surprisingly bland. Average to thin palate. A dissappointment. 5/4/5/3/10

35,5 cl bottle. No yeast in bottom. Black colour with a nice creamy head. Nice aroma of roasteness, chocolate, sweetness and hints of hops. Nice tasty flavour of roastness and coffee like, ends up with a bitter and long taste.

12 oz. bottle.  Big frothy caramel head, very dark ruby-almost black. Ttoasty malts, chocolate, and semisweet chocolate come through in the aroma.  The chocolate is stronger than the coffee in taste--not really picking up any hops in this beer, as some others have noted.  A little bitter in the finish, yes, but no hops.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Sampled from bottle.  Pours dark, chocolate brown with a creamy tan head and nice lacing.  Aroma is subtle roasted malt with some pepper and fruit notes.  Flavor is slightly bitter with coffe and chocolate.  Quite dry in the finish.  Medium-full body.  Enjoyable, easy to drink stout.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2006 Pours a deep dark brown (almost black) with a small tan head that disappeared quickly.  Aromas of chocolate, coffee, and something burnt or roasted.  Flavor was a nice coffee, bitter chocolate, with a touch of hops at the finish.
12 oz bottle-pours a thick, rich, rocky brown head with black color.  Aroma is malt, alcohol, sweet.  Taste is malt, coffee.  Good middle of class, not my style.

Highly anise-like nose of roasted malts, torrefaction, dry nuts. Lasting light tan head morphs quickly into a sticky cover. Not opaque, but black appearance. Restricted lactic touches are adequately hiding behind a generous herbal hop dose. Burnt wood notes emanate through the almost smokey, simple malts, while the citric bill grows up to becoming dominant in the aftertaste. Hesitating texture, not very firm light-medium body. Robust flavored still.

Dark black-brown coloured beer with a nice intens beige creamy head. aroma is soft coffee like with touches of raisins, figgs and black chocolate. The beer has some slight herbal touches and some hints of mint in the nose. Taste is medium dry and has outspoken hints of coffee, burned malts, black chocolate, some dried fruits and hints of refreshing herbs like sage and fresh mint. No the greatest of stouts, but a desent medium dry example. Aftherteste is wel ballanced and has a fine elegance for the style.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Walleye, Thanks Jim.  dark brown with a tan head fading quickly to some spotty lace.  aroma is of dark roasted malts, barley amd coffee.  flavor is pretty much more of the same with some dry hop bitterness on the finish.  a nice dry stout.

12z bottle.  Dark black body with a spotty tan head.  Good raisin chocolate nose.  Sweet nose with coffee and toffee.  Flavor is big in the mouth but the body is a little less.  Nice and bitter, but its still a little too chilled.  Nice bitter chocolate and coffee flavors.  Nice finish with a good dose of hops.
An ok stout. Dark / black colour. Fine, soft head. Aroma mainly with burnt notes. Flavor dry and burnt. A bit thin.
light roasted aroma.  dark but not black.  tan head.  roasted coffee flavor.  sort of milky.  not as dry as expected.  not bad.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2006 Pours dark brown with ruby tint, small tan head that quickly diminishes. Aroma is dry, roasted barley with some chocolate notes. The flavor is very dry, roasted, coffee, some dark chocolate. Finish is medium length and dry.

I didnt expect anything more than a Guinness clone, but this one surprised me with some original character.  Roasted flavors and a medium to full body, this is no Rasputin, but still tasty in its own right.
Dry beer that is malty but not sugary or sweet really.  Nice bitter touch at the tail and not to overpowering or fullbodied.  Excelllent Stout!

Pours a very dark brown/black color body with a bubbly tan head.  Subtle roasted aroma.  Sweet malty taste with some roasted malts and a dry finish.  Somewhat metallic aftertaste.  Very well-done, easy to drink stout.  Nothing really special, though.

A nice stout.  Like the Rasputin (one of my top 10 favorites) except with lower alcohol and a little less in the way of malts.  This was a good beer to round out the world beer festival in Durham with (#47 for me).
UPDATED: NOV 5, 2005 Dark brown/black, disappointing small brown head. Aroma of roasted malts and caramel. Medium full with flavors of coffee and dark chocolate leading to a dry finish.

Chocolate a roast jump right out of the glass.  Just looking into the dark abyss of this beer, you know you are in for something good.  The ehad on mine did not last long and the bubbled were large, but the flavor was assertive.  Massively roasty and thick, I can only drink one, wel maybe two if ya twist my arm.  Certainly not for beginners.

On tap at the Hop Leaf.  Jet black with a giant foamy head that begs to have a bottle cap or two float on it.  Looked great but did not live up. Very smooth and creamy.   Seemed to lack distinctive flavor.
12oz bottle. Pours black with a light tan head. Nose is dry, dark fruit, but not very much of anything really. Taste is very dry and thin. Very bland and lacking much of anything.
Black. Not much to say. Very dry, and very carbonated, make tis somewhat interesting. Not huge in the flavor department, but still a good session stout.

how the hell have i not rated this, ive had it before, this I know for fact. Well, its very black with a light tan head. Very smokey and nutty, really reminds me of a porter. Very smoked in the flavor, just like some scorched malts. A session stout I must say.

Bottle:  Courtesy of MikeMac.  Aroma has lots of chocolate, light fruit, and a hint of roastiness.  Pours brown, but its virtually transparent.  Since when is a stout transparent?  Insignificant white head.  Flaovr is a slightly watered down chocolate and fruit up front.  Finishes with roasted coffeee.  Thin mouthfeel.  Outside of aroma, lacking in expectations for a stout in all categories.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2005 Bottle. Pours thick dark brown with a hint of red.  Aroma of licorice and toasted coffee and nuts. Dry palate with flavors of coffee and smoke, some bitter chocolate. Light and dry but not thin.

Thanks Chuck!  Pours to a really dark brown body a red tint when held to the light.  There is a beige head and decent lacing.  The aroma is nutty and dry roasted coffee.  The flavor is a charcoaled coffee.  Not too shabby.  The palate is dry with a medium mouthfeel.  Charcoal like feel.

dark pour small tan head well laced.  roasted malt aroma along w/ some bittersweet chocolate and touches of barley.  Pal is pretty avg.  Flavor is a dry lightly bitter chocolate some roasted malts Fairly light and dry but a decent stout.
Textbook stout. Black body with a small head. Aroma is roasty with coffee and hits of chocolate. Flavor is the same, slightly bitter. Easy fast drinking.

Serviceable pleasant stout, with roast in nose. Dark black, roasted barley and chicory and some sourness in finish, and chocolate bar sugar and bit of chocolate malt. No complaints with this brewery. Medium mouthfeel, with biscuit crumbs. Dry aftertaste.

Deep walnut brown in the glass with little head and no lacing.  Aromas are dusky: tobacco, chocolate, caramel.  A little tart at first, and then pallid on the tongue, but with full stout flavors.  Nice chocolate cake profile.  Lacking a little in mouthfeel and complexity, but a nice simple stout.
Black color with a small light tan head. Very distinct roast coffee aroma and taste. Thinner body than some other stouts. A good beer.

Dark brown with a creamy khaki colored head. Coffe aromas complimented by a  floral hop note. Dry with no noticeable sweetness. Aftertaste is slightly bitter, some malt sweetness. Taste is a little thin for a stout, but still not bad.

Aroma was malt, smokey, and oakish.  Taste is very toasty and malty, with some heavily roasted coffee flavors.  The roasted flavor lingers for quite a while.  Hops are also evident here as well.  Nice

Bottle. - Roasty, slightly smoky nose.
The taste is dominated by a roasty, dry and oaky body, which is prolonged by a welladjusted hoppiness.
Black with an off-white head. Aroma of oak, licorice and burned toffee. Intense flavour with lots of bitterness and roasted character. Thin-ish, watery mouthfeel.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy & tupalev - courtesy of HogTownHarry. Very dark brown with ruby highlights and a small mocha head. Sweet, roasty aroma - lots of coffee, a little chocolate and smoke - with tingly hops around the edges. Flavour starts nice and roasty, and then the hops kick in, reminding you that youre drinking an American west coast stout. The body is thinner than I like in my stouts, and I wouldve liked the roastiness to hang around on the palette a bit longer before the hops took over, but all in all, its a pretty fine beer.
Why would anyone have a Guinness when they can drink this beer?  Great dark color with a thick tan head.  Burnt chocolate aroma with matching flavor.  Bittersweet and smoky, incredible combination.

Shared with blankboy, GregClow and Harry - courtesy of Harry.  Now this is a change to our Quebec micro night! Strong lovely sweet roasted barley aroma.  Burnt chocolate malt as well.  Dark brown pour, thick big white head.  Taste is heavy on the dark malt and roast side.  Medium bodied (almost milk like) - smooth silky stout mouthfeel.  Some hoppiness in here as well - more than a "normal" dry stout, but it didnt overwhelm me like it did to others that tried it.  Only complaint - just a touch more body necessary to make this even better.  As is, I enjoyed this tremendously, much more than the Old Rasputin which let me down.  Beer of the night.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a clear dark amber with a small frothy tan head. Aroma of sweet malt, chocolate, hops, alcohol and caramel. The flavour: wowza! Fabulous flavour of hops, dark roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and caramel. I loved it!

Bottle. Pours a deep brown with a thin tan head. Chocolate / mocha aroma. Chocolate / coffee / smoky flavor. Good carbonation. Flavors not too much, nor too little. Bit of bitters in aftertaste. Again, another fine offering from North Coast. Not as strong as Old Rasputin, but a great showing, and worth a try. And if you ever get a chance to rent a car and drive between Willits and Ft Bragg, I highly recommend it. The Redwoods are awesome, and making rental car tires squeal in the plentiful twisties is great. :-)
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: AUG 21, 2005 Bottle (12oz). Shared with blankboy, GregClow and tupalev - bottle from me.  Poured a clear middling dark brown with an average light tan foamy head.  Aroma starts off with a healthy hit of hops, then tons of dark roast malt, very bitter chocolate, coffee beans, peat smoke, alcohol and leafy yeastiness.  Flavour is VERY hop-bitter, after the hop-shock wears off, the dark roast malt enters, with bakers chocolate, black coffee, vanilla bean and roast chestnuts.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied and the bitterness dominates, would be more balanced and complex if they upped the malt some, or dropped the hops;  still very good and recommended.
Bottle. Pours dark amber with a big head. Sweet aroma with alcohol in it. Mild coffee flavor with a nutty finish. Good, but not outstanding.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2005 12oz bottle.  Very dark almost black beer with a nice but small tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma of sweet chocolate.  Flavor is creamy bittersweet chocolate and coffee.  Dries out some on the finish to a long roasty bitterness.  Smooth mouthfeel with a nice medium body.  A bit of cola.   Very Nice.  I like this.  $7.99 for a six pack at Broudys, Jacksonville, FL.  Excellent.

Light aroma of chocolate in the begining. On the finsh got a burnt wood roast aromas. Black body and tan head. Flavor was of chocolate, roasty malts and somewhat creamy. Roasted chocolate aftertaste a decent brew here.
bottle. Typical stout appearance, thats not a bad thing. The flavor is pretty straight-foward with a full body and roasted notes. The finish has definite coffee notes and lingers just long enough.
Toasted aroma with chocolate and coffee. Flavour is toasted too with notes of chocolate and cocoa ending in a long, dry finish. Definitely, a nice bitter stout.

On nitro-tap at La Cave Du Vin in Cleveland

Pours an opaque black with a huge, dense, creamy, tan head. Tons of lacing. The aroma is bitter but also milky, kind of like a sweet latte.

Taste is much like the smell. Bitter latte, dark chocolate, creamy, milky flavors. The nitro left it creamy and smooth (took it forever to settle btw). An easy drinker for sure but very full flavored. A well-crafted straightforward stout. You replace all the nitro Guinness taps with this stuff and you might have world peace or something.

Very dark pour with a decent beige head and some lace.  Lots of chocolate and roasted malts in the aroma with some PNW hops as well.  Lots of coffee in the flavor with agood hop bitterness.  Medium bodied and a good smooth finish.  Didnt seem to finish too dry- I would consider more of a regular stout than a dry stout.

Bottled.
Dark brown coloured with a beige head.
Roasted aroma with notes of chocolate and coffee.
Roasted flavour of chocolate and coffee with notes of dried fruits.
Dark brown/black. Creamy, tan head. Roasted malt and chocoffee aroma. Same flavor, dry. Medium/full body. Coffee aftertaste. Nice lacing. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2010 Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer pours a very dark brown color with a medium sized dark brown head. The aroma is strong with smoky and roasted malts and a faint hint of cocoa. The flavor is dry and very roasty with an almost smoky undertone, bakers chocolate and a slightly grainy finish. The dry graininess lingers on the tongue long after the beer has passed.Full bodied.

Bottle: Dark brown, nearly black, large light beige foamy head, attractive lacing. &nbsp Combination of cocoa, dark chocolate, and hops on the nose. &nbsp Semi-sweet cocoa start, soft bitterness mid palate, finishing with roasted malts. &nbsp Moderate body, medium mouthfeel that I wished was a bit bigger. &nbsp Nothing special or unique, but solid nonetheless.

Bottle. Brownish/black hue with medium head. Full aroma chocolate and roasted coffee. Medium to full body with creamy texture. Medium flavor much the same as aroma with a medium bitter finish. Good  everyday drinkalbe stout.

Clear dark reddish brown with a solid brown head. Chocolate, roast and some sourness with some muskiness in the aroma. Roasty, acrid, sweet and somewhat chalky flavor. Spritzy carbonation.  Full, bitter finish. To my chagrin, this has been pulled from my market but I found one stashed away.
A very good stout, but somehow leaves something desired compared to something like the 8 ball stout or old rasputin.  If the slight wateryness was corrected this could be an excellent brew.
THIS WAS A PRETTY GOOD STOUT.  DARK RED/BROWN.  HAD A NICE CARMEL AND COFFEE TASTE WITH A BITTER AFTERTASTE, BUT WAS A LITTLE THIN.

Very dark almost black with lasting, creamy head. Slight sting to the otherwise coffee like aroma.
Flavour dominated by dark, burnt malt and coffee.
Fills the mouth nicely with a very soft and pleasant palate.
Not quite spectacular but very, very close.

Black, beige tall lasting head. Sweet aroma. Roasted malts. Coffee, chocolate. Powerfull flavour with intente licorice flavour. Coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, smoke. Some underlying malty sweetness. Dry bitter long lasting finish. Overall excellent, just excellent.
Enjoyed this one from the bottle.  Poured black with a nice, thick tan head.  This is a good example of a solid stout - my favorite beer style!

Poured nearly black with a thick brownish head.  Cocoa color pretty much sums it up.  Well said.  Smell had a roasted coffee and chocolate smell.  Dark chocolate specifically.  Good bitter coffee and chocolate taste.  The palate was solid with a good bitterness.  A bit thin though.  Very nice chocolate finish.  The finish was actually my favorite taste even though the whole thing was good.  North Coast seems to always be solid.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2005 Pours black with a light cocoa-colored head. Lots of bubbles in the head. Sweet smelling with hints of toasted malt and coffee.
Very thick mouthfeel, with initial taste of coffee and dark chocolate. Ends with a roasted malt finish, which is quite dry.
Smells sweeter than it is, but this is much better than Guiness with a lot more flavor. A good stout, but nothing to shout about.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2006 Nice roasty aroma with touches of bakers choclate. Pours very nice. Bif fluffy mocha head atop an ebon body. Really a VERY impressive head. Great flavors of tosted malt, coffee and dark choclate. Much too thin for a stout. Great flavors and looks, but the moutfeel is thinner than some porters. Still something Id happily drink at any resteraunt or bar if I found it among a limited lineup. Solid, but not perfect.
A fairly dark color, though not as opaque as some. Thin head and aroma of coffee and malt. A little too malty and strong on the coffee flavor. It is missing the creaminess of many dry stouts.

Hoppy and beautiful in color and smell.  There is no particularly exciting about this beer (as compared to other stouts).  Nevertheless, I love stouts, and this could be used as a basis for what a solid stout should be.
Bottle. Malty coffee aroma. Almost black colour, small creamy head. Creamy mouthfeel. Quite bitter, not sweet or malty. It tastes a bit like malt bitterness, not to my liking.
Aromas of burntness and coffee.Poured black with a thin lacing tan head.Heavy tastes of coffee and roasted nuts.The finish had me tasting coffe for 30 minutes but that was ok.

A 12 oz. bottle sampled 05/26/05. The coal-fueled train imagery is fairly apt -- theres a distinctive burnt charcoal taste on the front end, and some remarkable bitterness & acidity at the tail.  Wish there was a bit more substance in between, though.  Quirky, but enjoyable.
Bottle. Blackish color with a beige head. Big roasty aroma with toasted grains. Light bodied. Astringent and burnt grains.
Bottle. Black colour with a small baige head. Light roasted coffee chocolat aroma and a roasted dry coffee taste. Medium body and a very dry finish.

Bottle from wayne valley wines. Poured very dark, with a very small tan head, not much lacing either. Aroma of chocolate and sweet dark fruits. Finished smooth and left a lingering sweet after taste. Strang, for a dry stout.

Bottle. Dark stout with a light brown head. The aroma is ok, dark chocolate and coffee mostly. Full bodied beer that feels nice in the mouth. The roasted flavours are dominant, and the finish is rather long and with lots of coffee. Balance between malt and bitterness is really good.

almost black colour, little irregular foam but a beautiful lacing, slightly toasted aroma of black chocolate, notes of coffee also, good malt body and a solid bitterness, long roasted coffeish finish with more notes of chocolate and peanut butter

Not the blackest stout around - dark reddish.
Roasted aroma: Chocolate and coffee. And a tiny bit of hops. 
Nice long finish.
Dark brown colour with a light brown head. Rather sweet aroma with chocolate notes. Flavor has a blend of chocolate and coffee notes, actually its quite sweet. Finish is fairly dry.

Pours black with a tan head that is not thick enough to be a stout.  Malt aroma but not strong for a stout either.  It is smooth tasting some chocolate and malt.  A little light on the palate and somewhat smokey on the finish.  Not bad but for a stout there are much better choices.
Black as night pour with a light brown head.  No lacing.  Aroma is remiscent of fruits.  Medium mouthfeel....sweet, malty front end with a chocolatey back end.
Bottle. Artificial charcoal taste on the back of the finish ruined this one for me.  I dont know why youd reach for  this instead of the Old Rasputin.
Nice flavor, not overpowering, quite smooth, nice mellow aftertaste, pretty good, a nice change from the heavy alc stouts Ive had recently.
Overall, not bad, but i was drunk when I drank this so take my statement for what its worth.

Pours dark brown with a small off white head. Coffee and cream aroma. Taste is creamy as well, with hints of coffee. A nice hop kick for an aftertaste. An extremely well made beer. Ive never had a bad one from North Coast.
Looks like petroleum...tastes really dark...it is soo dark...Im just not into it.  If you like it really dark, this is the place to go.  Deep coffee and malt.

Pours very dark ruby with thick beige and slightly bubbly head. Light comes through the glass some and lace sticks all down the sides. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, malt. Taste of cocoa powder, coffee, and lightly buttery. Very roasty. Light salty and bitter finish.  It tastes much thinner than it looks. Not a bad brew.

2004 bottle at the Downtown liquors Stout tasting, 3/10/05.  Dark brown colored body, nearly opaque and low carbonation to boot.  Lightly creamy head is an ashen-beige color, low retention.  Smells of sticky, salty toffee and caramel, light peanuts and chocolate as well.  Flavor shows off more caramel and chocolate, with a good chewy malt texture, no carbonation interuption.  But the body is a bit thin, even for a dry stout (and this isnt all that dry).  Hops are quite apparent, though not overdone, and impart a floral, almost minty bitterness (mint flavored hot chocolate anyone?), with a light, sticky resin note as well.  A tinge of sourness coming from somewhere and Im not getting all the intense coffee that everyone else mentions.

Dark brown color; thick creamy head. Nice aroma: coffee, nutty, hop. Quite balanced taste, with a strong roasted malt character and coffee, a lot of caramel, very light liquorice; unfortunately its also a bit metallic. Very strong final bitterness.
Pours black with thick dark head.  Aroma is a combination of roasted chocolate beans.  Taste was chocolately over-all with a roasted finish.
Bottle @ room temp. Black with bigbubbled head. Very faint aroma of some roast and light fruityness. Flavor is roasted, bitter and dry. Pretty good, but a bit onedimensional.
Roasty malt aroma, coffee, sweet, vanilla and chocolate. Dark brown body with a ruby tint, big fluffy off-white head. Roasty flavor, good bitterness in the end. Very smooth.

Bottle: Pours a very dark ruby colour, almost black. Long lasting off-white head. Has a roasted malt aroma with hints of cofee and chocolate. A bit weak in the taste. But you have the roasted taste and some coffe flavor too. Has a little bitter aftertaste. This is an other good beer from NCBC.

I love their Imperial Stout, but this one seems a little weak on almost every level.  Not bad, but not assertive enough for me.  Nice roasted malt flavor, but a little lacking in creaminess and mouthfeel.  Also, kind of lacking in the finish as well.  But again, a very decent drink.

Deep dark ruby (near black).  Aroma of an aged english strong ale (oily, yellow, sherry). Touch of dark roast coffee and clover honey.  Perfectly balanced mouthfeel with light finish. Mellow afterbite of sourness and hops.  A bit shallow in the body flavor (robustness) department, but I suppose thats part of the "dry" in the dry stout nomenclature.  I really love the Rasputin from these guys, and I am starting a serious (nearing monogamous) relationship with the sweet lipgloss left by this tasty brew.

Pours a dark brown color, small off white head. Aroma is lots of roasted coffee, chocolate.  Flavor is smooth and roasted. More of the above mentioned, with lots of malt sweetness to it. Very nice! Thanks to Pdee for the bottle!

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 [12 oz. bottle] Dark brown pour with a very thin brown head. Rich coffee and roasted. Malt aroma. Flavor is pretty much the same. roasted and toasted malts with a nice malt and barley backbone and a slightly bitter coffee finish. Good stout.

Typical American harsh stout. Ok roasted malt flavor and aroma ... inherent to any stout, but there is little else that can be said about this brews flavor. Overall its more than ok but in the end I prefer the smoother, more complex European varieties.
Very dark brown with a medium lasting tan head. Toasted with some coffee. Quite bitter finish.

As dark a brown as you can get without turning black, this stout sports a hefty and sustained, soapy light brown head.  Nice aroma of dark malts and roasted barley and coffee.  Creamy in the mouth, the roasted flavors carry through smoothly finishing on a slightly bitter coffee note.  Good for breakfast.
Bottle. Black with small tan head. Full flavored stout with creamy mouthfeel. Finishes quite bitter.

bottle from secret santa...semi-transparent deep mahogany color with a medium light tan head.  Heavy roasted malt aroma, chocolate malt, some coffee.  Smells yummy.  Roasty, choco-bitter to start, some sweetness.  Decent mouthfeel, a little thin and not as black as I would expect.  Viscosity seems ok, decent lacing.  Overall a good stout, nothing to differentiate it from a lot of others.

Black Coloring with Tan Head.  Nice Roasts Aroma...Small Hints of Chocolate.  On the Tongue....Nice Malt Presence..Good Roasts...But Not a Balanced Coffee Hit...Would Agree That its Bitter and Sweet on its Way Down Your Throat.  Overall a Very Good Stout...Not Quite as Balanced as I Would Have Liked.
Like an oatmeal stout.  black with little head.  Pleasant toasted herbal flavors.  Medium body.

Nice looking dark brown with a nice little creamy head. Good balanced toasty flavor with a perfect hop bite, and a hint of cocoa.
Furthermore it was a dry, robust flavor that really lit up the taste buds. 
Unlike any beer I have ever had. Normally, beer gets easier to drink as you drink more. - The first one was great. 2nd good. 3rd ok...6th I didnt like at all. In conclusion Id say drinkability was poor, and this is one of the oddest beers ive tried or reviewed.

12 oz bottle: pours with a tall, off-tan, cloud-like head that diminishes into a thin, though thick, melted ice cream layer.  Plum garnet.  Large roasted coffee with some cocoa, plums, toasted nuts, grain and light bitter hops.  Very clean palate, with a slight coffee stickiness, but does play on the border of watery.  Flavours are decent mixture of bitter hops, roasted dark grains and bitter milk chocolate truffles.  Slight fruity sourness in the finish, a pretty good effort.

Pours damn near jet black with just a little crimson on the bottom edges.  Medium sized, very creamy head.  For a beer out of a bottle and no widget, it looks a hell of a lot like a cask beer, only without the cascading effect.  Slightly bitter coffee aroma with some malt.  Its a strange mix of bitter and sweet.  That continues on into the taste.  It fights back and forth between being dry and/or bitter, versus a sweet kick.  Good coffee and roasted barley, both in amounts that let you know they are there but not so much that its all you taste.  Damn fine stout, a new favorite!

12.26.04  12oz bottle.  Black pour with sticky tan head and glowing highlights.  Burnt toast and coffee aromas followed by more roast, dry and sharp flavors.  Not much bitterness where it seems like there should be and the beer is sort of nutty when Im expecting earth/dirt notes.  Its good, but not what I was hoping for.

Pours near black, some brown creeping through the edges, small beige head.  Leaves good lacing. Aroma toasted and smokey, coffee.  Rich roasted flavor, with an even balance of roasted coffee and toasty malts, some creamy chocolate tones break in at first, then give way.  Very dry, and very easy going down.  Daddy likes.

Color is completely black, with a fine, creamy tan head. Aroma is largely roasted, espresso notes, nutty, some hints of chocolate. Very toasty and warm. Palate is smooth, and very, very dry. Finish is brief. Altogether, a solid and tasty, no-frills stout. Perfect for effortless drinking, and Id take one over a Guinness any day.

Bottle poured BLACK with a small but creamy head.Heavy aroma of chocolate,and toasty roasty!
Medium body, creamy roasty taste.. Very Very good.. maybe a little to watery for a stout of my liking,but good!
Not as strong as I would have liked, but it still quenched my thirst.  There are better examples of the style out there, but this one is still respectable.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: I though this was very good. It poured to a redish black color but taste wasnt over powering. Medium brownish head. It was a little more bitter than I would have liked it. The aftertaste was that of coffee. I would recommend it to anyone.

Bottle  Pours a nearly black, reddish brown, with a tall foamy pale light brown head.   Aromas of toasted malts and a slightly dry bitter note.  Flavors are quite bitter and dry.  Slightly sour.  Dark roast, charcoal andsome coffee.  Feel is a bit thin and the carbonation is somewhat soft.   Bitter,sharp aftertaste

Pours a brilliant dark ruby brown color, minimal head and lacing. Faint roasted hop aroma, black cherry. Almost medium bodied, some roasted malts, berry, ash, earth, metals, hints of dark chocolate. Dry and mildly bitter finish. Like most stouts, improves as it warms. Thin mouthfeel dragged this down a bit, but still a good beer.

Bottle.  From Sampler pack.  Cool little stubby bottle.  Nice and dark pour with decent head that lingers.  Dark and ruby colored with a nice actually somewhat earthy nose.  Malts and some coffee flavor early, but doesnt last like the great ones.  A different stout with not as much mouthfeel as some, but still a quality beer.
Pours a dark color. Not super dark for a stout though. Aroma is of roasted malts and sweet chocolate, with maybe some coffee too. Roasted and malty up front, with a bitter kick at the end. Darn good.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2005 Very, very dark body, but  a little light comes through and is a dark amber. thin slightly tan head. Aroma is potatoes, caramel and milk chocolate. the taste is slightly like cooked green beans with some roasted coffee in the finish. Slightly thin mouthfeel. A solid stout, but nothing spectacular. I like this as an everyday stout.
Pours dark brown with slight tan head which disappears quickly.  Nose is chocolate, mild coffee and licorice.  Very robust flavor with nice blend of maltyness and chocolate.  Finishes a bit dry.

12 0z. Bottle.  Poured a very dark brown color, which had a very chocolate nose.  The taste was of chocolate and coffee and were very well matched.  I would definitely try this again, except I am stopping drinking tomorrow!
Black body with a light brown head. Nice but rather weak aroma of coffee and roasted malt. Coffee flavor with notes of malt, fruit and hops. Nice and easy.

12 oz bottle: 
Pours black with a thin brown head.
Has a very nice aroma with a rich roasted coffee flavor.
Pours black with a brown head.  Aroma is coffee and smokiness.  Flavor is dominated by a coffee flavor, with hints of smokiness.  Watery body, uncomplex.  A disappointment after Old Rasputin.
This one was too dark for my liking, it did not have that smoothness through and through.  Definitely a note of coffee and roasted malt, but uncomplex body makes it jagged going down.  Simply okay.
Clear deep ruby/brown with a beighe head. Brown sugar and milk chocolate nose. Burnt and fruitty. Traces of smoke. Tastey, but thin and lacking in appearance.  Good flavour and aroma saved it.

clear dark bronw with ruby highlights, off white head.  brown sugar, chocolate milk, burnt raisins and slightly smoky aroma.   flavour is quite roasty with mocha notes, tarts raisiny flavours too.  finish is nutty and roasty.  ncie stout

Dark brown, almost black, with a small tan head. Big coffee like aroma. Flavor was a little sweet, nutty, and chocolate and coffee notes were the main thing here. Finish left a little quick, but it was an enjoyable stout.

Pours a dark brown. The head is white, creamy and mostly diminishing. Lacing is spiratic.

Toffee, dry chocolate, cocoa and very roasty in the nose.

Although I am not the biggest fan of dry stouts this is still quite delicious for the style. Wispy flavors of roasted malts and coffee in the flavor which I have come to know as the flavors for the style. Chocolate and toffee are present in the flavor profile as well.

This is a solid and pretty full-bodied dry stout but it just is a little to weak for me.

Pour is black with a thick and very creamy looking head.  The aroma is of mild coffee.  The texture is smooth and exceptionally creamy.  The flavor is also of mild coffee and roasted malt.  Goes down smooth and creamy.  Great stuff.

Bottle. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Those same flavors - combined with  rich roasted malts - predominate the flavor. Finish is quick and dry with a nice hop bite. Very good but Id like it to be a bit more complex.
A nice creamy head sits on a dark brew.  About standard for its style. Smooth going down, the aftertaste disappeared quickly. Good but not memorable

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2004 very light color for a stout,but the aroma and flavor is all there.very good stout for sure.it was a favorite of mine for a while.still very good.
re-rate:i got a bottle of this in the "winter brew" back.after having loads of other stouts i must say its still really good.nice roasted chocolate taste.i think ill up the rating a bit.

Stout colored.  Deep brown, low co2 and a light brown head.  Head retention is good and the lacing is slippery.  Aromas are roasty with some malt/caramel representation with some aroma hops and an earthiness. Flavor is biting from the start with some sweetness hanging in the background.  Palate is light bodied and watery with a lingering hop finish.
On draft at the Flying Saucer in Memphis.  Excellent, well made example of the style.  Step this baby up with a nitro draft system, and youve got a best in class dry stout.

Pours with a two-finger light brown head that fades slowly and leaves a good lace. Virtually black color. Good carbonation. Nose is coffee. Strong coffee flavor, good stout but finishes with a hard water taste. $1.90 for a 12oz bottle from Vintage Cellar Blacksburg, VA.  The ABV is 5.6%.

Pours black with big tan head...smells of bitter chocolate first, then coffee, then just roasty wood...tastes heavily of bitter coffee...there was some chocolate there, but mainly just coffee...too carbonated in the mouth though, the first thing on my tongue was tingles from the bubbles...seemed a little thing, watery...finish was hoppy dry but more just after coffee mouthfeel...
poured a dark brown with a small to med. size tan head. aroma caramel, soapy, nutty malts and molasses. flavor caramel, dark fruits, bitter choc. dry roasted nuts, coffee. good beer
(Bottle)  Pours black with mahogany highlights and a large tan head.  Aroma is rich with scents of chocolate, roasted coffee, and nuts.  Kind of a light body for a stout.  Bitter palate.
quality stout, asphalt aroma and appearance, tastes of nougat and licorice and cocoa powder, lightly buttery but with a potent dry finish

Bottled. Pours very dark, but not motor oil black. Some red to it. Nice burnt tan head. Good lacing. Loved the nose, tons of roasted barley, good hoppiness, dark fruitiness. Taste was dominated by roast, some chocolate, good amount of fruitiness. It was a bit thin on they tongue and finish was somewhat of a let down. Overall a solid stout though.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2004 ReRate-bottle-rio puerco field trip-pours pitch black with nice tan head-good lacing!  Flavors of chocolate, roasted malts, coffee and lots of hops for a stout.  Full body and a long finish.  Very solid stout!
bottle-old chicago, rockford, IL-pours pitch black with a small tan head-medium carbonation.  Lots of roasted coffee notes on the aroma-sugary sweet.  very nice coffee flavors.  nice body and long roasted finish.  good stout!
This is a pretty decent stout.  Lots of rich flavor and plenty of fruitiness.

Poured a dark Mahogany (not dark enough that you could not see through it) with a large frothy brown head. Strong chocolate aromas and tastes with a slight hint of coffee. Nice bitter finish. Watery body. Lots of lacing left on the glass as I drank it. OK but nothing too special.
Bottled: Reddish brown coloured. Dark beige head. Smoke, cocoa, light coffee in the aroma. Roast, malt, chocolate in the flavour. Quite smooth. Is light bitter and roasty in the end. Good one.
Not a bad stout, good chocolate aroma, burnt coffee and chocolate flavors, but was a bit watery and thin overall.
Dark full bodied, smooth stout, coffee and toasted flavors w/hints of dark fruit, this is was a really good stout, enjoyed it!

bottle. pitch black with a brown head. roasted chocolate aroma.  slightly bitter first taste but the roasted malt comes through quickly with a nice chocolate flaor. leaves an enjoyable burnt coffee and chocolate taste. I like this, this is my kind of beer. Im glad i have another in the fridge.

Dark black stout with a nice vanilla , raisin and chocolate aroma. Nice rich chocolate malts, and surprinsgly, they didnt go overboard on hops in this. Some smokinees in aftertatse with a fine balance of hops. Nice bodied and pleasant.

The summer heat may have gotten to me because I fell head over heels for this Dry Stout.   Poured dark brown with a firm creamy, head.   Heavy roasted malt aroma was the invite to sample the coffee. chocolate and smoke flavor that had a dry, crisp finish.   Excellent dry stout with a perfect balance of drinkability and flavor.   Not sure of the alcohol content, but Old No. 38 did not hit me like a locomotive.
UPDATED: AUG 16, 2004 Decent stout.   Nothing that amazing, however. Not that different from a Guinness. I'd rather reach for their Rasputin stout any day of the week.

Beer pours dark brown with a nice thick tan colored head and lots of lacing.  Aroma is thick with notes of coffee, chocolate, and fresh tilled earth.  Flavor is mostly coffee and smoke.  This is good easily accessible beer.

Bottle. Dark pour with a fading beige head. Nose is sweet and malty. The first taste notes to come out are roasted malt, raisin, malt, a little spice, and some toffee. The flavor is good, but there is a taste on the finish that is slightly astringent. Overall not bad, but nothing to write home about. Your basic stout.

To be fair  I rated this beer immediately after rating a westy 12.  As such the rating may not be fair.  Beer poors a nice black color toped by a tan rapidly diminishing head.  Aroma is roastyand chocolate  but also a little burnt in my opinion.  Flavor is as you would expect of chocolate and roasted nuts but again the slightly burnt taste arises.  Nice malt with a generous hops present found in the finish.  The palate was dissapointing and detracts significantly for this beer to me.

This one was surprising too me, althogh it probally was not a good idea to have had Westvleteran 12 just before.  The appearance was attractive with its dark brown pour, diminishing dark brown head yet moderate lacing.  The aroma with presence of a very roasted malt and bittersweet chocolate.  As it warmed however I began to get hints of a peat moss/decaying leaf aroma.  Not bad, just natural smelling.  The palate was VERY dissapointing however.  It was very weak and washed out.  The taste was about as impressive.  It tasted like charcoal with an astringent, bitter aftertaste.  My last sip had a unusal flavor, the warmest sip...and that was essence of wet dog.  So you see why I said it was surprising.  This one looks and smells better than it tasted.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2004 Dark burgundy with a grayish tan head. Roasted malt aroma with notes of coffee and chocolate. Very roasty, even smoky flavor. Coffee and mild acidity come out in the finish. Could use more body but this is still a good, enjoyable stout.
Dark with a thick creamy head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted and anise. Flavour it roasty and dry with citrus hops and anise. A bit thin for a stout, but pretty good over all.
This is a good stout. Smooth and creamy, nice long-lasting head. Not very strong but still fulbodied and complex.
On tap acrossed street from brewery...very attractive, black body with creamy tan head.  Medium-full body, creamy mouthfeel, sweet and roasty, finishing dry...Im very much a fan.

Black pour with a dense tan head. Very roasted aroma. Flavor is sweet and roasted with an acidic finish. The sweetness seemed out of place, either that or get rid of the acidity and call it a sweet stout.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2004 Man this brew dissapointed me. Im not a big fan of dry stouts. Too dry and not rich enough. This brew poured lovely. Dark and rich. Smelled like dry grain, motor oil and ash. Taste is burnt not roasted. And dry for days. The carbonation and the dryness make me want to puke.
Grat
Deep brown in color with a nice tan head. Full bodied beer. Roasty and chocolatety. Enjoyable. Smooth tasting. Dry finish. Drinkable.
Pours a deep brown, held up to light you can see through it. Aroma coffee and chocolate. Flavor is the same.  It is what a stout should be. Nothing to get excited about but still is pleasing.
