This was pretty tasy, quite toasty/roasty. Some smokeyness in there aswell. Nutty and chocolatey, long dry finish, really tasty.

Pours black with some ruby tint.  Nice tan head.  Aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Very slight hint of anise.  Decent body.  Coffee flavor was very pleasing.  A good coffee stout but not as good a Bells Java Stout.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2005 Bottle @ Akkurat, StockholmNice full stout head. Coffe and roasted barley in aroma. Complex full taste with chocolate and coffe. If something negative nust Be said there is a slight aftertaste of burned rubber.

Tastes and feels more like a porter to me. Pours a deep dark brown with a light brown head. Roasty aroma. Taste is of roasted malt, barley and coffee. Mouthfeel is nice but on the thinner side. Leaves a nice slightly burnt aftertaste. Not bad.

Bottle: Good nose, Chocolate milk, pine, coffee. Clear reddish brown. Small head that faded. Sweet malt, touch of hops, Bakers chocolate, pine grapefruit in the flavor. Dry sweet finish. Faded quickly. Smooth. Very drinkable, went down fast. I might even think of it as my lawn mowing stout.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Aroma has lots of chocolate, slightly smokey, malty, with oak notes. Dark ruby red color with medium sized tan head. Flavor is full of coffee and chocolate, creamy, malty, with a somewhat bitter finish. Palate is a little thin for the style.

Pours dark maroon, with a subdued head.  Nice lacing.  Good coffee/chocolate smell.  Tastes very dry, with toffee, malt, soy sauce, chocolate, and earthy hints.  Finishes smooth...not as thick and rich as other stouts, but pretty good overall.

Dark dark red body with a stiff tan head.  Dry chocolate aroma with a hint of fruitiness.  Dry roasty coffee bean taste peach and banana hints.  This stout might be a bit weak in mouthfeel or depth of flavor but it certainly has no flaws.
From the bomber bottle: Dark reddish-brown-black in appearance. Tan head. Roasted malt aroma. Chocolate, caramel, vanilla flavor. Very nice stout.

Got this from Bottleworks; it's not available anywhere I've seen in Oregon.

Pours... Well, looks like a foamy cup of coffee, and smells that way too. Taste is roasted coffee and mocha with a bit of a bite. Just a touch of mineral mouthfeel on the palate. Overall, it's not the best North Coast (stiff competition, though!) but a solid stout that holds its own quite well.

A mellow smokey malty aroma.Dark w/ruby highlights.Taste is citrus,coffee,smoked tease of choc-burn.Decent smooth yet bitter finish lingers.Almost like a sour hopped scotch ale(weird)burnt dry long finish(eck)Tastes old.Not bad,but intense.
Not bad, but having it next to Rasputin makes it seem a bit weak.  Still, there are nice coffee and smoky notes, with a bitter finish.
Roasty chocolate aroma, roasted sweet dark chocolate taste bubbles kept sparking flavor in your mouth, you can taste the chocolate just about the entire trip. Very good but not that complex

Black libation with a frothy tan head that gives way to some intriging lacing.  Overwhelming taste of unsweetened baker's chocolate, mingled with burnt,toasted and roasted flavors.  An assault on the palate.  Effervescant and lively in the mouth, with little visible carbonation in the glass.  Is my dishwasher dying or is this beer oily?  Cannot find the hops through the chocolate dryness.
Nice frothy head, very good lacing.  Coffee aroma and malt.  Slightly bitter, fairly smooth, good amount of carbination, slightly smokey.  Good dry stout.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2009 Aroma is kind of funny.  Doesnt really smell too much like a stout.  Smells kinda malty, but no chocolate or coffee really.  Color is a moderately transparent dark mahogany with a robust light tan head with decent staying power.  Start is malty and smooth, with smoky choclate in the middle, finishing smoky.  Decently balanced with enough hops.  After the Shipyards stout, this one seems like a champ. (4/3/7/4/13) ----RE RATE---12 ounce bottle from the Davis Food Co-Op.  Nice roasted aroma with just the right amount of chocolate sweetness.  Fairly aromatic and pleasant.  Has a bit of a milky character to it.  Mildly transparent dark brown body with a quickly dissipating, small, tan head.  Starts a little carbonated and bubbly on the tongue.  Followed by some thinly veiled mineral like flavors before a nice roastiness takes over.  Finishes moderately bitter and somewhat dry.  A little thin on the palate.  Flavorful and pretty rounded.

Bottle pours black with red highlights.  The aroma is of roasted malt.  The flavor is roasted malt, nutty, some ale fruit notes, and dark chocolate.  The palate is nice and rich.  Overall, pretty good.

on tap fort braggs:  dark brown coffee appearance with a creamy tan head. pungent hop floral aroma with a bit of choc malt kicking in the butt. same thing with the taste. medium bodied. easy and nice to drink.

12 oz bottle.  Dark reddish-black, little head, thick lacing.  Roasty, bitterweet mocha nose with a hint of burgundy.  Touch of sweetness deep in the aroma.  Very smooth, nice coffee attributes, slightly oily, bit of prune, dry bitter finish.  Could use a little more rough & tumble quality, a bit too soft, but overall another fine libation from this great brewery.
Nothing of note can be said of this beer, nice color with no head, smell?? I don't know. however, it is a very smooth stout that should not be eaten with tacos
Deep black.  small head.  Medium thickness and oily taste.  Tastes of cocoa and chocolate with a slight aftertaste.

This one rung a bell with me. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Nice malty aroma, with roasty chocolate coffee blended. Big round malty flavor with notes of roast and chocolate, and a nice full body. Easy drinkin'.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle; watery and overly burnt tasting. Not even very dry for a dry stout.
Nice dark color. Aroma is malty, cocoa and cream. Flavor from cocoa and chocolate, somewhat peppery. Really nice...

Wow an excellent brew!  This bottled brew poured a large sized head of foamy fine to medium sized brown colored long lasting bubbles that left behind a good lacing.  The body was a semi-transparent very dark ruby red brown colored with no visible carbonation.  It had a most excellent coffee dark malt caramel and molasses aroma.  The mouth feel was smooth with a very mild coffee bite.  The flavor was also smooth with a good chewy dark malt coffee hop taste.  A very nice brew that I will seek out a a session standard.
Nice coffe aroma.  Dark in color but no black.  Small, dense head.  Flavor is big coffee up front with a watery middle and a bad finish.  Finish was like old celery.
As my wife pointed out, just a little too carbonated. No head at all. A little sour, definite coffee flavor. A sweeter stout. Nice.
Roasted chocolate malts dominate the aroma.  This one is creamy and smooth up front with a biting dryness at the end, which is really pleasent.  Nice flavor of smoke and cream.  Quite good.

Decently thick, off-white head over sweet smelling, dark brown (cola) stout. Very dry taste.  Reminds me off dark chocolate. I don't get too much coffee. I found this beer to be quite enjoyable, but was a little pricy for what it was.

Dark black with a nice head and lots of lace. Malty espresso aroma. Taste is toffee malts with strong coffee tones, lightly sweet and bitter. The flavors could all stand to be a little more pronounced and it its a little on the thin side.

Bottle. This beer poured a small sized tan head with fine-small sized bubbles that completely dissipated. The body was opaque and uncarbonated with a dark brown hue. The nose was chocolate and coffee. The flavor of this beer was that of coffee with a smooth mouthfeel.

Dark brown with ruby edges, and almost no head.  Roasted aroma, but with hints of licorce as well. Very dry taste, but with glimpses of roasted coffee, and malts.  Good bitter finish as well.  Maybe a bit on the weak side of a stout as far as assult on the taste buds, but a good beer.

Paid $1.19 for a 12-oz single.

Dark brown, not black, big, fluffy head.

Sweet & rich choclate in the nose.

Coffee, slight orange, burnt toast, chocolate... all mixed together to make up the taste. Nice and refreshing.

A bit thin in the mouth- my only complaint about this brew.

Quite enjoyable.  Side by side with Rasputin, I usually go with the Imperial, but this is a solid, well-made stout that always pleases.  Really, nothing wrong with it, but it does fail to stand out as the Rasputin does. I compare this to Sierra Navada Stout, the Shipyard Bluefin, and the Old Australia.  Also similar to the Rogue Shakespeare.  Great beer to keep in your "frequently purchased" list. Won't let you down, but won't inspire much poetry.
Whoa. Smokey malt nose with wood. Taste was the same. amazing smokiness mxed with wood, malt, and even some chocolate and coffee. Lots going on here.

Pours reddish black with a quickly dissipating, fluffy head.  Roasted malt aroma.  Roasted coffee flavor that doesn't overwhelm combined with a good dose of hops. It's the hops in this that I love.  Slightly lingering bitter chocolate flavor.  Very smooth and very nice.

On tap.  Poured a jet  black apperance with a nice creamy tan head.  This was a very easy-drinking stout that doesn't have the astringent hop finish of most stouts.  Great coffee notes came through in the flavor in a big way.  My new favorite dry stout.
Sweet chocolate aroma, maybe a bit of caramel.  deep ruby when held against a light.  Good bitter coffee flavors with chocolate notes and a bit of peat.
Pours a dark brown color with a small white head.  The aroma is roasted and sweet.  The flavor is chocolate, roasted malt and slightly bitter.  The body is very thin and watery.
Light black color with beautifil ivory head that stays all the way through. Nice balance of the roasted malt and chocolate/coffee.
Roasty and chocolaty in both aroma and flavor, with a robust, smooth presence. Coffee and choclate with a subdued roast barley flavor that make this very drinkable.
A typical stout - flavors of chocolate and coffee with a hint of caramel. Pretty damn good, but I have had a few that were better.

Brownish ruby beer with a lasting light tan head.  Heavily roasty and chocolatey at first, possibley a little black malt for a sharper, lightly burnt aroma.  The aromas become more rounded as it warms and a light fruitiness and toffee appear.  Flavor is bitter roasty/coffee and chocolate with a light sourness, probably from the dark grains; malty mid palate to help balance very well and finishes dry.  Roasty coffee aftertaste w/ a bit of a burnt character to it.  Dry, lightly astringent m/f from grains, medium bodied with low carbonation.  Pretty good dry stout, although it seems a little two dimensional flavor wise lacking a lot of complexity, but still very good nonetheless.
Dark amber, medium light tan head, nose has some spice, mild coffee, some fruit and chocolate. Coffee start, sweeter chocolate middle, mildly bitter finish. Somewhat thin palate, highly drinkable.

Dark ruby, black from a distance, medium tan head, ring of lace lasted. Aroma was roasty and malty, plenty of coffee. Coffee flavor up front, roasted barley throughout. Lingering coffee finish. A little lighter body for a stout but it did not detract. Pretty good.

More of a porter than a stout, but I don't mind a bit -- very coffee like in taste and aroma -- body is not very thick, which lends it more drinkability. Roasted flavor gets stronger as it warms. Disappointedly ruby colored rather than rich and black, but again its a porter lovers stout.  One I'd get again, but I'd still like to try Old Rasputin. Cheers!
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text: Dark brown with red tints, small head. Aroma of roasted barley and coffee beans. Roasty coffe flavors up front followed by a malty bitter sweet cocoa finish.

Brown colour with a dense tan head. Very light for a stout-however. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Light-bodied; Mild sweetness and roasted malt flavour-fairly light for the style. Aftertaste shows some bitter qualities, full of coffee and chocolate tastes. Overall, a decent beer-more of a porter than a stout in my opinion. I bought this twelve ounce bottle from Chevy Chase Wines & Spirits in Washington, D.C. and sampled it on 21-November-2003.

Beautiful stout. The very darkest of browns, paired with a creamy tan head. Heavily roasted malts dominate the palate, with some licorice? Although the flavor is quite pleasant, it doesn't seem to stand out in any noticible fashion. Finish is somewhat short. It could use a little more strength

I am really starting to enjoy Stouts. This only about the fourth stout that I have ever had but I enjoyed it very much. It poured out dark with little to no head and on the carbonation scale (if there is one) it had very little. I could taste chocolate with an after bite leaving a nutty flavor behind. I wasn't overly impressed with the aroma. Try this one, I think you will like it.

Poured with great head that left rather quickly.  Dark color with red tint in the light.  Lacing was nothing great.  Aromas were of coffee, malts, and slight caramel.  It goes down smooth with nice malt and coffee flavors, but it too subdued to be great.  After taste lingers for a while like you just coated your mouth with oil.  Not bad, but nothing to write home about.

Pours very dark brown/amber with small tan head.  Nice chocolate aroma.  Somewhat bitter coffee flavor is prevalent.  Mouthfeel is watery but the flavor is still full.  A lingering bitter aftertaste.  Average stout.
A decent stout, though it's not as complex and smooth as I had hoped and just a bit too dry. I wouldn't shy away from having another, but my search for a favorite, easily accessible stout continues.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2004 Dark black with tawny red edges with large head initially then fades quickly and stays creamy with lots of lacing. The aroma is fruity with grapes, figs and raisin. Notes of chocolate & coffee are very prevelant too. Flavor is much more mild compared to the aroma and doesn't match too well. This finishes fairly musty and stays in your mouth for a while. moderate burnt/toasty finish as well.

Pours very dark brown with a reddish tint with a big bubbly head that dissapates rather quickly. Very spotty lacing.  Roasted coffee and malts in the nose. Starts with a big coffee flavor mixed with roasted malt that finishes slightly hoppy. Palate is slighly oily or buttery as it feels slick in the mouth. Good stout.
Musty, chocolate aroma with a mild hop lingering.  Dark brown color with good head and lacing, but a little oily.  Coffee and hop flavor that is very slight on the palate.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2010 Its exactly what a stout should look like:  very dark; a reddish hue on the rim; dense beige head and good lacing.  Sweet malty aroma of chocolate, toffee and caramel.  Flavors of cookie dough, bakers chocolate and a passing note of coffee.  Aftertaste is surprisingly dry, despite all the sweetness.
Aroma of toasted cheerios.  Sanguine red-brown color, with a light tan thin head.  Flavor of roasted cheerios.  Nothing remarkable here- just a run-of-the-mill dry stout.  Average in every respect.
Deep burgandy color with an initial huge frothy beige head. Light aroma of dark chocolate. Taste is coffee and bitter chocolate. Palate is thin. Light dry mouth watering bitter aftertaste.

Nice aroma of chocolate, raisins, and coffee. Flavor is the same but the coffee comes out as prominent. The palate is very very thin however. This is nice if you want to drink these all night, but I prefer stouts that have a thicker feel.

Color is a dark coffee brown with dark ruby highlights when put up to the light, thin compact tannish head fading fairly slow to leave ink blot patches of crumbly lace. Aroma is dark, sweet chocolate and a nice alcoholic warmth and spice. Also blends in some nice malty roastyness and dried hops with a nice overlaying touch of fresh coffee beans. Taste is quite different then what the smell leads on; mostly a heavy roasted flavor with an older left-in-the-pot coffee sense, a milding roasted sweetness and the chocolate is all but gone from the nose with only hints of cocoa powder and light burnt brownie drying that comes in and through the finish. Feel is medium bodied with a creamy start and middle wrapping up the finish with a favorable little bittering and drying factions with notes of cocoa, coffee, and cinnamon. A nice stout with a great nose and a nice finish. A solid stout all the way.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2003 Very dark brown with a small off-white head. Good lacing. deep and quite sweet aroma of of coffee and cacao. Coffee and roasted malt in flavour with hints of dark chocolate, vanilla and cacao. Good palate. Long bitter finish with hints of choclate. Not very complex but very tasty! Good stout!

Deep darkness follows the pour, but some light does shine through the darkness when held upto a bulb.  Very nice pour though, with a big tan head, and a very inviting aroma.  The flavor is rich and tastes like burnt coffee but not in a bad way, the body is very light, but the mouthfeel is very moist and oily.  I still prefer Old Rasputin.

Deep dark ruby, more opaque then a typical stout. Very nice frothy small light brown head that leaves nice lacing. Deep dark raosted malt aroma, chocolate and coffee are prominent. Burnt/roasted malt flavor dominates. Very little hops as expected for the style. Body is medium light, a wee bit light for the style. Overall a decent stout but I expected a little more from North Coast.
Dark brown,lasting tan head.Dry malt & light coffee nose. Dry malt and toasted flavor with dry, but bitter finish. A bit on the thin side

This is one tasty dry stout - intense toastiness all around, with roasted malts downright assaulting the tongue, and sticking around on the palate for a ridiculous amount of time - I would go as far as saying that the dark coffee and chocolate flavors in this one are almost up there with the Old Rasputin - this is that beer's less potent, but just as tasty cousin.
Forms an off-white head and is not quite pitch black.  Has rich, caramel taste that is pleasing in front and back.  It's good to be king.
Pours dark brown, not quite black.  Roasted malty and coffee notes in the aroma.  Lots of coffee flavors on the palate as well.

The flavor is sweet with strong chocolate notes. The color is dark brown and it has a fantastic brown head - looking like a stout should. The flavor is dominated by chocolate and coffee with sweet notes - all coming from a great malt blend. All in all a great beer.

Dark brown hue with fluffy tan head and very good lace. Aroma hinted of ripe fruit, vanilla, semi-sweet chocolate, and coffee. The taste was a surprising coffee twang and acadic nature. Not a much sweetness. Bitter dry finish. Thin-bodied with a lively mouthfeel. Very interesting beer, smells sweet but tastes dry. Can't recommend because something seems missing on the palate.

Brown with amber glints. Off-white to khaki head. Sticky roast and coffee on the aroma with accents of chocolate and light fruit (almost earthy). Full mouthfeel with a sour finish and burnt coffee lingering. Standard stout.
Pours deep dark brown with a full light brown head.  Aroma of roasted coffee with a touch of chocolate sweetness.  Strong roasted coffee flavor.  Leaves a strong bitter dry aftertaste.

Bottled. Sampled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm. 
Black, off-white head. Rich aroma of chocolate and coffee. Fruity flavour with notes of coffee, with a bitter ending. Dry palate-feel.

Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm 2003.
Very dark with a nice, brown head.
I think this one's too artificial, both in the aroma and the flavour.
Nutty flavour.

Nice black color,medium sized tan head that had a decent staying power.Good roasted aroma with a little licorice thrown in.The flavor was roasty malty and chocolate and mild coffee with an after taste of dark chocolate and coffee.finishing off in a semi dry sense.This is a great tasting brew and i'm glad i have 5 more to work with for later tasting.
Reddish black with a tan head. Cherry chocolate odor. Dark chocolate flavor, as well, then some mild coffee flavors leading to a dry, dusty, bitter finish.
UPDATED: FEB 15, 2004 Black with a nice creamy brownish head. Aroma from chocolate, cocoa and whipped cream. Flavor from cocoa and coffe. Rather mild, a pleasant stout

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2004 Bottled. Black, or at least very dark ruby, beige, dense head. Rich aroma of licorice and chocolate. Dry and salty with clean but rounded mouthfeel. Fairly roasty, coffee and aromatic citric hops dominate until a salty, bitter finish.  Excellent hop profile and decent malt profile. Like most US microbrews it's an extrovert, flavourful beer, focusing on loads of flavour than subtle complexity.
looks like guinness extra stout in a glass, good flavor, another good beer by this company.  good smell

95% opaque, with just a little dark-chocolate-brown color shining through when held to light.  Medium-sized, off-white head.  Smell is big time chocolate, oatmeal and a little French roast. Beer is huge and flavorful, filling the whole mouth. Taste is tremendous on the taste buds (healthy dose of carbonated zing), with sweet malt up front (not fruity, think: sweet dark chocolate), followed with oatmeal and some soured milk, building towards a big ending of bitter-chocolate and dark coffee. The wave of flavor for this beer is V-shaped, if you will: big beginning, mild medium, huge end. Also, all 3 sections offer a nice contrast from one another making this an enjoyable, rousing stout from one of my favorite breweries. Sampled from a 12oz bottle purchased at Chevy Chase Wine & Liquors in Washington, DC.

Very nice deep head which settles nicely.  Nice roasty, toasty aroma.  Color is a very dark brown but not opaque.  Flavor is pretty smooth with dark chocolate, a touch of coffee and plenty of malt.  Finish is a dry and a little bitter.  I guess the hops they claim is finally showing its head.  A decent stout but a little thin and not much kick in the alcohol department.

Pours with a black body topped by a thick lasting off-white head with lots of lacing left on the glass.  Coffeeish malt aroma with a slight sweetness and a touch of roastiness.  Slightly bitter malt flavor with a smokey/roasty character and a very slight sweetness as well as some licorice.  Full bodied, slightly tingly yet smooth  with a touch of dryness.

A very nice dry stout; flavors are focused on the roast barley/hop bite synergy that make it the kind of dry stout you can drink all night.  Not too busy, not a lot of complexity-simply a well made dry stout.

A robust, extremely dry, bitter stout.  Flavor of dry hops and roasted (burnt!) malt.  Overall, flavor and aroma is a little lacking, as it is a basic stout without any added flavoring.  Good for what it is, I guess.
UPDATED: JUL 18, 2004 Nice black with decent tan head. Malt aroma. Taste is smokey with hints of coffee. A good stout, but their Rasputin is better.

Pours a deep ruby-brownish clear colour.  Creamy, foamy, light tan head.  Roasted malt and light floral hops emerge from the nose.  Roasty toasty palate, medium bodied, but a bit thin...Actually, really thin for a stout, but...Dark chocolate, burnt caramel, finishing pleasantly bitter.  Very drinkable, but perhaps Mr. Powers is correct...

Smelled very smokey and tasted very hoppy. Poured with a massively bubbly whitish brown foamy head that lasted quite awhile.  lacing was excellent.  Was turned off by the aroma.  Smelled too much of dirty laundry.  The taste was bitter, tart, and tangy.  Roasted cofee with a highly acidic taste was evident.  This was not as near as good as I was hoping.

Beer pours (in Chimay glass) a near total black that light can barely penetrate.  Head is off-white to caramel in color that collapses to near nothing.  Aroma is of hops and skunk spray hiding a sweet chocolate.  Flavor is a medium hop with light pine needles leaving a dry ending - stripping the mouth out.  Its not so bad.  Sampled at 72 degrees Fahrenheit.

It’s great to find that we have another American brewer, North Coast, which continually produces quality beer. * Not that Old # 38 is a mind blowing stout, but it is quality stuff. The aroma is of coffee, chocolate malt, and some hints of plum. The flavor is a bit charred, over roasted malt, but it’s not bad; the finish is dry and bitter. The palate is also a bit watery, but the beer has nice lacing. Decent beer but as I said before, it’s not my favorite dry stout.

This beer pours a dark color with a thick and steady tan head with quite a bit of lacing left on the glass.  The aroma is not very strong, but there are hints of burned malts and possibly a hint of coffee - it has an interesting sweet character to the aroma as well.  The flavor is a little spicy and reminiscent of coffee.  The malt is also very noticeable.  Very smooth with a little bit of sweetness in the aftertaste.  I'm normally not a fan of this style, but I could have several of these without complaint.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2003 Didn't really pack the punch I like in a stout but not that bad overall. Thick head with good retention. Aroma not real powerful but had a significant roasted malt presence and perhaps subtle notes of coffee. Dry and bitter but not as full as I'd like. Was satisfying none the less with good roasted malt flavor. I enjoyed their Imperial much more.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Started out strong, ended kind of watery.  Great smell, great initial flavor.  Reminiscent of Bell's Expedition Stout, but not at all thick.
Poured dark brown color with small brownish head. Big coffeee aroma. Nice  roasted coffee flavor with a bitter finish.
Rich coffee aroma, dark brown color. Small head with nice lacing. Roasted flavor, coffee with a nice bitter finish. Enjoyable
Dry stout. Ugh. I've discovered another style I don't care for. Coffee flavor, burnt. Kind of like a porter. Just not my style. I like Imperial stouts and sweet stouts, but not this.
more of a coffee flavor that the imperial stout.  very good.  North coast knows how to make stouts.
Unlike other raters, not much of a head.  But nice lacing all the way down, and a lovely color.  Nice roasted espresso flavor, hangs around for a while.  Not bad.

Large bubbled tan head. Almost opaque. Black with red highlights. Grainy, fruity nose. Full bodied. Laceing hanging around, slight head still there. Roasty, chocolatey aand some black malt to boot., kinda burnt tasting. Creamy, dry finish.

Pour is a nearly opaque black, large rocky tan head that leaves good lacing.  Aroma is dark roastiness, smoky, ash, and strong espresso.  Flavor follows the aroma, starting with some more of the smokiness coming out at the end.  Thick and chewy on the palate.

Very attractive pour, dark brown revealing ruby when held up to light.  Large, light brown, rocky head, mostly diminishing with slight lacing.  Complex aroma with coffee, chocolate, raspberry and a hint of raisin.  Big smokey malt flavor with a bracing hop finish to balance.  Good, enjoyable dry stout - though on the tame side.
Dark Brown Stout with a very dry flavor.  A very coffee and chocolate flavor that doesn't quite live up to the stout label, but is still an excellent beer (More a Porter?)

Nice deep brown color, a different stout than I am used to, some coffee hints, but surprisingly hoppy for a stout beer(with the distinct North Coast hop flavor).  Preferred over the Red Seal Ale, and a good overall stout.

Bottle:  Pours a dark brown.  Small, tan head, which dissapates quickly.  Aroma is mainly chocolate, with hints of coffee and roastiness.  Roasted malty flavor is the most prevalent.  Some bitterness in it also.  Flavor is strong, but the body is a little thin.  Overall this is pretty good, but I'll stick to their Old Rasputin.

Straight slam into stout glass only produces a fine layer of creamy bubbles for a head. Aromas right away are of malt syrup,
licorice, anise, and butterscotch. Fruity aromas of figs, dates, prunes. Pours out a deep, dark brown, with red highlights at the
bottom of the glass. Bitter maltiness followed by expresso notes make up the front of the beer. Plenty of black malts, and
chocolate malts in this beer, apparent by the taste. Touch of hops bitterness at the finish of this beer. Plenty of complexity to this
beer. Makes for an interesting drink. A pretty fair stout, in my book. Guinness, take notes, there will be a quiz following.

Chocolate and coffee; roasted smoky bitterness. Sweet with hint of molasses and some hoppy tang. Foamy smooth head with brown lacing. Brown-black clear liquid. Low carb and smooth medium watery body. Iced tea and roasted malts on the tongue. Sweet and very smooth but not quite creamy. Light bitter finish and after. Coffee and chocolate bitterness with light hops. Heavy malts, but surprisingly weak overall. Not as good as Rasputin.
Nice dark color, however, no head to speak of at all.  Very watery for a stout.  Nice coffee flavor and toasty aftertaste.  Just a bit light/watery for a "stout"...

Your good ol', average stout. Nothing spectatular (Guinness), but definitely worth trying and having again. Nice dark color with a full, whit head. The first sip is loaded with a sweet kick, and slowly moves into deep chocolate and roasted overtones, and finishes with a nice mellow tobaccoie taste.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2006 Dark amber with a creamy tan head.  Mix of chocolate, coffee, and slight hops aroma.  On tasting this reminds me of Rogues Shakespeare Stout with the hops flavor.  That being said this is more tolerable, as the hops are not an overpowering presence here.  Unlike Rogues I can still smell the coffee as it warms.  The traditional stout taste with a bitter and dry finish.
Pours black with a thin tan head. Nose is mainly of dark chocolate. Full bodied and the flavor is of roasted chocolate, coffee, and hints of fruit. Very smooth and easy to drink. Very good!

This one pours a very dark brown color with a small tan head. Strong aroma of roasted malts with coffee tones and a smell not unlike burnt bacon. Full bodied and very smooth, the flavor is full of roasted malts and coffee, with a roasted and slightly bitter finish. A very nice stout, not overdone in the burnt malt department and just enough hops to help balance it out.
Very dark brown w/ lots of coffee notes. Nice drinkable beer. It's a very smooth stout

Deep brown beautiful color with a small tan bubbly head. The nose is of chocolate...sweet, malty. Tasting of coffee and chocolate. Roasted malts with a slightly dry finish. It has a good amount of carbonation...medium body. Worth drinking again.

Roasted and nutty, with a touch of coffee overtones, yet it leaves a hint of sweetness in the air. It pours deep dark brown , Im just barely able to see through it, yet it is crystal clear and shadowy. The head is a foamy beige blanket that fades and forms a nice thick ring around the top. Starts out a bit acidic and tart, but turns into a big roasty flower of barley in the middle. The finish is smooth, with a slightly burnt tinge at the very end. A very nice stout, that I wouldnt hesitate to buy again.

Dark ruby color, one of the lightest stouts Ive had.  Biege head left decent lacing.  Chocolate, coffee and roasted malt in the nose and flavor.  Bitter roasted malt aftertaste, medium-full mouthfeel.  Very similar to Guinness, a good dry stout.
dark,heavy roasted flavor.  touches of chocalate and a coffee. decent beer
Chocolate, coffee and a nice dry, roasted flavor at the end.  Very appropriate for dry stout category.  I like this beer a lot.
Wow, COFFEE!  Commercial description was quite on, and I also experienced a fruitiness in the nose.  Good, strong stuff...
It has been too long since Ive had this.  The archetypal West Coast Stout: hop fruitiness, wonderful chocolate and dry roasted malts.  Brilliant.

I am stunned to see the relatively low rating for this beer--even though my rating is not spectacularly high--I appreciate the greatness of this brew. Syrupy black amber colored with a strong roasted coffee aroma and deep chocolate notes--subtlety is certainly not this beers trademark--quite a coffee monster. Nonpareil, full mouthfeel of coffee roasted, robust to the max with a bitter coffee ground and metallic finish. This beer might be considered a bit overpowering. A stout stout for sure and a dry stout with no known superiors
a smooth stout. almost like old rasputian minus the bite. has a very deep coffee taste to it.

North Coast Old No 38 Stout poured a menacingly dark brown color with hints of ruby red becoming apparent when held up to the light. The head was clearly present and lasted throughout the enjoying of this fine stout..quite creamy may i add. The aroma is that of high maltiness, sweetness, coffee and something between mocha and chocolate. The taste begins with a malty jolt, followed by the subtle coffee and powerful chocolate jolts, (and those roasted subtleties are just great) and ends with a bitterness from those fine but thinly spread hops...a good dry bitterness. This one is pretty solid given its price, it has a decent flavor to it and its definitely worth trying again.

Very nice roastiness for a stout and theres a pleasant underlying chocolate thing going on here. Very well rounded with the hops, but the finish is a bit on the bitter side. The only thing this beer really lacks is that final punch, it should leave the drinker with that nice roasted flavor for hours. Right now, the finish is coffee, two seconds later it blends into bitersweet hoppiness (which is not my personal favorite) then a final lingering of that roasted flavor, but I need the Old 38 to hit me like, well, a train.
This deep dark porter, has a roasted coffee smell with a hint of toffee.  Tasteing sort of smokey with a chocolate/coffee taste. Um Um Good.
Nicely toasted aroma. Small off white head. Little to no lacing. Deep ruby color. Flavor is very roasted and dry. Medium bodied mouthfeel.

Ok, so its no Old Rasputin, but this isnt bad at all. Dark and burnt, with a dryness in the hops that assaults your mouth in the finish. A well brewed beer, probably deserving of a higher rating although in the shadow of its bigger brother.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 darkness hinting at stained glass churches...1/2 inch firm and strong tan head, aroma was earthy soil, cocoa bitterness, and powdery...flavor was cocoaish..not too bitter but not sweet...mellow powdered cocoa goodness..tad earthy & burnt but wholesome
Quite a lighter taste actually than most stouts with a hint of coffee, almost as good as BJs or Gentle Bens (AZ breweries).

The head is reluctant to form and once it does form has trouble lasting. What remains of the head clings to the sides of the glass like a 12-year-olds at their first dance. The body is a bit pale for a stout. Instead black with light seeping only through the edges, light passes relatively easily through this beer making is less black and more blackened ruby. The first thing I caught on my first whiff was a shock of citric hops that didnt seem to mesh well with the chocolately dark malt. I tried again and the hop aromas died down until after a few minutes all they were was a suggestion of bittereness lurking beneath the sweet malt. The flavor is moderately sweet and far from dry. I wouldnt describe it as rich, but I would call it chocolatey with low bitterness. There are few coffee or other bittering flavors from the darker roasted malt, although a lighter crisper malt lurks underneath the chocolate. Sadly, the mouthfeel is very thin for a stout. Of course that also makes it unusually drinkable for a stout. Still the flavor could benefit from a richer body and the mouthfeel really shouldnt so thin.

My final verdict is that for a stout its only run of the mill. It has some high points, like the fairly complex and lush flavor and aroma, and while a little too transparent for what I like in a stout, the resulting color is quite attractive. But it also has low points, like the thin mouthfeel and wimpy head. Despite all this, for pure easy-drinking pleasure, its not a bad beer.

Deep dark chestnut color with no head.  Aroma of sweet coffee.  Quite thin with flavors of dark malts, light coffee and  touch of molassas.  More of a mix between a brown porter and sweet stout, than a dry stout; but a decent beer.

Im pretty sure Im deeply upset that I bought a full six of this.  Have had only one, and will possibly rerate once I try another, but on first tasting this is by and large just godawful.  Thin body, watery and unimpressive.  Looks thin, a sort of cola-esque, vaugely dark but doesnt appear to have much body.  Flavor just nasty, tastes largely like burnt coffee.  Little hops and no chewiness in any kind of malts.  Leaves a residual oiliness in the mouth.  If the second one doesnt improve, Im just simply dumping the rest.  Ick.
Dark brown with a rocky tan head.Big roasted coffee nose. Huge dark roasted flavor. Medium body. Decent stout.

A decent concoction, whatever you want to call it.  Very dark--I couldnt see through it, except at the very edges, but then maybe I just have a very wide glass.  A nice mix of traditional flavors: roated, nutty, coffee-like.  Notable for its rather dry, bitter finish (enhancing the sense of coffee)--although in the end it struck me as slightly metallic in the aftertaste.  Not excessively carbonated, in my opinion.

A nice, thin stout compared to others of the style. Slight bitterness and less roasty/malty than other stouts. Not bad though. Havent yet had the Imperial Stout by North Coast but it is in my fridge.

Must have just hit Tallahassee!  Expected more from North Coast - a little chalky tasting.  Initial aroma - sweet and delicious - but quickly mellows. Not real familiar with dry stouts - so probably a good representation of the style - but I prefer the imperial.
Lotsa patent malt in there with Cascade hop.  Clean drinking but a understandably a little disappointing compared to Old Rasputin Imperial Stout made by North Coast.
Strong roasted coffee aroma protruding from the richly opaque body.  The finish is a bit bitter for its style, but the body is relatively thick.  A respectable stout.

This beer should be renamed Old No. 38 Porter, because thats what it is.  With that in mind, it should garner better ratings.  It seems raters have dinged this brew because it incorrectly bills itself as a stout.  As a porter, its sufficiently coffee-ish and roasty to satisfy the staunchest porter-head.  You can see through the glass and the body is appropriately thin for the style.

Dark brown color, medium head. Deeply roasted malts, coffee and chocolate flavor, some hop spiciness. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is smooth and slightly dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter, some malt sweetness. Taste is a little thin for a stout, but still a very nice beer.
Overall a pretty good stout. Just a tad to carbonated in my opinion. Nice aroma and flavor.

Dark brown color with just a hint of red. Small head, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The aroma/flavor was strong roasted/smokey/coffee. No alcohol was apparent in the flavor. The body was a little too thin. Easy drinking stout.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2004 Dark brown in color, nice lasting creamy tan head that leaves a sticky lacing in my glass, roasty chocolate-coffee aromas. Roasted burnt chocolate coffee, nice bitter-sweet flavors, good roasted bitterness in the finish. Medium body, kind of porter like.

Not quite as robust as I like my stouts.  Toasty.  Coffee notes.  
brown color.
A good coffee like stout with a strong roasted flavor.  Good texture and nice color in the glass.
Roasted flavor comes through, dark brown with little head. Flavors of coffee and roasted caramels. This is lighter than most stouts I have had not bad, not great, just OK.
Dark brown color with a light tan head and thin head of the same color.  Strong coffee flavor with a very sharp hops finish.  Very nice.
Dark brown color with a very light tan head. Both nose and flavor have deeply roasted coffee notes, coupled with piny hops. Solid flavors brewed ion the traditional West Coast hoppy style.
Bottle. A beige head with a dark brown body.  Chocolate, smooth, grainy, and some roasted coffee flavors.
roasted barley, sweet aroma.  nothing memorable.  In the words of Gloucester-Reggie.  late coffee
kinda weak bodied and not nearly as solid as I remembered
Good stout, bought a variety case of North Coast, & liked #38 the best

dark brown with  medium sized beige head.  roasted malt flavor and aroma, with definate hints of coffee, hops come to play at the end for dry finish.  Would prefer it be a little thicker, but overall a nice drinking stout.

Pours out a nice dark mahogany, a bit lighter than your standard stout.  Lightly roasty malt aroma.  Mostly malt flavor profile, with more roastiness and a bit of coffee.  Hops come in about halfway, and lend some light bitterness to the finish, which also has a little bit of malt sweetness, but is mostly dry.  Body is on the light side of medium, mouthfeel is a bit thin, surprisingly.  This is a lightweight stout.  More of a porter, really.  That said, its not bad, its just almost a session stout, you know, summer weight.

This beer rocks. 
Read the commercial description. Its accurate.

Substantial roastiness that goes a long way, with enough hops to keep it company for most of the journey.  Theres a little cola sweetness buzzing around annoyingly, but for the most part taking the 38 makes for a good trip.

Near-opaque, light tan head that sticks to the side of the glass as it dissipates.  Standard roasted coffee, barley, maltiness, but there was some acidity in the taste that really didnt appeal to me, especially when it lasted into the aftertaste.  As a stout fan, I find it hard to believe that this is the same company that put out the great Old Rasputin!

This beer poured out a nice dark color. Formed a medium tan head with some lace as it subsided. The aroma had definate malt and coffee.smell. Coffee and chocolate flavor to it. Slightly burnt aspect to it. Seemed to be one of the lighter bodied stouts. A good beer, worth a try, but not one of the best stouts out there.
Too coffee-ish and too thick.  Im not a fan of stouts and this is no different.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2004 Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (roasted/burnt grain), lightly hoppy (resin). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Rather boring aroma and a sourish flavor makes this one rather difficult to enjoy.  Never have understood the appeal of this one.

Mmmmm, great aroma, I get chocolaty, toasted malts, deep brown with a ruby tint. Burnt toast and coffee with a hop bite. Very tasty, somewhat reminds me of Coopers Best Extra Stout but a bit less bitter. Quite good.
Dark brown, aromatic coffee & cocoa; toasty, nutty, coffeeish body; long, dry finish.
weak aroma, watery dark appearance. this brew seems more like a dark ale gone wrong.strong burnt carmel taste with a overdone hops after taste.
Just an ordinary stout as far as Im concerned.  Just that plain roasted flavor you can find anywhere.  Not bad, but nothing special.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 This was a really intense beer.  I'm surprised more people don't think highly of it.  Maybe I just got a good bottle?  ;)  I liked this much better after I stopped seeing it as a stout and as a really dark ale with a huge amount of roasted, coffee taste (and aroma).  The only compliant is a watery, fizzy palate.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2005 Decent roasted and chocolate malts with a strong hop finish.  A little thin for a stout.  Over all pretty forgettable stout.
Re-rate: Reddish-black color with a pretty sorry looking head. Nice aroma of prunes and other dried fruit. Caramel, malt, chocolate and dark fruit flavor  with a nice finish. Much better than the first rating.
A very good stout.  Not as hoppy as many american stouts.  Seemed more like a cream stout.

more of a heavily roasted porter,
has a nice hoppy finish.
lacks the chewy mouthfeel that all great stouts should have.
dark brown, slight head, bitter coffee flavor...not bad, but ive had better stouts

this is a transparent stout, (imposter!) perhaps needing to be downgraded to a porter. okay, i dont pretend to know the mechanics of style, maybe i just need a fatter glass. the aroma is certainly robust. my scent-association impressions were mixed: burnt rubber, molasses and graham cracker--if theres any chocolate there its the leftover cocoa husks. id say its a very bitter hoppy stout, and tho its way better than a poke in the eye, i think ill curl my lip downward the next time someone asks: what about this one?!

My review may be a bit biased because this tastes IDENTICAL to a homebrew I recently made.  Imagine my shock when I bought something that tasted just like what I made myself.  Anyhow, the dark flavors are apparent, nutty, roasty, slightly sweet followed by a bitter finish.  I dont know about these guys, but I used Cascade hops in mine.  Medium bodied with light carbonation so it goes down smooth.  Hops and roastiness linger.

Very dark in color but a thin, short-lived head when poured.  Aroma is of dark malt with some coffee-like sweetness from caramel or molasses.  First sip did remind me of Guinness but it is much thinner in body, and a little too light on the palate.  The bitter finish is a nice complement to the sweetness, though, so I dont mind the light body.  It reminded me of a hoppy version of Salvator, strange but ok nevertheless.  So far I like what Ive had from North Coast.
Tasting Notes from Fall 2000:  Porter stout. Hint of chocolate, lightly hopped and not heavy.
Thin in body with a sourness that is not checked by roastiness, malty sweetness or hops, so it takes over. There are many better options out there.
UPDATED: FEB 20, 2005 Dark brown with a big tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and some chocolate. Flavor of  strong roast and very bitter dark chocolate.

Ya know, I dont want to give anyone the wrong impression about this beer, but Im not sure of what I think of it.  It truly reminds me of the Guinness extra stout we all grew up on, but milder and thinner, much thinner. Actually, I held it up to the light to see if was a thin looking as it is tasting. This is a perfectly good stout and will win you a friend or two, but there are more interesting stouts out there, many of them in fact.
I made my overall lower then usual because, in the end, this beer was not the sum of its parts.
Slightly above average stout though I think I may have had a bad bottle.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2003 The key word here seems to be 'coffee'.  Dark brown color with light brown head that dissipates quickly.  Strong hop and coffee nose with maltiness evident in the background.  Very astringent coffee flavors with dark chocolate notes and some sweetness up front.  Very bitter aftertaste, but with intense flavors throughout. Good quality stout, especially if you are a coffee lover.
Not sure what to make of this one. Pretty thin for a stout, but a really nice dry coffee malty flavor.
Dark body. Fairly carbonated. Great malt aroma. Roasted malty taste with hints of mocha. Solid stout.
Fairly thin, sweet stout with medium hops and a strong coffee malt taste.
Dark brown and reddish, with a thick frothy head. Surprisingly light mouthfeel, malty aroma, with a hoppy/malty taste. Overall roasty/burnt quality, not bad, but I have had better.

Number 200! I enjoyed this more than their Rasputin. Inviting coffee and sugar aroma, hinting at the underlying hops.  A bit fizzy, the coffee flavor seems to touch every taste bud on the tongue, and finishes with a nice, mellow hop bitterness.  This beer is rich, almost too rich, and somewhat edgy. A small amount of refinement would make this an excellent brew.
UPDATED: MAY 29, 2003 Caramel, creamy, chocolate malt. Slightly dry finish.. Strong burnt aroma.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2003 The beer pours a quite deep garnet color, the head is initially modest, frothy in texture, but erodes quite quickly leaving a fair to middling sheet of lace to conceal the glass. Light hints of roasted grains and coffee, malt and a pleasant enough nose I guess. Malt and lightly sweet, the top disappointing in its feel, a bit light for this stout lover. Finish is moderately carbonated, the hops adequate, the aftertaste dry. Maybe I should classify it as a beginners stout, certainly most stouts have nothing to fear from this rather Wimpy stout, not bad mind you, just a tad to light for me.

Fairly light bodied for a stout - more like a porter...even more like a dark lager, (oscura, dunkel, even maybe a schwarzbier?).  It esp had those toffeeish, roasted, burnt flavors found in good German dark lagers.
Clean nose.  Dark but not opaque - a deep garnet color.  Light head.
This is an easy drinking stout, you might almost call it a porter based on the texture alone.  Nevertheless, this was a good beer.
